assignments.description:
Self-Reflection Assessment

Deliverables:

Format: Individual assignment; 1-2 page written assessment; double-spaced; MLA format

Points: 50 points

Due Date: Thursday March 17 by 11:59 pm

Assignment Description:

As the quarter ends, take some time to reflect on your critical thinking process, contributions to your team, and your understanding of your topic. Discuss your role as a student, collaborator, and thinker in a written letter to me. In particular, be specific about your roles and contributions for Stasis Three: Claim of Advocacy. Consider answering some of the questions below (you don't need to answer all of them):

  • What do you feel most proud of?
  • What else would you like to work on?
  • What contributions did you make to your team?
  • How well did you and your team collaborate?
  • If you had more time, what else would you do?

No pressure on this assignment. If you write a reflection to the assignment description requirements and post it on time, I will award you a full score of 50 points.

assignments.description:
Claim of Advocacy

Deliverables:

Format: Collaborative Project--Website

Points: 250

Due Date: Tuesday March 15 by 11:59 pm

Overview Description:

This assignment requires your team to now develop a plan of action with your accumulated research and analyses. You will collect your materials from your Claim of Fact Presentation and your individual Claim of Value Essays to take the next step into Advocacy. Your team will create a website to advocate for some demonstrable action. Advocacy requires a few components:

  • Identifying the Problem,
  • Proposing a Plan of Action,
  • Demonstrating why that Action will Address or Alleviate the Problem,
  • Explain how this Plan of Action is Feasible at this Time

See below for more details about these steps.

Objectives:

By the successful completion of this project, students should be able to:

  • Synthesize evidence and analysis into a cohesive website
  • Incorporate source material ethically by documenting all borrowed content using both in-text and works cited citation, avoiding misrepresentation or misattributing source material, and explicitly addressing potential biases, if present.
  • Use clear and concise language to convey message
  • Use appropriate, intentional, and effective rhetorical strategies to convey messages to audience
  • Avoid logical fallacies in website
  • Use technology ethically and effectively to convey their message
  • Demonstrate various strategies of advocacy in the document or website
  • Use digital medium effectively to convey message

Definitions:

  • Advocacy: "any action that speaks in favor of, recommends, argues for a cause, supports or defends, or pleads on behalf of others" ("What is Advocacy")
  • Conventions: "an established technique, practice, or device" ("Conventions")
  • Medium: "a means of effecting or conveying something" ("Medium") Genres include some of the following: website, report, essay, presentation, textbook, newspaper, magazine, podcast, comic book, etc. 

Step One: Identifying the Problem

Reaching consensus about the problems surrounding your topic will provide your team a solid foundation to build your argument. When identifying the problem, your team will need to review your previous materials, research, and feedback to determine the significant problem you think needs attention. A problem should identify stakeholders, tensions, and values. It should also be considered timely and significant to your audience. Consider your answers to the following questions:

  • What lens do you think you need to extend upon or add to your topic to understand it better?
  • What do you see as the most significant problem surrounding your topic?
    • What specific evidence lends itself to this identification?
    • Have you accumulated enough evidence to establish this problem and considered multiple viewpoints? If so, move on. If not, what else do you need to gather? Where will you get it? 
  • Has your team reached consensus about the problem? If so, move on. If not, what are the key points of tension that need addressing?
  • Who does this problem affect or address?
  • What are the tensions between stakeholders? To what extent do these tensions affect the stakeholders? Why does it matter that these tensions affect the stakeholders to this extent?
  • What types of stakeholders, policies, or systems influence or play a role with this problem?
  • How urgent and timely is this problem? Why does it matter that this problem get addressed now?

Once you have reached consensus, it's time to write it out. Make sure to document your research using in-text citation and corresponding works cited page. See "Writing a Problem Statement: 10 Effective Tips (Links to an external site.)" for crafting an effective problem statement.

Step Two: Proposing a Plan of Action and Choosing an Audience

Now that your team has established the problem, what do you think should be the best course of action? In this case, you would propose a solution or next steps, depending upon the complexity of the problem. This proposal should address specific, demonstrable steps to solve or alleviate the problem. Note--if this problem is especially complex, consider more incremental steps if that's more feasible at this stage. Sometimes, however, bold plans may be the best course of action, so develop your position with conscious intent. Consider the following:

  • How does this plan of action address the problem?
  • What is your audience's stake, knowledge base, and stance about this issue?
  • How does this plan of action address the problem?
  • How does this plan of action incorporate your audience?
  • Who or what has the means to implement this plan of action?
    • Is this person(s) or agency motivated to implement this plan of action? If so, what can you do to encourage them to move more quickly or effectively? If not, what do you need to do to convince this person or agency?
  • To what extent does this plan of action address the problem?
  • Why does it matter that this plan of action takes place?

Step Three: Demonstrating why that Action will Solve or Alleviate the Problem

Now that your team has decided on a plan of action, show why that action is the best to undertake. To fully demonstrate this action is the best, your team will need to establish context and anticipate opposition, give voice to that opposition, and counter that opposition effectively. Consider the following:

  • What are other potential solutions or steps to address this problem? 
    • Why are they insufficient or questionable to address this problem?
    • What makes your team's solution or step better? Why is that better?
  • Are any other potential solutions or steps strong?
    • What concessions might your team have to make?
    • How will those concessions still not undermine the effectiveness of your solution or steps? Or do you need to make adjustments to align your points more effectively?
  • Is this the moral or ethical plan to undertake? Why or why not?

Step Four: Explaining how this Plan of Action is Feasible at this Time

A plan of action must be feasible if you want to see it implemented. Therefore, your team must demonstrate or explain how your solution or steps are attainable. Consider the following:

  • Do we have the resources or technology to implement this plan of action?
  • Do we have the funding to implement this plan of action?
  • Do we have the ethical or moral backing to implement this plan of action?
  • Will this plan of action negatively affect any stakeholders? 
    • To what extent are these effects harmful to these stakeholders?
    • Why does it matter that these stakeholders are affected to this extent?
    • Is it acceptable that these stakeholders are affected in these ways? Why or why not?
  • Is the return on investment worth the time, money, sacrifice?
    • To what extent is it worth it?
    • Why does it matter that we invest in this plan of action despite the costs?

Step Five: Using Medium Conventions--Digital Writing

Consider the standard conventions that surround the medium--website digital writing--you select. Identify the ways a reader should interact with your website.

Website Conventions:

  • Logo Placement
  • Main Navigation
  • Visual Content Hierarchy
  • Link Styling
  • Functional Buttons 
  • Colors
  • Consistency between pages
  • Chunking (white space to written text distribution)
  • Composition

See 8.4: Website Resources for more detailed specifics.

Step Six: Creating your Claim of Advocacy

Your team should select a medium for your argument: Website or Report. Review the standard conventions and resources to aid and guide you as you present your argument. See Step Five for links to those resources. The claim of advocacy should read as a cohesive argument regardless of the medium you select. Your claim of advocacy should include the following materials (you determine the order and location of these materials):

  • Statement of the Problem: a clear and well-supported establishment of the problem surrounding your topic; your reader should understand the problem and be convinced that it is a problem; a sense of timeliness and urgency; sufficient evidence to support your team's assertions
  • Plan of Action: an explicit and clear explanation of what your team thinks the reader/audience should do, supported with evidence and reasoned ethically
  • Demonstration of Efficacy: an explanation of how this plan of action will address the problem; a fair voice to potential tensions surrounding the plan of action; a counter or concession to any points of dissent; an explanation of why this plan of action is the more effective course to take
  • Demonstration of Feasibility: an explanation of how this plan of action is possible; a discussion of resources, funds, sacrifices, etc.--whatever is applicable; a reinforcement of why this plan is worth any costs
  • Incorporation of Research: include relevant and reliable research using documentation requirements for MLA--in-text citation and corresponding works cited page; minimum of 10 sources for this project--you may choose from previous projects or add new sources: they should be the best type of source for the type of evidence you're using
  • Incorporation of Graphics or Data Visualizations: include clarifying graphics or data visualizations to illustrate or clarify concepts to your reader; minimum of 5 graphics for this project--your team must create 3 of these graphics/data visualizations and then you may borrow any additional graphics; the visual aids must illustrate concepts or information, not just be decorative
  • Development of Argument: approximately 2000 quality words that read cohesively and consistently
  • Application of Medium: effectively use the medium to its potential in the argument by employing standard conventions and rhetorical strategies to resonate with audience

Post Claim of Advocacy Assignment Post to this assignment link Tuesday March 15 by 11:59 pm

Video Assignment Description

Assignment Posting

Your team created a website, so please include the website url here. You can make the site just visible to people who have the link. Also, if you used Google Sites, you will need to make any files shareable for me to be able to access.

Assessment:

I will review your Self-Reflection assignment and your Team Contract prior to grading your Claim of Advocacy projects. Although I will tend toward grading the project as a team effort, I do reserve the right to grade each student individually based on my evaluation, your self-reflection discussion about your contributions as well as your teammates', and your team contract agreement if the circumstances deem it necessary. See rubric below for grading criteria and description.

Sample Advocacy Websites

  • Ocean Clean Wash (Links to an external site.) (Informs people about microfibers and offer solutions for consumers and companies)
  • Prison Policy Initiative (researches to encourage advocacy campaigns)
  • Fight the New Drug (Links to an external site.) (Raises awareness about harmful effects of pornography and provides articles for education and support)
  • Greenpeace International (environmental advocacy and fundraising)
  • CASA San Luis Obispo (court appointed special advocates for children)
  • 10 Websites that are Doing It Right

Data Visualization Resources

  • Kennedy Library Slideshow to Data VisualizationLinks to an external site.
  • Image CollectionLinks to an external site.--allows you to find usable images without violating copyright
  • Color Wheel (Links to an external site.)--helps you identify effective color combinations
  • Data Visualization Catalogue (Links to an external site.)--directs you to the best resources for making the types of data visualizations you want to use
  • WebPlot Digitizer (Links to an external site.)--allows you to reverse engineer existing data visualizations and extract the numerical data
  • Census Data Tables-- helps you find datasets
  • Introduction to Data VisualizationLinks to an external site.
  • 7 Principles of Art and Design (Links to an external site.)--provides composition principles for design
  • Information is Beautiful (Links to an external site.)--includes numerous data visualization examples and their excel sheets

Accommodations for DRC or Document Accessibility

It is university policy to provide, on a flexible and individualized basis, reasonable accommodations to students who have disabilities that may affect their ability to participate in course activities or meet course requirements. Students with disabilities are encouraged to contact their instructor to discuss their individual needs for accommodations. If you need to convert a file to a more accessible medium, please use Sensus AccessLinks to an external site.

References:

"Conventions."  Merriam Webster Dictionary, https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/conventions, Accessed 22 Dec. 2020.

"Medium." Merriam Webster Dictionary, https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/medium, Accessed 22 Dec. 2020. 

"What is Advocacy." Alliance for Justice, https://mffh.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/AFJ_what-is-advocacy.pdf, Accessed 11 Dec. 2020.

assignments.name: Stasis Theory: Claim of Advocacy

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the manageability of the scope, the establishment of the problem, and the quality of the thesis.

ratings.long_description: The writers establish a narrow and manageable scope that succinctly and creatively addresses the problem. The team reaches a cohesive consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that addresses that problem in meaningful, creative, and constructive ways. The thesis is consistently developed and supported in cogent, stylistic, and convincing ways.

The writers establish a narrow and manageable scope that succinctly addresses the problem. The team reaches a cohesive consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that addresses that problem in meaningful and constructive ways. The thesis is consistently developed and supported in cogent and convincing ways.

The writers establish a mostly manageable yet general scope that addresses the problem. The team reaches some consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that addresses that problem in general ways. The thesis is generally developed and supported.

The writers establish a somewhat unwieldy scope that somewhat addresses the problem. The team reaches an inconsistent consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that doesn't quite address that problem. The thesis is somewhat under-developed and supported.

The writers establish a consistently unwieldy scope that doesn't address the problem. The team reaches no consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that doesn't address that problem. The thesis is consistently under-developed and supported. The writers consistently stray from the controlling idea.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the quality of the reasoning based on the evidence, conclusions drawn from the evidence, thoroughness of the reasoning, and the challenges addressed (tensions/alignments) in the reasoning, quality of graphics to supplement reasoning, and quality of support

ratings.long_description: The writers provide ample and cogent reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate insight, depth, and logical reasoning. The writers consistently address tensions and alignments within the argument and provide creative and well-reasoned counterarguments and/or concessions that don't undermine their main position. The level of support is thorough, relevant, and compelling. The 5 graphics provide compelling and engaging support to the discussion. Of those 5 graphics, the 3 original data visualizations significantly contribute to the reasoning in ethical and demonstrable ways.

The writers provide cogent and strong reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate insight and logical reasoning. The writers strongly address tensions and alignments within the argument and provide well-reasoned counterarguments and/or concessions that don't undermine their main position. The level of support is strong and relevant. The 5 graphics provide clear and strong support to the discussion. Of those 5 graphics, the 3 original data visualizations mostly contribute to the reasoning in ethical and demonstrable ways.

The writers provide general or uneven reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate some logical reasoning but may benefit from more depth. The writers address some tensions and alignments within the argument and provide some counterarguments and/or concessions but may struggle with the examination or leave off the discussion too early. The writers may miss some opportunities to expand or extend the discussion. The level of support is general or somewhat uneven. The 5 graphics provide general support to the discussion.  Of those 5 graphics, the 3 original data visualizations generally contribute to the reasoning in ethical and demonstrable ways.

The writers provide uneven reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate some illogical reasoning. The writers address few tensions and alignments within the argument and somewhat provide some counterarguments and/or concessions but consistently struggle with the examination or leave off the discussion too early. The writers miss some significant opportunities to explore the discussion. The level of support is consistently  uneven or sometimes irrelevant. The 5 graphics may provide uneven or irrelevant support to the discussion. May be missing one graphic.  Of those 5 graphics, the 3 original data visualizations somewhat contribute to the reasoning but may have lapses in ethical design or have redundant or loose connections to the controlling idea.

The writers provide consistent flawed reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate consistent illogical reasoning. The writers address no tensions or alignments within the argument and provide few counterarguments and/or concessions but leave off the discussion too early. The writers miss quite a few significant opportunities to explore the discussion. The level of support is consistently uneven or often irrelevant. The 5 graphics consistently provide irrelevant support to the discussion. May be missing two or more graphics. Maybe the required 3 original data visualizations aren't all present or have faulty connections to the reasoning but significant flaws in ethical design.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the application of the medium selected for the topic, the quality of the way the writers meet audience expectations through the genre of the medium and convey the topic, the formatting professionalism, and the accessibility of the medium.

ratings.long_description: The team uses the medium of choice to an exemplary degree. They use all the standard conventions of the medium to fully and creatively execute their claim of advocacy argument. The document or website is professionally presented, proofread, and accessible to the audience, fully meeting those audience expectations.

The team uses the medium of choice to a strong degree. They use most of the standard conventions of the medium to clearly execute their claim of advocacy argument. The document or website is mostly professionally presented, proofread, and accessible to the audience, mostly meeting those audience expectations.

The team uses the medium of choice to a competent degree. They use some of the standard conventions of the medium to generally execute their claim of advocacy argument. The document or website is somewhat professionally presented, proofread, and accessible to the audience, generally meeting those audience expectations.

The team uses the medium of choice to a problematic degree. They use some of the standard conventions of the medium to execute their claim of advocacy argument but the missing conventions lead to some reader confusion. The document or website misses some marks in its presentation, has some proofreading errors, and some accessibility problems for the audience, not consistently meeting those audience expectations.

The team uses the medium of choice to a consistently problematic degree. They use few to none of the standard conventions of the medium to execute their claim of advocacy argument. The missing conventions consistently lead to reader confusion. The document or website misses significant marks in its presentation, has confusing proofreading errors, and consistent accessibility problems for the audience, not meeting audience expectations.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the quality of the synthesis of all source material, the ethical use of source material, the accuracy of MLA8 source citation both in-text and works cited, the quantity of source material--10 sources minimum required

ratings.long_description: Contains a fully accurately formatted works cited; uses strong, reliable sources including a minimum of 10 total; cites all borrowed material accurately and ethically; varies source integration by using a combination of signal phrases and parenthetical citation; smoothly and seamlessly integrates all borrowed content.

Contains an accurately formatted works cited; uses strong, reliable sources including a minimum of 10 total; cites all borrowed material accurately and ethically; varies source integration by using a combination of signal phrases and parenthetical citation; smoothly integrates all borrowed content.

Contains a somewhat accurate formatted works cited but may be missing some minor materials; uses general sources or might have one questionable source; uses minimum of 10 sources total; cites most borrowed material accurately; minor ethical issues in integrating material; somewhat redundant source integration; redundant techniques of integrating all borrowed content. May contain a couple of floating quotes

Contains a inconsistent formatted works cited or may be missing some major materials; uses general sources or might have two or three questionable sources; uses minimum of 10 sources total; cites some borrowed material inaccurately; a major ethical issue in integrating material; consistently redundant source integration; redundant techniques of integrating all borrowed content. May contain a few floating quotes

Contains an inaccurate formatted works cited or missing some major materials; uses consistently questionable sources or misrepresents sources; cites most borrowed material inaccurately; major ethical issues in integrating material; consistently redundant source integration; neglects to integrate all borrowed content. Unintentional plagiarism resulting in 25-point + deductions--see flagged items in the comments. Neglects to include the minimum requirement of 10 sources total

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the overall structure and organization of the argument using coherence strategies and cogent indications of where the reader should proceed.

ratings.long_description: Invisible but apparent; Strong, smooth transitions, easy to follow; establishes a clear and cogent line of reasoning; unified paragraphs; uses variety of coherence tools that are seamless and fully appropriate for the logical connection. Applies coherence strategies for Medium clearly and creatively

Original, strong, mostly smooth and logical transitions; clear line of reasoning most of the time; unified paragraphs; uses variety of coherence tools that are mostly seamless and appropriate for the logical connection. Applies coherence strategies with Medium choice clearly.

Some minor coherence issues; formulaic in places; unified paragraphs; transitions are present but somewhat redundant; Uses general but logical transitions; clear line of reasoning most of the time; unified paragraphs; Applies coherence choices to Medium generally, repetitively, or somewhat inconsistently.

Difficult to follow; some disunified paragraphs; unclear progression of ideas; transitions are often imprecise or author neglects to include transitions; choppy; meanders; Some confusing coherence issues within the medium
No structure; very confusing; illogical sequence; disjointed; coherence issues in medium choice significantly affects the reasoning and accessibility.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the quality of ethos the writers present in their arguments with a focus on cohesiveness and presence of voice, precision of language, clarity of syntax, professionalism of presentation, and understanding of audience needs.

ratings.long_description: Takes risks; original and cohesive voice; rich, precise and varied vocabulary; provides a clear impression of team's stance; few to no minor grammatical errors; concise; Demonstrates a thorough and sophisticated understanding of the topic and uses convincing, stylistic rhetorical techniques in advocacy

Takes some risks; mostly cohesive voice; precise vocabulary; provides a clear impression of team's stance; few minor grammatical errors; concise; Demonstrates a strong understanding of the topic and uses convincing rhetorical techniques in advocacy

Somewhat cohesive voice but may slip here or there; general vocabulary; provides a general impression of team's stance; some distracting grammatical errors that don't affect comprehension; Some redundancy; Demonstrates a general understanding of the topic and uses few rhetorical techniques in advocacy

Somewhat non-cohesive voice; imprecise vocabulary; provides a somewhat confusing impression of team's stance; some consistent distracting grammatical errors that affect comprehension; Consistent redundancy; Demonstrates a flawed understanding of the topic and uses some alienating rhetorical techniques in advocacy

non-cohesive voice; imprecise and confusing vocabulary; provides a consistently confusing impression of team's stance; some distracting grammatical errors that significantly affect comprehension; Consistent redundancy; Demonstrates a significantly flawed understanding of the topic and uses alienating rhetorical techniques in advocacy

assignment.description:
Claim of Advocacy

Deliverables:

Format: Collaborative Project--Website

Points: 250

Due Date: Tuesday March 15 by 11:59 pm

Overview Description:

This assignment requires your team to now develop a plan of action with your accumulated research and analyses. You will collect your materials from your Claim of Fact Presentation and your individual Claim of Value Essays to take the next step into Advocacy. Your team will create a website to advocate for some demonstrable action. Advocacy requires a few components:

  • Identifying the Problem,
  • Proposing a Plan of Action,
  • Demonstrating why that Action will Address or Alleviate the Problem,
  • Explain how this Plan of Action is Feasible at this Time

See below for more details about these steps.

Objectives:

By the successful completion of this project, students should be able to:

  • Synthesize evidence and analysis into a cohesive website
  • Incorporate source material ethically by documenting all borrowed content using both in-text and works cited citation, avoiding misrepresentation or misattributing source material, and explicitly addressing potential biases, if present.
  • Use clear and concise language to convey message
  • Use appropriate, intentional, and effective rhetorical strategies to convey messages to audience
  • Avoid logical fallacies in website
  • Use technology ethically and effectively to convey their message
  • Demonstrate various strategies of advocacy in the document or website
  • Use digital medium effectively to convey message

Definitions:

  • Advocacy: "any action that speaks in favor of, recommends, argues for a cause, supports or defends, or pleads on behalf of others" ("What is Advocacy")
  • Conventions: "an established technique, practice, or device" ("Conventions")
  • Medium: "a means of effecting or conveying something" ("Medium") Genres include some of the following: website, report, essay, presentation, textbook, newspaper, magazine, podcast, comic book, etc. 

Step One: Identifying the Problem

Reaching consensus about the problems surrounding your topic will provide your team a solid foundation to build your argument. When identifying the problem, your team will need to review your previous materials, research, and feedback to determine the significant problem you think needs attention. A problem should identify stakeholders, tensions, and values. It should also be considered timely and significant to your audience. Consider your answers to the following questions:

  • What lens do you think you need to extend upon or add to your topic to understand it better?
  • What do you see as the most significant problem surrounding your topic?
    • What specific evidence lends itself to this identification?
    • Have you accumulated enough evidence to establish this problem and considered multiple viewpoints? If so, move on. If not, what else do you need to gather? Where will you get it? 
  • Has your team reached consensus about the problem? If so, move on. If not, what are the key points of tension that need addressing?
  • Who does this problem affect or address?
  • What are the tensions between stakeholders? To what extent do these tensions affect the stakeholders? Why does it matter that these tensions affect the stakeholders to this extent?
  • What types of stakeholders, policies, or systems influence or play a role with this problem?
  • How urgent and timely is this problem? Why does it matter that this problem get addressed now?

Once you have reached consensus, it's time to write it out. Make sure to document your research using in-text citation and corresponding works cited page. See "Writing a Problem Statement: 10 Effective Tips (Links to an external site.)" for crafting an effective problem statement.

Step Two: Proposing a Plan of Action and Choosing an Audience

Now that your team has established the problem, what do you think should be the best course of action? In this case, you would propose a solution or next steps, depending upon the complexity of the problem. This proposal should address specific, demonstrable steps to solve or alleviate the problem. Note--if this problem is especially complex, consider more incremental steps if that's more feasible at this stage. Sometimes, however, bold plans may be the best course of action, so develop your position with conscious intent. Consider the following:

  • How does this plan of action address the problem?
  • What is your audience's stake, knowledge base, and stance about this issue?
  • How does this plan of action address the problem?
  • How does this plan of action incorporate your audience?
  • Who or what has the means to implement this plan of action?
    • Is this person(s) or agency motivated to implement this plan of action? If so, what can you do to encourage them to move more quickly or effectively? If not, what do you need to do to convince this person or agency?
  • To what extent does this plan of action address the problem?
  • Why does it matter that this plan of action takes place?

Step Three: Demonstrating why that Action will Solve or Alleviate the Problem

Now that your team has decided on a plan of action, show why that action is the best to undertake. To fully demonstrate this action is the best, your team will need to establish context and anticipate opposition, give voice to that opposition, and counter that opposition effectively. Consider the following:

  • What are other potential solutions or steps to address this problem? 
    • Why are they insufficient or questionable to address this problem?
    • What makes your team's solution or step better? Why is that better?
  • Are any other potential solutions or steps strong?
    • What concessions might your team have to make?
    • How will those concessions still not undermine the effectiveness of your solution or steps? Or do you need to make adjustments to align your points more effectively?
  • Is this the moral or ethical plan to undertake? Why or why not?

Step Four: Explaining how this Plan of Action is Feasible at this Time

A plan of action must be feasible if you want to see it implemented. Therefore, your team must demonstrate or explain how your solution or steps are attainable. Consider the following:

  • Do we have the resources or technology to implement this plan of action?
  • Do we have the funding to implement this plan of action?
  • Do we have the ethical or moral backing to implement this plan of action?
  • Will this plan of action negatively affect any stakeholders? 
    • To what extent are these effects harmful to these stakeholders?
    • Why does it matter that these stakeholders are affected to this extent?
    • Is it acceptable that these stakeholders are affected in these ways? Why or why not?
  • Is the return on investment worth the time, money, sacrifice?
    • To what extent is it worth it?
    • Why does it matter that we invest in this plan of action despite the costs?

Step Five: Using Medium Conventions--Digital Writing

Consider the standard conventions that surround the medium--website digital writing--you select. Identify the ways a reader should interact with your website.

Website Conventions:

  • Logo Placement
  • Main Navigation
  • Visual Content Hierarchy
  • Link Styling
  • Functional Buttons 
  • Colors
  • Consistency between pages
  • Chunking (white space to written text distribution)
  • Composition

See 8.4: Website Resources for more detailed specifics.

Step Six: Creating your Claim of Advocacy

Your team should select a medium for your argument: Website or Report. Review the standard conventions and resources to aid and guide you as you present your argument. See Step Five for links to those resources. The claim of advocacy should read as a cohesive argument regardless of the medium you select. Your claim of advocacy should include the following materials (you determine the order and location of these materials):

  • Statement of the Problem: a clear and well-supported establishment of the problem surrounding your topic; your reader should understand the problem and be convinced that it is a problem; a sense of timeliness and urgency; sufficient evidence to support your team's assertions
  • Plan of Action: an explicit and clear explanation of what your team thinks the reader/audience should do, supported with evidence and reasoned ethically
  • Demonstration of Efficacy: an explanation of how this plan of action will address the problem; a fair voice to potential tensions surrounding the plan of action; a counter or concession to any points of dissent; an explanation of why this plan of action is the more effective course to take
  • Demonstration of Feasibility: an explanation of how this plan of action is possible; a discussion of resources, funds, sacrifices, etc.--whatever is applicable; a reinforcement of why this plan is worth any costs
  • Incorporation of Research: include relevant and reliable research using documentation requirements for MLA--in-text citation and corresponding works cited page; minimum of 10 sources for this project--you may choose from previous projects or add new sources: they should be the best type of source for the type of evidence you're using
  • Incorporation of Graphics or Data Visualizations: include clarifying graphics or data visualizations to illustrate or clarify concepts to your reader; minimum of 5 graphics for this project--your team must create 3 of these graphics/data visualizations and then you may borrow any additional graphics; the visual aids must illustrate concepts or information, not just be decorative
  • Development of Argument: approximately 2000 quality words that read cohesively and consistently
  • Application of Medium: effectively use the medium to its potential in the argument by employing standard conventions and rhetorical strategies to resonate with audience

Assessment:

I will review your Self-Reflection assignment and your Team Contract prior to grading your Claim of Advocacy projects. Although I will tend toward grading the project as a team effort, I do reserve the right to grade each student individually based on my evaluation, your self-reflection discussion about your contributions as well as your teammates', and your team contract agreement if the circumstances deem it necessary. Sample Advocacy Websites

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the manageability of the scope, the establishment of the problem, and the quality of the thesis.

ratings.long_description: The writers establish a narrow and manageable scope that succinctly and creatively addresses the problem. The team reaches a cohesive consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that addresses that problem in meaningful, creative, and constructive ways. The thesis is consistently developed and supported in cogent, stylistic, and convincing ways.

The writers establish a narrow and manageable scope that succinctly addresses the problem. The team reaches a cohesive consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that addresses that problem in meaningful and constructive ways. The thesis is consistently developed and supported in cogent and convincing ways.

The writers establish a mostly manageable yet general scope that addresses the problem. The team reaches some consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that addresses that problem in general ways. The thesis is generally developed and supported.

The writers establish a somewhat unwieldy scope that somewhat addresses the problem. The team reaches an inconsistent consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that doesn't quite address that problem. The thesis is somewhat under-developed and supported.

The writers establish a consistently unwieldy scope that doesn't address the problem. The team reaches no consensus in their establishing of the problem and crafts a thesis that doesn't address that problem. The thesis is consistently under-developed and supported. The writers consistently stray from the controlling idea.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the quality of the reasoning based on the evidence, conclusions drawn from the evidence, thoroughness of the reasoning, and the challenges addressed (tensions/alignments) in the reasoning, quality of graphics to supplement reasoning, and quality of support

ratings.long_description: The writers provide ample and cogent reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate insight, depth, and logical reasoning. The writers consistently address tensions and alignments within the argument and provide creative and well-reasoned counterarguments and/or concessions that don't undermine their main position. The level of support is thorough, relevant, and compelling. The 5 graphics provide compelling and engaging support to the discussion. Of those 5 graphics, the 3 original data visualizations significantly contribute to the reasoning in ethical and demonstrable ways.

The writers provide cogent and strong reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate insight and logical reasoning. The writers strongly address tensions and alignments within the argument and provide well-reasoned counterarguments and/or concessions that don't undermine their main position. The level of support is strong and relevant. The 5 graphics provide clear and strong support to the discussion. Of those 5 graphics, the 3 original data visualizations mostly contribute to the reasoning in ethical and demonstrable ways.

The writers provide general or uneven reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate some logical reasoning but may benefit from more depth. The writers address some tensions and alignments within the argument and provide some counterarguments and/or concessions but may struggle with the examination or leave off the discussion too early. The writers may miss some opportunities to expand or extend the discussion. The level of support is general or somewhat uneven. The 5 graphics provide general support to the discussion.  Of those 5 graphics, the 3 original data visualizations generally contribute to the reasoning in ethical and demonstrable ways.

The writers provide uneven reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate some illogical reasoning. The writers address few tensions and alignments within the argument and somewhat provide some counterarguments and/or concessions but consistently struggle with the examination or leave off the discussion too early. The writers miss some significant opportunities to explore the discussion. The level of support is consistently  uneven or sometimes irrelevant. The 5 graphics may provide uneven or irrelevant support to the discussion. May be missing one graphic.  Of those 5 graphics, the 3 original data visualizations somewhat contribute to the reasoning but may have lapses in ethical design or have redundant or loose connections to the controlling idea.

The writers provide consistent flawed reasoning throughout the argument. The conclusions drawn from the evidence indicate consistent illogical reasoning. The writers address no tensions or alignments within the argument and provide few counterarguments and/or concessions but leave off the discussion too early. The writers miss quite a few significant opportunities to explore the discussion. The level of support is consistently uneven or often irrelevant. The 5 graphics consistently provide irrelevant support to the discussion. May be missing two or more graphics. Maybe the required 3 original data visualizations aren't all present or have faulty connections to the reasoning but significant flaws in ethical design.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the application of the medium selected for the topic, the quality of the way the writers meet audience expectations through the genre of the medium and convey the topic, the formatting professionalism, and the accessibility of the medium.

ratings.long_description: The team uses the medium of choice to an exemplary degree. They use all the standard conventions of the medium to fully and creatively execute their claim of advocacy argument. The document or website is professionally presented, proofread, and accessible to the audience, fully meeting those audience expectations.

The team uses the medium of choice to a strong degree. They use most of the standard conventions of the medium to clearly execute their claim of advocacy argument. The document or website is mostly professionally presented, proofread, and accessible to the audience, mostly meeting those audience expectations.

The team uses the medium of choice to a competent degree. They use some of the standard conventions of the medium to generally execute their claim of advocacy argument. The document or website is somewhat professionally presented, proofread, and accessible to the audience, generally meeting those audience expectations.

The team uses the medium of choice to a problematic degree. They use some of the standard conventions of the medium to execute their claim of advocacy argument but the missing conventions lead to some reader confusion. The document or website misses some marks in its presentation, has some proofreading errors, and some accessibility problems for the audience, not consistently meeting those audience expectations.

The team uses the medium of choice to a consistently problematic degree. They use few to none of the standard conventions of the medium to execute their claim of advocacy argument. The missing conventions consistently lead to reader confusion. The document or website misses significant marks in its presentation, has confusing proofreading errors, and consistent accessibility problems for the audience, not meeting audience expectations.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the quality of the synthesis of all source material, the ethical use of source material, the accuracy of MLA8 source citation both in-text and works cited, the quantity of source material--10 sources minimum required

ratings.long_description: Contains a fully accurately formatted works cited; uses strong, reliable sources including a minimum of 10 total; cites all borrowed material accurately and ethically; varies source integration by using a combination of signal phrases and parenthetical citation; smoothly and seamlessly integrates all borrowed content.

Contains an accurately formatted works cited; uses strong, reliable sources including a minimum of 10 total; cites all borrowed material accurately and ethically; varies source integration by using a combination of signal phrases and parenthetical citation; smoothly integrates all borrowed content.

Contains a somewhat accurate formatted works cited but may be missing some minor materials; uses general sources or might have one questionable source; uses minimum of 10 sources total; cites most borrowed material accurately; minor ethical issues in integrating material; somewhat redundant source integration; redundant techniques of integrating all borrowed content. May contain a couple of floating quotes

Contains a inconsistent formatted works cited or may be missing some major materials; uses general sources or might have two or three questionable sources; uses minimum of 10 sources total; cites some borrowed material inaccurately; a major ethical issue in integrating material; consistently redundant source integration; redundant techniques of integrating all borrowed content. May contain a few floating quotes

Contains an inaccurate formatted works cited or missing some major materials; uses consistently questionable sources or misrepresents sources; cites most borrowed material inaccurately; major ethical issues in integrating material; consistently redundant source integration; neglects to integrate all borrowed content. Unintentional plagiarism resulting in 25-point + deductions--see flagged items in the comments. Neglects to include the minimum requirement of 10 sources total

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the overall structure and organization of the argument using coherence strategies and cogent indications of where the reader should proceed.

ratings.long_description: Invisible but apparent; Strong, smooth transitions, easy to follow; establishes a clear and cogent line of reasoning; unified paragraphs; uses variety of coherence tools that are seamless and fully appropriate for the logical connection. Applies coherence strategies for Medium clearly and creatively

Original, strong, mostly smooth and logical transitions; clear line of reasoning most of the time; unified paragraphs; uses variety of coherence tools that are mostly seamless and appropriate for the logical connection. Applies coherence strategies with Medium choice clearly.

Some minor coherence issues; formulaic in places; unified paragraphs; transitions are present but somewhat redundant; Uses general but logical transitions; clear line of reasoning most of the time; unified paragraphs; Applies coherence choices to Medium generally, repetitively, or somewhat inconsistently.

Difficult to follow; some disunified paragraphs; unclear progression of ideas; transitions are often imprecise or author neglects to include transitions; choppy; meanders; Some confusing coherence issues within the medium
No structure; very confusing; illogical sequence; disjointed; coherence issues in medium choice significantly affects the reasoning and accessibility.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the quality of ethos the writers present in their arguments with a focus on cohesiveness and presence of voice, precision of language, clarity of syntax, professionalism of presentation, and understanding of audience needs.

ratings.long_description: Takes risks; original and cohesive voice; rich, precise and varied vocabulary; provides a clear impression of team's stance; few to no minor grammatical errors; concise; Demonstrates a thorough and sophisticated understanding of the topic and uses convincing, stylistic rhetorical techniques in advocacy

Takes some risks; mostly cohesive voice; precise vocabulary; provides a clear impression of team's stance; few minor grammatical errors; concise; Demonstrates a strong understanding of the topic and uses convincing rhetorical techniques in advocacy

Somewhat cohesive voice but may slip here or there; general vocabulary; provides a general impression of team's stance; some distracting grammatical errors that don't affect comprehension; Some redundancy; Demonstrates a general understanding of the topic and uses few rhetorical techniques in advocacy

Somewhat non-cohesive voice; imprecise vocabulary; provides a somewhat confusing impression of team's stance; some consistent distracting grammatical errors that affect comprehension; Consistent redundancy; Demonstrates a flawed understanding of the topic and uses some alienating rhetorical techniques in advocacy

non-cohesive voice; imprecise and confusing vocabulary; provides a consistently confusing impression of team's stance; some distracting grammatical errors that significantly affect comprehension; Consistent redundancy; Demonstrates a significantly flawed understanding of the topic and uses alienating rhetorical techniques in advocacy

assignments.description:
Stasis Theory: Claim of Fact

Deliverables:

Format: Collaborative Presentation and Slideshow

Points: 150

Due Date: Wednesday Jan. 26 by 11:59 pm

Each member of the team needs to:

  • Post slideshow to assignment in pdf or shareable file to google slideshow (make sure to share it so that I can access it later)
  • Post link to video presentation (Zoom recording, YouTube, Screencast-o-matic)
  • Participate in Question and Answer session through a Canvas Discussion

Overview Description:

No time seems more pertinent than now to discern fact from fiction or opinion. As many of us most likely have witnessed, opinions posing as facts have been bandied about on a daily basis in our media, our government, and even our science. For this project, you and your team will find hard evidence to construct a claim of fact about your selected topic. This topic must be science-based, as you're taking a course called Writing Arguments about STEM. Your team's job is to postpone judgment or evaluation until you have the evidence necessary to construct your claim. That means that you each must identify and interrogate any preconceived assumptions to verify accuracy. At these early stages of inquiry, pretend that you know nothing about this topic as you gather your research.

You will be working with this topic all quarter long, so make sure that your team reaches an enthusiastic consensus about your topic. Everyone needs to be invested in the topic.

Objectives:

By the successful completion of this project, students should be able to:

  • Use research techniques and resources to find relevant evidence
  • Evaluate the reliability of source material
  • Apply hard evidence to construct an argumentative claim based on fact
  • Cite all borrowed research in MLA 8 format using both in-text and works cited requirements
  • Develop a cohesive, collaborative presentation featuring a claim of fact for a STEM-based topic to peers and instructor

Definitions:

  • Artistic Proofs: "arguments the writer/speaker creates" (Lunsford and Ruskiewicz 56)
  • Inartistic Proofs: "arguments the writer/speaker is given" (Lunsford and Ruskiewicz 56)
  • Hard Evidence: "facts that are definitely true and can be proved" ("hard evidence"); Examples: facts, statistics, testimonies, documents, contracts, witnesses (Lunsford and Ruskiewicz 56)
  • Constructed Arguments: "appeals to reason; common sense" (Lunsford and Ruskiewicz 56)

Step One: Sign up for a Team

STEM fields rely on collaboration, so this sequence of assignments throughout the quarter will require you to collaborate. Select a team comprising between 2 to 4 members who can reach consensus about a quarter-long topic. Every team member must agree on the selected topic in order to make this quarter's requirements work effectively for everyone. Once you've selected your topic, each team member must approach that topic through a different lens or focal point. Your Claim of Fact and Claim of Advocacy projects will require you to work with the team you selected.

How to Sign up for a Team: 

  • How do I join a Group as a Student?

Step Two: Choose a Topic

Select a STEM-based topic that your team is genuinely interested in exploring and that has enough complexity to extend into a claim of value and eventual claim of advocacy. Every team member must agree on the selected topic in order to make this quarter's requirements work effectively for everyone. Once you've selected your topic, each team member must approach that topic through a different lens or focal point. 

Broad Topics to Narrow Scope Examples:

Finding a Suitable Scope for Topic
Broad Topic Narrowed Scope and Potential Lens within Scope
Digital Currency
  • Bitcoin mining
    • environmental impacts
Space Exploration
  • Telescopes
    • James Webb
  • Solar Sails
    • design
Climate Change
  • Coral Reef Bleaching
    • Great Barrier Reef
  • Deforestation in Amazon
    • Techniques
  • Fracking
    • Pennsylvania Marcellus Shale
Technology
  • Algorithms used in Search Engines
  • CRISPR
    • Gene Modification
  • 3D Printing Capabilities
    • Human Organs
  • Drone Usage in the Military

Example:

Let's say, for example, my team is interested in sustainability issues (really broad) and after some discussion we have decided to narrow the focus to plastics in the United States (sufficiently narrow and complex enough to examine over the quarter). My team can look at plastic through multiple lenses:

  • production—how it’s produced, who produces it, materials used to make it, system of its distribution
  • disposal—how it’s disposed of, where it goes, how much is recyclable, who’s responsible for redemption values, systems (or lack thereof) in place to dispose, etc.
  • consumption—who uses, its application, longevity of use, what it’s used for, etc.

Each team member is responsible for researching plastics through one of these lenses in detail. So, if I chose "disposal" as my lens, I would find hard evidence from reliable sources that focuses on how the United States disposes of plastics. I would need to find research that answers fact-finding questions: 

  • Do the majority of United States municipalities dispose of plastic? If so, to what extent? In what ways?
  • Is the United States recycling its plastic? If so, to what extent? In what ways? If not, where is that plastic being sent to?
  • Are redemption centers available to collect consumer recyclable plastic? If so, to what extent do consumers use them? If so, where are these redemption centers located? If so, what are the available times these redemption centers accept recyclable plastic?
  • Are systems available in cities and states to dispose of plastic? If so, in what ways are they disposing of plastic? To what extent are they disposing of harmful chemicals/pollutants? Are these disposal methods affecting surrounding communities' water supplies, air quality, etc.?
  • Do the companies that produce the plastic also recycle the plastic? If so, to what extent? 

As you can see, the possibilities within the lens allow multiple directions based on the type of evidence you encounter as you cast that wide net. Ask many questions! You may find through your research that your team may need to narrow the focus even more. That's fine.

See OWL at Purdue's Stasis Theory reading for some sample questions to get you started. We will work on developing more customized questions as your team selects a topic.

Look for reliable sources to establish the hard evidence surrounding the topic. Use the information you've gathered from the Library Module in Canvas and the Library Introduction to Databases to help you find great hard evidence. 

Step Two: Hard Evidence and Artistic Proofs

Hard evidence is demonstrable and verifiable. It is considered true and irrefutable. However, in the sciences, we tend to stay critical and skeptical of how we interpret our evidence as we gather data. We have to look at the methodologies of acquiring that evidence and confirm that the collection is based on sound practices. That means that the research you acquire in your inquiry practice also needs to look at the ways in which that data was gathered. Relying on reliable sources with a reputation for using sound methodologies is important as you accumulate your evidence. However, facts can change according to new information and definitions we construct from that information. For example, when I was a kid, Pluto was a planet. Now, as we've acquired more data regarding planets' characteristics and Pluto, we've reclassified Pluto as a dwarf planet. That is now a fact. As we gather more data and refine our understanding of Pluto, we might even change that label--if the scientific community reaches consensus.

It's also important that you compile a sufficient amount of evidence to construct a strong claim. In artistic proofs, you interpret the hard evidence you've amassed over multiple sources and construct a claim of fact that is a statement of fact. The key here is that the statement of fact must focus on the principle of accuracy without overstatement or speculation. If your findings are inconclusive, that is still a claim of fact. If your findings indicate a probability, then your claim of fact needs to include language that indicates the extent to which that probability exists. Using qualifiers, acknowledging limitations, etc. all contribute to making a strong claim of fact. As you work with your team, make sure to devote some time and attention to the methodologies, sample sizes, representation distribution, etc. of the studies and information you use. Consider the strengths and limitations of the studies as your team analyzes the information and constructs your claim. What is your team's consensus on all the research you've acquired?

Step Three: Presentation

Once you have each amassed sufficient information, your team will combine your findings and present them as a claim of fact to the rest of the class in a recorded video presentation. When you construct a claim of fact, you gather the evidence, interpret the significance of that evidence, and arrive at a conclusion based solely on that evidence. Having great guiding questions starting with "Is," "Does," "In what ways," or "To what extent" will allow you to answer that question as a group. The answer may be more complicated than "yes" or "no," so keep yourselves open to an accurate consensus rather than an oversimplified one. Avoid answering value-based questions: e.g., is X better than Y? These types of questions will stray from objective and observable facts.

In a slideshow, present your team’s findings to the rest of the class. Include the following elements:

  • The topic selected and its broader issue
  • Each team member’s name on the title slide
  • The lenses your team selected and why; make sure to identify who is responsible for each lens on the slide
  • A works cited slide for each lens and the team member responsible for that lens
  • The findings—should be a combination of both written and visual text; include citations both within the relevant slide and the works cited lens slide at the end
  • A summation and conclusion of the facts your team can now assert about the topic or issue from your research and a description of the key takeaways
  • An invitation for questions from the class and subsequent answers from team members
  • The presentations should range from 10-12 minutes

Presentation Guidelines:

  • Time: Your presentations should take up no more than 10 minutes, with each member contributing to explain their lens, topic, and slides.
  • Research Requirements: Each member should include a minimum of 6 sources providing fact-based hard evidence. Hard evidence includes raw data, charts, graphs, examples, events, forensics, etc. However, it is acceptable (if relevant) for members to use some of the same sources, so I encourage you to share your research and findings with each other. Your individual application of your source and lens will indicate a different use of that source. 
  • Slide Content: Title slide with each member's name; Multiple slides per lens with clear labels; Final takeaways and claim of fact; Works cited slides of research used for each lens--the team member responsible for the lens must include their own works cited slide; In-text citation included on all slides with borrowed content that references the lens' works cited slide
  • Performance Content: Recorded Video--Share the slideshow; Explain the topic and lenses selected; Explain your guiding question(s);  Explain the main claim of fact your group reached based on all your evidence; 
  • Posting: post your slideshow and the link to your recorded presentation to this assignment link (either Zoom, Screencast-o-matic, or YouTube) and to the Discussion Section for a Q&A from another group.
