assignments.name: Stasis Theory: Claim of Fact

rubric.long_description: Assesses the quality of the claim of fact, the unity of the presentation, the challenge/originality of the scope, and the relevance of the supporting evidence--research-based.

ratings.long_description: Each presenter provides a clear and focused portion to video that includes convincing, fact-based, hard evidence. Each piece of evidence contributes to the controlling claim of fact's idea/thesis. The lens the presenter uses applies in significant ways to the team's topic, and the evidence contributes to the main idea clearly and significantly. For further comments to indicate distinctions between exemplary and strong, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

The presenter provides a generally focused portion to the video that includes mostly fact-based, hard evidence. Occasionally, the presenter may slip in a minor value-based piece of evidence. Most pieces of the team member's evidence contribute to the controlling claim of fact's idea/thesis but may stray in some minor places. The lens the presenter uses applies in general ways to the team's topic, and the evidence contributes to the main idea but could use more focus or explanation. For further comments, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

The presenter provides a somewhat unfocused or irrelevant portion to the video that may include the following: mostly value-based evidence or assertions, evidence's relevance strays from the controlling idea, team member's lens doesn't yet contribute to the main topic enough; the presenter's section tends to stray or meander rather than contribute to the controlling idea. For further comments, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the quality, depth, and insight of the team's reasoning of the topic. Also, this criterion assesses the team member's ability to connect fact-based evidence and reasoning to build a fact-based claim. Extra weight will be issued to presentations that ethically engage with complexity.

ratings.long_description: Team member thoroughly and clearly connects their lens' ample, fact-based evidence to the claim of fact. The team member's reasoning is clear, insightful, sophisticated, and ethical. The team member's lens' reasoning contributes meaningfully and significantly to the video's main claim. The team member uses reliable and convincing evidence in their reasoning and represents the evidence ethically. The presenter provides a generally focused portion to the video that includes mostly fact-based, hard evidence. Occasionally, the presenter may slip in a minor value-based piece of evidence. Most pieces of the team member's evidence contribute to the controlling claim of fact's idea/thesis but may stray in some minor places. The lens the presenter uses applies in general ways to the team's topic, and the evidence contributes to the main idea but could use more focus or explanation. For further comments regarding distinction between exemplary and strong assessment, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

Team member generally connects their lens' fact-based evidence to the claim of fact. The team member's reasoning is clear in most places yet general  and would benefit from more specificity. The team member's lens' reasoning contributes to the video's main claim but could benefit from more depth or specificity. The team member uses reliable yet general evidence in their reasoning and represents the evidence ethically but may make some minor slips in the presentation. The presenter provides a generally focused portion to the video that includes mostly fact-based, hard evidence. Occasionally, the presenter may slip in a minor value-based piece of evidence. Most pieces of the team member's evidence contribute to the controlling claim of fact's idea/thesis but may stray in some places. The lens the presenter uses applies in general ways to the team's topic, and the evidence contributes to the main idea but could use more focus or explanation. For further comments, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

Team member may somewhat or neglects to connect their lens' fact-based evidence to the claim of fact. See any of the following that may apply: the team member's reasoning meanders and needs more specificity; the team member's lens has loose or flawed connections to the main idea; the team member may fall into the trap of making value-based claims rather than fact-based claims; the team member may use some unreliable or suspect evidence that impacts their ability to reason ethically; the team member may accidentally misinterpret/misrepresent the evidence, which then affects the reasoning; the team member may consistently mistake value-based evidence for fact-based evidence; the team member may display significant trouble explaining the significance of the evidence. For further comments, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the presentation's structure, logical progression, and unity using a variety of coherence techniques including, but not limited to slide transitions, unified slides, transitions to other team member's lenses, etc. Also, assesses the team's use of time, ensuring that each team member's lens gets equivalent representation and balances time effectively.

ratings.long_description: Each team member has sufficient time to present their lens and uses the time effectively. As each team member's lens moves to the next, they clearly and cogently set up the next lens. The slides and lenses progress from idea to idea logically. The team smoothly provides a final portion of consensus for the main idea based on all the lenses. For further comments regarding distinction between exemplary and strong assessment, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

Each team member has time to present their lens and uses the time somewhat effectively. As each team member's lens moves to the next, they might abruptly or generally set up the next lens. The slides and lenses progress from idea to idea in a list-like fashion rather than a concept-driven fashion. The team provides a final portion of consensus for the main idea based on all the lenses but may be rushed. For further comments, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

Some team members may not receive sufficient time to present their lens or uses the time in somewhat ineffective ways. As each team member's lens moves to the next, they might not set up the next lens. The slides and lenses progress from idea to idea in confusing ways. The team may not provide a final portion of consensus for the main idea. For further comments, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the quality of the presentation's product: effective use of time; clear speaking voices, precise language and appropriate tone; few to no errors in slides, "clean" slides; team members' contents expand on information in slides rather than read off of of slides, etc.

ratings.long_description: Team keeps video within time restraints yet makes excellent use of the time they have. Team member provides a clear presentation with "clean" slides, excellent expansion on slides, precise language, and minimal minor errors. For further comments regarding distinction between exemplary and strong assessment, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

Team keeps video within time restraints but could make better use of the time they have. Team member provides a clear presentation with somewhat "clean" slides, general expansion on slides, general language, or a couple of distracting errors. For further comments regarding assessment, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

Team's video exceeds time restraints. Team member provides an unclear clear presentation with distracting slides, reads off of slides, imprecise language, or consistent distracting errors. For further comments regarding assessment, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the team's integration of source material based on the following: source requirements--each lens has 6 different sources in its works cited page and represented in the len's slides, sources provide fact-based evidence; citation accuracy, reliable source material, use of parenthetical citation, and ethical comprehension and subsequent integration of source material. Any unintentional plagiarism errors will be flagged and require the student to contact the instructor.

ratings.long_description: The team member uses reliable and convincing research, interprets and represents the original source material ethically, includes a minimum of six sources represented in the works cited slide and relevant slide, accurate MLA formatting. For further comments regarding distinctions between exemplary and strong assessment, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

The team member uses mostly reliable yet general research, interprets and represents the original source material mostly ethically, includes a minimum of six sources represented in the works cited slide and relevant slide, mostly accurate MLA formatting with some minor inaccuracies. For further comments regarding assessment, see annotated comments and feedback comments.

The team member has some questionable incorporation of source material that needs to address one or more of the following: works cited slide is missing significant identifying information; uses questionable sources or misrepresents sources; neglects to include minimum source requirements; cites most borrowed material inaccurately; major ethical issues in integrating material; consistently redundant source integration; neglects to integrate all borrowed content; unintentional plagiarism mistakes--see flagged content in the annotated comments. Suggestions: Consult with your instructor about any confusion you may have regarding ethical use of sources. Review the evaluative steps you need to adopt to use a source with confidence about its accuracy. Consult Purdue OWL for accurate citation, both in-text and works cited. Review our course materials on Avoiding Plagiarism and MLA Citation. Student will see a 10% deduction per accidental plagiarism issue but may decide to correct this/these issue(s) if this is the first time within a week of grading. If there is a significant pattern of accidental plagiarism, student's work will be reported to OSRR. Intentional plagiarism will result in a zero for the assignment and a report to OSRR.

rubric.long_description: Quality of questions and answers to teams

ratings.long_description: Student posts a thoughtful question and provides a thorough answer to their partnered team. Student posts the question and answer on time.
Student posts a general question and a general answer to their assigned team on time.
Student posts an unrelated or redundant question and/or posts no answer or inaccurate answer. Student might not post on time.

rubric_settings.title: Stasis Theory: Claim of Fact Presentation

assignment.description:
Stasis Theory: Claim of Fact

Deliverables:

Format: Collaborative Presentation and Slideshow

Points: 150

Due Date: Wednesday Jan. 26 by 11:59 pm

Each member of the team needs to:

  • Post slideshow to assignment in pdf or shareable file to google slideshow (make sure to share it so that I can access it later)
  • Post link to video presentation (Zoom recording, YouTube, Screencast-o-matic)
  • Participate in Question and Answer session through a Canvas Discussion

Overview Description:

No time seems more pertinent than now to discern fact from fiction or opinion. As many of us most likely have witnessed, opinions posing as facts have been bandied about on a daily basis in our media, our government, and even our science. For this project, you and your team will find hard evidence to construct a claim of fact about your selected topic. This topic must be science-based, as you're taking a course called Writing Arguments about STEM. Your team's job is to postpone judgment or evaluation until you have the evidence necessary to construct your claim. That means that you each must identify and interrogate any preconceived assumptions to verify accuracy. At these early stages of inquiry, pretend that you know nothing about this topic as you gather your research.

You will be working with this topic all quarter long, so make sure that your team reaches an enthusiastic consensus about your topic. Everyone needs to be invested in the topic.

Objectives:

By the successful completion of this project, students should be able to:

  • Use research techniques and resources to find relevant evidence
  • Evaluate the reliability of source material
  • Apply hard evidence to construct an argumentative claim based on fact
  • Cite all borrowed research in MLA 8 format using both in-text and works cited requirements
  • Develop a cohesive, collaborative presentation featuring a claim of fact for a STEM-based topic to peers and instructor

Definitions:

  • Artistic Proofs: "arguments the writer/speaker creates" (Lunsford and Ruskiewicz 56)
  • Inartistic Proofs: "arguments the writer/speaker is given" (Lunsford and Ruskiewicz 56)
  • Hard Evidence: "facts that are definitely true and can be proved" ("hard evidence"); Examples: facts, statistics, testimonies, documents, contracts, witnesses (Lunsford and Ruskiewicz 56)
  • Constructed Arguments: "appeals to reason; common sense" (Lunsford and Ruskiewicz 56)

Step One: Sign up for a Team

STEM fields rely on collaboration, so this sequence of assignments throughout the quarter will require you to collaborate. Select a team comprising between 2 to 4 members who can reach consensus about a quarter-long topic. Every team member must agree on the selected topic in order to make this quarter's requirements work effectively for everyone. Once you've selected your topic, each team member must approach that topic through a different lens or focal point. Your Claim of Fact and Claim of Advocacy projects will require you to work with the team you selected.

How to Sign up for a Team: 

  • How do I join a Group as a Student?

Step Two: Choose a Topic

Select a STEM-based topic that your team is genuinely interested in exploring and that has enough complexity to extend into a claim of value and eventual claim of advocacy. Every team member must agree on the selected topic in order to make this quarter's requirements work effectively for everyone. Once you've selected your topic, each team member must approach that topic through a different lens or focal point. 

Broad Topics to Narrow Scope Examples:

Finding a Suitable Scope for Topic
Broad Topic Narrowed Scope and Potential Lens within Scope
Digital Currency
  • Bitcoin mining
    • environmental impacts
Space Exploration
  • Telescopes
    • James Webb
  • Solar Sails
    • design
Climate Change
  • Coral Reef Bleaching
    • Great Barrier Reef
  • Deforestation in Amazon
    • Techniques
  • Fracking
    • Pennsylvania Marcellus Shale
Technology
  • Algorithms used in Search Engines
  • CRISPR
    • Gene Modification
  • 3D Printing Capabilities
    • Human Organs
  • Drone Usage in the Military

Example:

Let's say, for example, my team is interested in sustainability issues (really broad) and after some discussion we have decided to narrow the focus to plastics in the United States (sufficiently narrow and complex enough to examine over the quarter). My team can look at plastic through multiple lenses:

  • production—how it’s produced, who produces it, materials used to make it, system of its distribution
  • disposal—how it’s disposed of, where it goes, how much is recyclable, who’s responsible for redemption values, systems (or lack thereof) in place to dispose, etc.
  • consumption—who uses, its application, longevity of use, what it’s used for, etc.

Each team member is responsible for researching plastics through one of these lenses in detail. So, if I chose "disposal" as my lens, I would find hard evidence from reliable sources that focuses on how the United States disposes of plastics. I would need to find research that answers fact-finding questions: 

  • Do the majority of United States municipalities dispose of plastic? If so, to what extent? In what ways?
  • Is the United States recycling its plastic? If so, to what extent? In what ways? If not, where is that plastic being sent to?
  • Are redemption centers available to collect consumer recyclable plastic? If so, to what extent do consumers use them? If so, where are these redemption centers located? If so, what are the available times these redemption centers accept recyclable plastic?
  • Are systems available in cities and states to dispose of plastic? If so, in what ways are they disposing of plastic? To what extent are they disposing of harmful chemicals/pollutants? Are these disposal methods affecting surrounding communities' water supplies, air quality, etc.?
  • Do the companies that produce the plastic also recycle the plastic? If so, to what extent? 

As you can see, the possibilities within the lens allow multiple directions based on the type of evidence you encounter as you cast that wide net. Ask many questions! You may find through your research that your team may need to narrow the focus even more. That's fine.

See OWL at Purdue's Stasis Theory reading for some sample questions to get you started. We will work on developing more customized questions as your team selects a topic.

Look for reliable sources to establish the hard evidence surrounding the topic. Use the information you've gathered from the Library Module in Canvas and the Library Introduction to Databases to help you find great hard evidence. 

Step Two: Hard Evidence and Artistic Proofs

Hard evidence is demonstrable and verifiable. It is considered true and irrefutable. However, in the sciences, we tend to stay critical and skeptical of how we interpret our evidence as we gather data. We have to look at the methodologies of acquiring that evidence and confirm that the collection is based on sound practices. That means that the research you acquire in your inquiry practice also needs to look at the ways in which that data was gathered. Relying on reliable sources with a reputation for using sound methodologies is important as you accumulate your evidence. However, facts can change according to new information and definitions we construct from that information. For example, when I was a kid, Pluto was a planet. Now, as we've acquired more data regarding planets' characteristics and Pluto, we've reclassified Pluto as a dwarf planet. That is now a fact. As we gather more data and refine our understanding of Pluto, we might even change that label--if the scientific community reaches consensus.

It's also important that you compile a sufficient amount of evidence to construct a strong claim. In artistic proofs, you interpret the hard evidence you've amassed over multiple sources and construct a claim of fact that is a statement of fact. The key here is that the statement of fact must focus on the principle of accuracy without overstatement or speculation. If your findings are inconclusive, that is still a claim of fact. If your findings indicate a probability, then your claim of fact needs to include language that indicates the extent to which that probability exists. Using qualifiers, acknowledging limitations, etc. all contribute to making a strong claim of fact. As you work with your team, make sure to devote some time and attention to the methodologies, sample sizes, representation distribution, etc. of the studies and information you use. Consider the strengths and limitations of the studies as your team analyzes the information and constructs your claim. What is your team's consensus on all the research you've acquired?

Step Three: Presentation

Once you have each amassed sufficient information, your team will combine your findings and present them as a claim of fact to the rest of the class in a recorded video presentation. When you construct a claim of fact, you gather the evidence, interpret the significance of that evidence, and arrive at a conclusion based solely on that evidence. Having great guiding questions starting with "Is," "Does," "In what ways," or "To what extent" will allow you to answer that question as a group. The answer may be more complicated than "yes" or "no," so keep yourselves open to an accurate consensus rather than an oversimplified one. Avoid answering value-based questions: e.g., is X better than Y? These types of questions will stray from objective and observable facts.

In a slideshow, present your team’s findings to the rest of the class. Include the following elements:

  • The topic selected and its broader issue
  • Each team member’s name on the title slide
  • The lenses your team selected and why; make sure to identify who is responsible for each lens on the slide
  • A works cited slide for each lens and the team member responsible for that lens
  • The findings—should be a combination of both written and visual text; include citations both within the relevant slide and the works cited lens slide at the end
  • A summation and conclusion of the facts your team can now assert about the topic or issue from your research and a description of the key takeaways
  • An invitation for questions from the class and subsequent answers from team members
  • The presentations should range from 10-12 minutes

Presentation Guidelines:

  • Time: Your presentations should take up no more than 10 minutes, with each member contributing to explain their lens, topic, and slides.
  • Research Requirements: Each member should include a minimum of 6 sources providing fact-based hard evidence. Hard evidence includes raw data, charts, graphs, examples, events, forensics, etc. However, it is acceptable (if relevant) for members to use some of the same sources, so I encourage you to share your research and findings with each other. Your individual application of your source and lens will indicate a different use of that source. 
  • Slide Content: Title slide with each member's name; Multiple slides per lens with clear labels; Final takeaways and claim of fact; Works cited slides of research used for each lens--the team member responsible for the lens must include their own works cited slide; In-text citation included on all slides with borrowed content that references the lens' works cited slide
  • Performance Content: Recorded Video--Share the slideshow; Explain the topic and lenses selected; Explain your guiding question(s);  Explain the main claim of fact your group reached based on all your evidence; 
  • Posting: post your slideshow and the link to your recorded presentation to this assignment link (either Zoom, Screencast-o-matic, or YouTube) and to the Discussion Section for a Q&A from another group.

See Assignment Rubric below for Assessment. I will grade this presentation based on both individual contribution and team cohesion. Individual members may earn different grades than the overall team if I see significant discrepancies in quality.

The team member has some questionable incorporation of source material that needs to address one or more of the following: works cited slide is missing significant identifying information; uses questionable sources or misrepresents sources; neglects to include minimum source requirements; cites most borrowed material inaccurately; major ethical issues in integrating material; consistently redundant source integration; neglects to integrate all borrowed content; unintentional plagiarism mistakes--see flagged content in the annotated comments. Suggestions: Consult with your instructor about any confusion you may have regarding ethical use of sources. Review the evaluative steps you need to adopt to use a source with confidence about its accuracy. Consult Purdue OWL for accurate citation, both in-text and works cited. Review our course materials on Avoiding Plagiarism and MLA Citation. Student will see a 10% deduction per accidental plagiarism issue but may decide to correct this/these issue(s) if this is the first time within a week of grading. If there is a significant pattern of accidental plagiarism, student's work will be reported to OSRR. Intentional plagiarism will result in a zero for the assignment and a report to OSRR.

Student posts a general question and a general answer to their assigned team on time.
Student posts an unrelated or redundant question and/or posts no answer or inaccurate answer. Student might not post on time.

assignments.description:
Claim of Value

Deliverables:

Format: Essay of ~1200 words using MLA 8 Style formatting (Individual Project)

Points: 250

Due Date: Feb. 20 by 11:59 pm

Overview:

The Conversation

"Imagine that you enter a parlor. You come late. When you arrive, others have long preceded you, and they are engaged in a heated discussion, a discussion too heated for them to pause and tell you exactly what it is about. In fact, the discussion had already begun long before any of them got there, so that no one present is qualified to retrace for you all the steps that had gone before. You listen for a while, until you decide that you have caught the tenor of the argument; then you put in your oar. Someone answers; you answer him; another comes to your defense; another aligns himself against you, to either the embarrassment or gratification of your opponent, depending upon the quality of your ally's assistance. However, the discussion is interminable. The hour grows late, and you must depart. And you do depart, with the discussion still vigorously in progress."

--The Philosophy of Literary From--Kenneth Burke 1941

Working from your previous research in your claim of fact presentation, team’s research, and topic choice, you (individually) will now establish the value and ethical considerations of the topic and lens you selected by defining a conversation. The focus on this portion of the project examines the concerns and values of your topic and lens and how they affect a variety of stakeholders. Consider the conversation taking place within this field and among its stakeholders and your place within it.

Objectives:

By the successful completion of this project, students should be able to:

  • Identify internal and external stakeholders relevant to their topic
  • Find appropriate and reliable research that demonstrates both internal and external stakeholders' perspectives
  • Summarize stakeholders' perspectives objectively
  • Identify claims, ground, and warrants in various stakeholders' arguments
  • Evaluate the significance of various stakeholders' perspectives and arguments
  • Establish criteria to justify the evaluation
  • Apply ethical use of research using MLA 8 format documentation
  • Construct a values-based argument that evaluates the significance of topic's stakeholders' perspectives
  • Create a cogent and logically-based argument by avoiding logical fallacies
  • Use a combination of deductive and inductive reasoning in their essay

Definitions:

  • Stakeholders: "one who is involved in or affected by a course of action" ("stakeholder"). Examples include:  Employees, Customers, Government, Communities, Suppliers, Investors, Ecosystems, etc.
  • External Stakeholders: "groups outside a business [or project] or people who don't work inside the business [or project] but are affected in some way by the decisions and actions of the business [or project]" ("Business Stakeholders"). Examples include: Suppliers, Customers, Government, Communities, Shareholders, etc. ("Business Stakeholders").
  • Internal Stakeholders: "groups or people who work directly within the business [or project], such as managers, employees, and owners" ("Business Stakeholders"). Examples include: Managers, Employees, Owners, etc. ("Business Stakeholders")

Step One: Identify Stakeholders

Your first steps should be to identify the stakeholders, both internal and external, who have an interest or are affected by your topic and your lens. Establish the context by researching the background and current situation from their perspectives. At this stage, you should have a list of potential stakeholders (a blend of internal and external) to choose to research further. Note: you will not need to comment on or examine all of them. You will whittle this list down to three significant stakeholders with at least one present in each category of internal and external. For example, you can have two external stakeholders and one internal or vice versa.

Example:

  • If we want to continue with the plastic example, we could identify some internal stakeholders in these ways: production company making the plastic, company using the plastic for their products, chemists designing biodegradable plastics, etc. External stakeholders could be the following: residential communities located next to the plastic production affected by the pollution produced in the making of the product, fishing industry affected by the plastic presence in the oceans, homeless communities who gather plastic bottles for cash-in redemption values, consumer using the plastic and then disposing of it, etc.

Once you’ve identified your stakeholders, try to answer the following questions:

  • Who or what might have an investment in this topic?
  • What are their interests?
  • What are their concerns?
  • What is their background with this topic?
  • What do they consider the most important value for them?
  • How does the issue/topic affect them, their fields, their safety, well-being, or their careers? And why might that be important?

Additional research beyond your Claim of Fact evidence will help you identify these groups and their concerns. Once you’ve identified potential stakeholders and their concerns, apply the value and ethical considerations of the topic/issue. Choose a minimum of three stakeholders’ perspectives using a combination of internal and external stakeholders in articles or journal publications to frame your examination and explicitly summarize their positions, grounds, and warrants.

You will also need to interview or find a published interview with an expert, enthusiast, or specialist in the field and incorporate this information into your essay. If you choose a personal interview, feel free to interview friends, family members, graduate students, work colleagues, etc. for this portion of the requirement. This interview, whether published or personal, should provide you an extra point of insight into this topic that other published research cannot. In an effort to minimize requests for faculty interviews, please use your professors as a last resort for an interview and choose to attend their office hours.

Note on Personal Interview Informed Consent:

According to the CCCC Guidelines for the Ethical Conduct of Research, informed consent is “an ongoing and negotiated process” between the writer and their interview subject(s). If you plan to incorporate a personal interview, you will need to review the considerations and vulnerabilities that might be exposed by incorporating that person's interview--you will need to obtain written permission and if anyone else is mentioned or implicated in the discussion, you would also need their permission to print their name or implicitly reveal their identity. Read here for specifics: CCCC Guidelines for the Ethical Conduct of Research

Make sure that your stakeholders have points of tension or dissent as well as some commonalities between each other. Good places to look for these viewpoints include the following:

  • conduct a Google search using "op-ed" + your topic
  • use the library databases like Opposing Viewpoints or CQ Researcher
  • watch TED Talks
  • listen to Podcasts

Your stakeholders' perspective texts must be published somewhere reliable in order to qualify for this assignment. Avoid procon.org, as this site rarely has substantive or developed arguments.

Step Two: Develop a Guiding Question Set

Now that you've gathered all these perspectives, weighed them against each other, and identified the tensions, so what? Guiding questions can help you keep focused and encourage you to deepen your inquiry. Create a guiding question set that helps you examine and evaluate the value of the topic to these stakeholders. Once you’ve gathered enough evidence to inform yourself about the topic and its stakeholders, use the guiding question set to help you establish your focus and thesis.

Your goal of this essay is to give a fair voice to three perspectives representing a combination of internal and external stakeholders. Once you've examined these perspectives, you then need to evaluate who (or what) has the most significant interest or involvement that needs consideration, attention, addressing? Why? Finally, you need to show your position within this conversation.

Extended Example:

  • If we're going to work with our plastics example, I can create an assertion from my research and develop guiding questions to help me answer those next steps.
    • X = Companies that push the onus of plastic disposal onto the individual consumer
    • Verb = Overwhelm
    • Y = the capacity of recycling plants in US cities

Assertion: Companies that push the onus of plastic disposal onto the individual consumer overwhelm the capacity of recycling plants in US cities, thereby shifting the burden onto impoverished nations like Bangladesh to take the overflow.

Question One: To what extent do companies push the onus of plastic disposal onto the individual consumer?

Question Two: Why does it matter that companies push the onus of plastic disposal onto the individual consumers to that extent?

Question Three: To what extent does this disposal method overwhelm the capacity of recycling plants in US cities?

Question Four: Why does it matter that these disposal methods overwhelm the capacity of recycling plants in US cities to that extent?

Question Five: To what extent do the overwhelmed US recycling plants then dispose of their excess plastic?

Question Six: Why does it matter that the overwhelmed US recycling plants dispose of their excess plastic to that extent?

These questions all build upon each other to prompt a values-based thesis that relies on hard evidence, summaries of stakeholders' perspectives, and identification of your own warrants to form an evaluation. For example with the question set above: I now have to explain why I think it matters that I've established and identified a causal relationship between companies' plastic practices and the mountains of discarded (for recycling) plastic in impoverished nations like Bangladesh. I will have to identify my value system as I evaluate the situation and determine which stakeholders' concerns hold more weight with that value system. Do I think it's a shrewd and viable practice that US companies apply to their plastics disposal? Do I think it's mostly the consumers' fault for continuing to purchase these single use plastics? Do I think that these US municipalities unfairly take advantage of lax regulations in impoverished nations to hide the single use plastics problem? My answers to these questions will help me determine my final assessment, which most likely will be more complicated than it's just one stakeholder's fault.

Step Three: Write the Essay

Write an essay of approximately 1200 words that examines and evaluates the value and ethical considerations of this topic to three of its stakeholders using the lens you applied in your claim of fact presentation. You must include at least three potential stakeholders (combination of internal and external) in your evaluation, explicitly stating their position, concerns, and warrants. You should also incorporate relevant research from your first project, interview, and subsequent research for this assignment. Use your guiding questions to keep you focused. What do you consider to be important? In what ways can you weigh competing value systems against each other? Why does it matter that you weigh these value systems against each other? This assignment's purpose in your Stasis Theory process is to help you determine who or what your team will advocate for in your next project.

Essay Requirements:

  • Length: ~1200 quality words
  • Genre: Claim of Value essay
  • Content: 
    • include summaries of three perspectives from a combination of internal and external stakeholders (based on your specific research--not from a generalized or anonymous perspective); weave them throughout the essay where rhetorically necessary
    • apply topic and lens from your claim of fact presentation;
    • identify claims, grounds, warrants of stakeholders' perspectives  as well as your own; weave throughout the essay where rhetorically necessary
    • establish a evaluation-based thesis that weighs out these perspectives and determines most significant, pressing, important, etc. based on your evidence and reasoning; avoid committing logical fallacies and identify any you see in your research
    • research and source material using MLA 8 format: in-text and works cited documentation--(see below for specific research requirements)
  • Research: you should have a strong and varied blend of research from reliable sources. This blend should include a minimum of 8 sources, 2 of which must be from peer-reviewed journal articles and 1 that includes an interview (either person or published). You can pull from your claim of fact research but must also build from there to round out your understanding of the topic.
  • Coherence: you should clearly progress from idea to idea using coherence techniques like transitional cues and structured sections both in your essay--your summaries of stakeholders' perspectives should take up no more than 30% of your essay while your analysis and evaluation should comprise the bulk of your page space
  • Clarity: you should use precise and concise language to convey your reasoning and thesis; use clear syntax; apply voice and rhetorical choices designed to connect with your audience

See Assignment Rubric below for assessment criteria.

Project Timeline

Timeline Due Dates
Activities Canvas Location Due Date
Choose Your Skills option: Defining the Conversation Choose Your Skills: Defining the Conversation Feb. 9 by 11:59 pm
"Entry Ticket" Guiding Questions Set "Entry Ticket": Guiding Question Procedure Feb. 11 by 11:59 pm
Claim of Value Workshop 7.1: Preparation: Workshop--Claim of Value Essay
  • Part One: February 16 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two: February 18 by 11:59 pm class discussion
Claim of Value Essay Due Post to this assignment link February 20 by 11:59 pm

Resources

MLA Header 2021.pdf 

Core Values List.pdf 

Incorporating Quotes Templates Handout.pdf

Templates for Opposition and Analysis.pdf 

Guiding Question Textual Conversations.pptx

5.3: Mapping the Claim of Value Essay

Sample Student Essay: Textual Conversations (completed for a different assignment but same principles): Sample Student Essay Textual Conversations Deforestation.pdf 

Example of a Published Interview: "Comparing Police Responses to Pro-Trump Mob, Racial Justice Protests"

Accommodations for DRC or Document Accessibility

It is university policy to provide, on a flexible and individualized basis, reasonable accommodations to students who have disabilities that may affect their ability to participate in course activities or meet course requirements. Students with disabilities are encouraged to contact their instructor to discuss their individual needs for accommodations. If you need to convert a file to a more accessible medium, please use Sensus AccessLinks to an external site.

Works Cited:

"Business Stakeholders." Introduction to Business. Ch. 1, OER, https://courses.lumenlearning.com/suny-wmopen-introbusiness/chapter/business-stakeholders-2/, Accessed 11 Dec. 2020. 

Jo Zimny Photos. "Scales of Justice." Flickr, 29 Oct. 2020, https://www.flickr.com/photos/78814955@N00/50544105502, Accessed 11 Dec. 2020.

"stakeholder." Merriam-Webster Dictionary, https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/stakeholder, Accessed 11 Dec. 2020

assignments.name: Stasis Theory: Claim of Value

rubric.long_description: Assesses the writer's stance, development of position, and presence.

ratings.long_description: The writer presents and fully develops a sophisticated and engaging stance. The writer selects precise and convincing evidence that is sometimes surprising and often compelling--pulled from required sources. The writer gives a detailed, yet succinct presentation of viewpoints and rebuttals based on reliable research. The writer also engages in multiple levels of development to form a well-crafted argument.

Writer presents a promising stance that would benefit from one or more of the following: a more narrow and challenging scope, deeper layers of development, a shift from generalities to specific and relevant insight, some editing for redundancies, some editing to break formulaic and limiting patterns, and/or a more challenging thesis to explore. The evidence used is relevant, yet general, and could be used in more convincing ways.

Writer's essay would benefit from one or more of the following: a thesis that presents an arguable stance that explores rather than repeats already established arguments; a more narrow stance/focus; specificity in the quality of research; establishing relevant and convincing research pulled from required source materials; a shift from superficial or imprecise content to specific and relevant insight; some focused editing for redundancies; a more unified approach to incorporating evidence as support for the thesis; a focused and unified thesis that avoids the writer contradicting themselves; more accurate representation of the topic's context

rubric.long_description: Assesses the quality, depth, and insight of the writer's examination of the stakeholders' perspectives, with an emphasis on evaluation. Also, this criterion assesses the writer's ability to connect the evidence to the controlling stance in meaningful and significant ways. Extra weight will be issued to essays that engage complexity and grapple with tensions ethically.

ratings.long_description: Writer identifies the value systems inherent for each stakeholder's perspective and fully examines the tensions and alignments in significant ways. The writer evaluates the competing value systems and provides a fully developed stance. The writer provides criteria from which to draw logical conclusions in their evaluation.

Writer generally identifies the value systems inherent for each stakeholder's perspective and examines the tensions and alignments in general or broad ways. The writer evaluates the competing value systems and provides a generally developed stance. The writer provides some criteria from which to draw generally logical conclusions in their evaluation.

Writer's essay may include one of the following: the writer misidentifies or doesn't identify the value systems inherent for each stakeholder's perspective; the writer  under-examines the tensions and alignments; the writer may not evaluate the competing value systems; the writer may provide an underdeveloped stance; the writer provides scant to no criteria from which to draw logical conclusions in their evaluation.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the essay's structure, logical progression, and unity using a variety of coherence techniques including, but not limited to, sentence and paragraph-level transitions, unified paragraphs, given-new chaining, etc.

ratings.long_description: The writer presents a "constellation" of coherence strategies that makes the writing unified and organic. The writer provides logical and varied transitions to establish a clear and cogent line of reasoning. The progression both at the paragraph and sentence level read seamlessly. The writer selects a strong organizational and rhetorical approach. The writer presents a balanced and sophisticated textual conversation essay.

The essay has some minor coherence issues or tends to be formulaic in overall structure. While the paragraphs are unified, many of the transitions are either somewhat redundant or present some imprecise logical connections. The essay seems to meander in places but does bring everything back to the stance eventually. The writer could choose a more rhetorically relevant organizational structure. The writer may favor some content over other, resulting in a generally balanced essay.

Writer's essay could benefit from one or more of the following suggestions: The essay can be difficult to follow in many places and has either abrupt or imprecise transitions--identify some places where you can make the logical connections more explicit. The essay meanders and doesn't yet connect to the controlling idea--reconsider or question some of the included content. In places, the essay can be choppy--try some of the coherence strategies we've discussed in class to improve continuity and unity in the essay. The organizational structure seems to misfire in regards to connecting to audience--try reworking the structure to better resonate with your audience selection. The essay is imbalanced.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the writer's syntax, consistency of voice, and precision of language. Extra weight will be issued to essays that use concise and precise language.

ratings.long_description: The writer's voice is appropriate, creative, and employs stylistic techniques. The syntax is varied and clear, using concise and precise language. The writer has few minor grammatical errors that don't affect comprehension. The writer's stance is present and assertive in the essay.

Writer presents a good effort but could improve upon one or more of the following: using more precise language and avoiding filler language; avoid redundancies and edit for conciseness; address some distracting grammatical errors that constitute a pattern of clarity issues; engage in more assertive voice.

The writing could use some significant editing with a focus on one or more of the following: addressing consistent clarity issues by using more precise and concise language; varying syntax to eliminate choppiness and redundancy; reviewing syntax rules for clear sentence structure; review grammatical rules that affect reader comprehension; establish an assertive voice in the essay; improve clarity.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the writer's integration of source material based on the following: source requirements (2 peer-reviewed/1 interview/8 sources total minimum), citation accuracy, reliable source material, use of signal phrases or parenthetical citation, and ethical comprehension and subsequent integration of source material. Any unintentional plagiarism errors will be flagged and require the student to contact the instructor.

ratings.long_description: The writer uses reliable and valuable research to establish context and evidence. The essay meticulously cites all borrowed content accurately both in-text and on works cited page. The writer also seamlessly integrates source material through the use of well-selected choices including: signal phrases, truncating and integrating borrowed language into original sentences using quotation marks for all borrowed language, applying summary or paraphrase when better suited to the content, etc. The writer demonstrates a clear understanding of ethical citation techniques. The essay contains an accurately formatted works cited including a minimum of 8 total sources, of which at least 2 are peer reviewed and 1 is an interview, and incorporates them ethically in the essay itself.

The writer demonstrates an ethical use of sources, using the minimum requirements in the assignment description, but would benefit by employing one or more of the following: using stronger, more reliable sources; improving the citations to clearly indicate where content came from; accurately format works cited and in-text citations; making better use of peer-reviewed and/or interview materials

The writer has some questionable incorporation of source material that needs to address one or more of the following: works cited page is missing significant identifying information; uses questionable sources or misrepresents sources; neglects to include minimum source requirements; cites most borrowed material inaccurately; major ethical issues in integrating material; consistently redundant source integration; neglects to integrate all borrowed content; unintentional plagiarism mistakes--see flagged content in the annotated comments. Suggestions: Consult with your instructor about any confusion you may have regarding ethical use of sources. Review the evaluative steps you need to adopt to use a source with confidence about its accuracy. Consult Purdue OWL for accurate citation, both in-text and works cited. Review our course materials on Avoiding plagiarism and MLA Citation. If these issues appear, student will see a 10% deduction per accidental plagiarism issue, but if this is the first time, student may fix all accidental plagiarism issues to earn back these deductions. If there is a significant pattern of accidental plagiarism, student's work will be reported to OSRR. Intentional plagiarism will result in a zero for the assignment and a report to OSRR.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the writer's ability to select, summarize, and present 3 stakeholders' perspectives from a collection of internal and external positions.

ratings.long_description: Writer presents three stakeholders' perspectives fully, ethically, and objectively. The selected stakeholders the writer presents provide excellent alignments and tensions between value systems to explore and analyze. The writer selects a strong combination of internal and external stakeholders.

Writer presents three stakeholders' perspectives from internal and external positions. The selected stakeholders the writer presents provide general alignments and tensions between value systems to explore and analyze. The writer selects a  general combination of internal and external stakeholders.

Writer's representation of stakeholders' perspectives may have one or more of the following: writer presents less than three stakeholders' perspectives; writer presents three stakeholders' perspectives but they may all be internal or external; the selected stakeholders the writer presents provide scant to no alignments and tensions between value systems to explore and analyze; the writer misrepresents one or more of the stakeholders' perspectives; the writer doesn't rely on source material to inform them about the stakeholders.

My answers to these questions will help me determine my final assessment, which most likely will be more complicated than it's just one stakeholder's fault.

Step Three: Write the Essay

Write an essay of approximately 1200 words that examines and evaluates the value and ethical considerations of this topic to three of its stakeholders using the lens you applied in your claim of fact presentation. You must include at least three potential stakeholders (combination of internal and external) in your evaluation, explicitly stating their position, concerns, and warrants. You should also incorporate relevant research from your first project, interview, and subsequent research for this assignment. Use your guiding questions to keep you focused. What do you consider to be important? In what ways can you weigh competing value systems against each other? Why does it matter that you weigh these value systems against each other? This assignment's purpose in your Stasis Theory process is to help you determine who or what your team will advocate for in your next project.

Essay Requirements:

  • Length: ~1200 quality words
  • Genre: Claim of Value essay
  • Content: 
    • include summaries of three perspectives from a combination of internal and external stakeholders (based on your specific research--not from a generalized or anonymous perspective); weave them throughout the essay where rhetorically necessary
    • apply topic and lens from your claim of fact presentation;
    • identify claims, grounds, warrants of stakeholders' perspectives  as well as your own; weave throughout the essay where rhetorically necessary
    • establish a evaluation-based thesis that weighs out these perspectives and determines most significant, pressing, important, etc. based on your evidence and reasoning; avoid committing logical fallacies and identify any you see in your research
    • research and source material using MLA 8 format: in-text and works cited documentation--(see below for specific research requirements)
  • Research: you should have a strong and varied blend of research from reliable sources. This blend should include a minimum of 8 sources, 2 of which must be from peer-reviewed journal articles and 1 that includes an interview (either person or published). You can pull from your claim of fact research but must also build from there to round out your understanding of the topic.
  • Coherence: you should clearly progress from idea to idea using coherence techniques like transitional cues and structured sections both in your essay--your summaries of stakeholders' perspectives should take up no more than 30% of your essay while your analysis and evaluation should comprise the bulk of your page space
  • Clarity: you should use precise and concise language to convey your reasoning and thesis; use clear syntax; apply voice and rhetorical choices designed to connect with your audience

See Assignment Rubric below for assessment criteria.

assignment.name: Stasis Theory: Claim of Value

rubric.long_description: Assesses the writer's stance, development of position, and presence.

ratings.long_description: The writer presents and fully develops a sophisticated and engaging stance. The writer selects precise and convincing evidence that is sometimes surprising and often compelling--pulled from required sources. The writer gives a detailed, yet succinct presentation of viewpoints and rebuttals based on reliable research. The writer also engages in multiple levels of development to form a well-crafted argument.

Writer presents a promising stance that would benefit from one or more of the following: a more narrow and challenging scope, deeper layers of development, a shift from generalities to specific and relevant insight, some editing for redundancies, some editing to break formulaic and limiting patterns, and/or a more challenging thesis to explore. The evidence used is relevant, yet general, and could be used in more convincing ways.

Writer's essay would benefit from one or more of the following: a thesis that presents an arguable stance that explores rather than repeats already established arguments; a more narrow stance/focus; specificity in the quality of research; establishing relevant and convincing research pulled from required source materials; a shift from superficial or imprecise content to specific and relevant insight; some focused editing for redundancies; a more unified approach to incorporating evidence as support for the thesis; a focused and unified thesis that avoids the writer contradicting themselves; more accurate representation of the topic's context

rubric.long_description: Assesses the quality, depth, and insight of the writer's examination of the stakeholders' perspectives, with an emphasis on evaluation. Also, this criterion assesses the writer's ability to connect the evidence to the controlling stance in meaningful and significant ways. Extra weight will be issued to essays that engage complexity and grapple with tensions ethically.

ratings.long_description: Writer identifies the value systems inherent for each stakeholder's perspective and fully examines the tensions and alignments in significant ways. The writer evaluates the competing value systems and provides a fully developed stance. The writer provides criteria from which to draw logical conclusions in their evaluation.

Writer generally identifies the value systems inherent for each stakeholder's perspective and examines the tensions and alignments in general or broad ways. The writer evaluates the competing value systems and provides a generally developed stance. The writer provides some criteria from which to draw generally logical conclusions in their evaluation.

Writer's essay may include one of the following: the writer misidentifies or doesn't identify the value systems inherent for each stakeholder's perspective; the writer  under-examines the tensions and alignments; the writer may not evaluate the competing value systems; the writer may provide an underdeveloped stance; the writer provides scant to no criteria from which to draw logical conclusions in their evaluation.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the essay's structure, logical progression, and unity using a variety of coherence techniques including, but not limited to, sentence and paragraph-level transitions, unified paragraphs, given-new chaining, etc.

ratings.long_description: The writer presents a "constellation" of coherence strategies that makes the writing unified and organic. The writer provides logical and varied transitions to establish a clear and cogent line of reasoning. The progression both at the paragraph and sentence level read seamlessly. The writer selects a strong organizational and rhetorical approach. The writer presents a balanced and sophisticated textual conversation essay.

The essay has some minor coherence issues or tends to be formulaic in overall structure. While the paragraphs are unified, many of the transitions are either somewhat redundant or present some imprecise logical connections. The essay seems to meander in places but does bring everything back to the stance eventually. The writer could choose a more rhetorically relevant organizational structure. The writer may favor some content over other, resulting in a generally balanced essay.

Writer's essay could benefit from one or more of the following suggestions: The essay can be difficult to follow in many places and has either abrupt or imprecise transitions--identify some places where you can make the logical connections more explicit. The essay meanders and doesn't yet connect to the controlling idea--reconsider or question some of the included content. In places, the essay can be choppy--try some of the coherence strategies we've discussed in class to improve continuity and unity in the essay. The organizational structure seems to misfire in regards to connecting to audience--try reworking the structure to better resonate with your audience selection. The essay is imbalanced.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the writer's syntax, consistency of voice, and precision of language. Extra weight will be issued to essays that use concise and precise language.

ratings.long_description: The writer's voice is appropriate, creative, and employs stylistic techniques. The syntax is varied and clear, using concise and precise language. The writer has few minor grammatical errors that don't affect comprehension. The writer's stance is present and assertive in the essay.

Writer presents a good effort but could improve upon one or more of the following: using more precise language and avoiding filler language; avoid redundancies and edit for conciseness; address some distracting grammatical errors that constitute a pattern of clarity issues; engage in more assertive voice.

The writing could use some significant editing with a focus on one or more of the following: addressing consistent clarity issues by using more precise and concise language; varying syntax to eliminate choppiness and redundancy; reviewing syntax rules for clear sentence structure; review grammatical rules that affect reader comprehension; establish an assertive voice in the essay; improve clarity.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the writer's integration of source material based on the following: source requirements (2 peer-reviewed/1 interview/8 sources total minimum), citation accuracy, reliable source material, use of signal phrases or parenthetical citation, and ethical comprehension and subsequent integration of source material. Any unintentional plagiarism errors will be flagged and require the student to contact the instructor.

ratings.long_description: The writer uses reliable and valuable research to establish context and evidence. The essay meticulously cites all borrowed content accurately both in-text and on works cited page. The writer also seamlessly integrates source material through the use of well-selected choices including: signal phrases, truncating and integrating borrowed language into original sentences using quotation marks for all borrowed language, applying summary or paraphrase when better suited to the content, etc. The writer demonstrates a clear understanding of ethical citation techniques. The essay contains an accurately formatted works cited including a minimum of 8 total sources, of which at least 2 are peer reviewed and 1 is an interview, and incorporates them ethically in the essay itself.

The writer demonstrates an ethical use of sources, using the minimum requirements in the assignment description, but would benefit by employing one or more of the following: using stronger, more reliable sources; improving the citations to clearly indicate where content came from; accurately format works cited and in-text citations; making better use of peer-reviewed and/or interview materials

The writer has some questionable incorporation of source material that needs to address one or more of the following: works cited page is missing significant identifying information; uses questionable sources or misrepresents sources; neglects to include minimum source requirements; cites most borrowed material inaccurately; major ethical issues in integrating material; consistently redundant source integration; neglects to integrate all borrowed content; unintentional plagiarism mistakes--see flagged content in the annotated comments. Suggestions: Consult with your instructor about any confusion you may have regarding ethical use of sources. Review the evaluative steps you need to adopt to use a source with confidence about its accuracy. Consult Purdue OWL for accurate citation, both in-text and works cited. Review our course materials on Avoiding plagiarism and MLA Citation. If these issues appear, student will see a 10% deduction per accidental plagiarism issue, but if this is the first time, student may fix all accidental plagiarism issues to earn back these deductions. If there is a significant pattern of accidental plagiarism, student's work will be reported to OSRR. Intentional plagiarism will result in a zero for the assignment and a report to OSRR.

rubric.long_description: Assesses the writer's ability to select, summarize, and present 3 stakeholders' perspectives from a collection of internal and external positions.

ratings.long_description: Writer presents three stakeholders' perspectives fully, ethically, and objectively. The selected stakeholders the writer presents provide excellent alignments and tensions between value systems to explore and analyze. The writer selects a strong combination of internal and external stakeholders.

Writer presents three stakeholders' perspectives from internal and external positions. The selected stakeholders the writer presents provide general alignments and tensions between value systems to explore and analyze. The writer selects a  general combination of internal and external stakeholders.

Writer's representation of stakeholders' perspectives may have one or more of the following: writer presents less than three stakeholders' perspectives; writer presents three stakeholders' perspectives but they may all be internal or external; the selected stakeholders the writer presents provide scant to no alignments and tensions between value systems to explore and analyze; the writer misrepresents one or more of the stakeholders' perspectives; the writer doesn't rely on source material to inform them about the stakeholders.

assignments.description:
Data Visualizations

20 points | "Entry Ticket" | 3 Parts

Anticipated completion time: 90 minutes for all 3 parts

After completing this activity, students should be able to:

  • analyze data to determine the "story" to tell in their data visualization
  • choose an appropriate data visualization for the data they've acquired
  • design a data visualization using ethical considerations in its design
  • cite the sourcing they use in the data visualization

Assignment Description

Sometimes graphs and charts convey information more succinctly and effectively than written text can. This choice of communication especially applies in digital writing. Using our course materials on data visualizations and the information you learned from the Data Visualization Workshop, you will create a data visualization for your Claim of Advocacy project. This data visualization should apply your lens to the topic and add substantial meaning to the reasoning and support in your upcoming Claim of Advocacy website. Consider this project a process phase of developing your final data visualization that you'll provide in the final website. Thus, your data visualization doesn't need to be the "end product" at this stage. It should be one that you anticipate adjusting and revising until it's ready for the website. Review the following resources for this project:

  • 9.1: Data Visualization
  • 9.2: Ethics of Data Visualization
  • Engl 149 Data Visualization Ethics PPT.pptx
  • 5 Ways Writers Use Misleading Graphs to Manipulate You

Part One Due: Sunday March 6 by 11:59 pm

Collect some raw data, information on process, or tables for your Claim of Advocacy project that you think will be best represented visually. Determine the significant point the data indicate by analyzing, examining, and interpreting the data. Then, select the best way to represent the "story" you see that the data indicate. This process works much like your claim of fact project works. Compile the hard data; draw inferences and meaning from it;  convey that to your audience. In this case, you'll be using visual methods to demonstrate those inferences. To help me determine the "best fit" for my "story" for the data, I use the Data Visualisation Catalogue "Search by Function" website. Once you've selected the type of chart or graphic you'd like to use, find the best free apps to help you develop an information-rich and meaningful visualization that will contribute in some way to your Claim of Advocacy project.

For the discussion posting here, include the following:

  • a list or table of your raw data or information
  • a works cited of the sources providing you the data
  • a description of the inferences you drew from the data 
  • attach an image or screenshot of your original data visualization
  • a title and description of the data visualization
  • an explanation of why you selected that type of graphic, designed it the way that you did, and what you hoped to convey in it that connects to your Claim of Advocacy project

Part Two Due: Monday March 7 in Class

Apply the Data Visualization Checklist to your partner's data visualization. Offer constructive feedback for improvement. 

Part Three Due: Tuesday March 8 by 11:59 pm

Post a revised version of your data visualization based on the feedback you received during our class session. Explain the changes you made and what effect you hoped to attain through those changes.

Assessment:

To earn credit for this assignment, you must complete the following:

  • Post Part One, participated in Part Two, and Post Part Three on time
  • Include an original data visualization for your Claim of Advocacy project
  • Include data, citations, and explanations of the data
  • Provide a revised version of the data visualization
assignments.name: "Entry Ticket" Data Visualizations

discussion_entries.message:
Katzmeier, F., et al.. Comparison of Low-cost Fluorescence Detectors.. 1, PLOS ONE, 18 Dec. 2019, doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0220091.t001. 

I tried to emphasize through the colors in the image that lower is better for sensitivity, and I think once you can understand that, you can see how CRISPR is clearly the best option. Not only is it the cheapest by an insane margin, it is also not that much more imprecise than kits costing $200 making it a solid choice for testing of viruses like COVID that are so widespread as well as ebola and zika that spread in poorer areas that cannot afford more expensive testing.

assignments.description:
"Entry Ticket" Problem Statement: Claim of Advocacy

30 points | "Entry Ticket" | 3 Parts

  • Part One Due: February 26 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two Due: In class on February 28
  • Part Three Due: February 28 by 11:59 pm

See Rubric for Assessment

By the end of this assignment, students should be able to:

  • compose a problem statement to set the foundation for the claim of advocacy project
  • describe the problem for their claim of advocacy
  • tailor a problem statement to their selected audience for the claim of advocacy
  • provide constructive criticism to their colleagues
  • incorporate evidence to support their description of the problem
  • cite all borrowed content in MLA8 format

This assignment requires your team to compose the problem statement you plan to incorporate into your website. As you've read, a good problem statement includes a sense of urgency, demonstration of seriousness/urgency, and rhetorical awareness of audience and situation. For review, revisit 8.2: Crafting a Problem Statement.

Part One: Compose a Problem Statement (15 points)

In less than 500 words, your team should compose a problem statement tailored to your audience for your claim of advocacy project. When writing for a digital audience, you want to choose each word wisely and precisely. Your problem statement should include the following:

  • Identification of the problem with a distinct focus on "the gap"
  • Relevant context to orient your reader
  • Demonstration of evidence to convince the reader that the problem exists including causal reasons for the problem
  • In-text documentation and a corresponding works cited using MLA8 formatting
  • Rhetorical choices in language, structure, and reasoning to resonate with the reader and the situation
  • Consideration and relevant inclusion of the advice mentioned in your course materials

Your problem statement, while team written, should read as unified and coherent. In your posting, include the audience/reader your team has selected for this project. In order to be assigned teams for Part Three, you must post this assignment on time. One team member per team should post the problem statement.

Part Two: Discussion with Peers in Class 

During our class meeting, you will review your problem statement with another team and gather feedback. We'll have a form ready for the meeting to review then.

Part Three: Post Feedback to Team in a Different Class (15 points)

Each team member should post constructive feedback to a team's posting in a different class. I will assign you a partner team from another class section on Feb. 27 by 6 am. Comment on the following as if you were the selected audience and use complete sentences (use the rubric):

  • Did you see a clearly stated problem? Explain.
  • Are you convinced that the problem is pressing and needs addressing? Explain
  • Does the team use effective rhetorical appeals for the audience they've identified? Explain.
  • Does the problem statement read coherently and clearly? Explain.
  • Does everything in the problem statement contribute in meaningful and convincing ways to define the problem? Explain.
  • How effectively does the team explain the scientific terms and processes in the problem statement? Explain
  • What do you consider to be the strongest, most effective part of this problem statement? Be specific.
  • What do you think needs adjusting to become more effective in this problem statement? Be specific.

Assessment

To earn points for this assignment,

  • your team must post a problem statement with in-text and works cited MLA documentation by the due date. Please post it in the text box and not as an attachment.
  • your team will consult with another team about both postings during our class session for Part Two
  • each individual team member needs to provide written, constructive feedback to their assigned team for Part Three by the due date
  • do use the rubric

rubric.long_description: Does the team provide enough evidence and information to demonstrate the problem? What more or less would you like to see?

ratings.long_description: Team posts Part One on time, individuals participate in Part Two and Three, answering all prompts completely

Team posts Part One on time or late by a couple of hours. Individuals may post feedback slightly late in Part Three or not participate in Part Two because of extenuating circumstances. Individuals may answer some of the prompts but may miss one or two minor answers.
Team doesn't post Problem Statement or posts it too late for review. Individuals don't post Part Three feedback to their assigned teams. Individuals don't answer to most of the prompts in Part Three.
