Team posts a partially developed Problem Statement. Individuals provide general feedback that would benefit from more specificity.
Team doesn't post a Part One Problem Statement. Individuals provide scant to no feedback to their assigned team.

rubric.long_description: How well does the team present the problem? Are you convinced about the problem they describe? Do you see a sense of urgency and seriousness about this problem? Explain.
Does the problem statement include clear, precise language; clear syntax; citations to show what's informing the statement; tone directed toward an audience that's designed to build trust? Explain.

rubric_settings.title: Problem Statement: Claim of Advocacy feedback

discussion_entries.message:
Team Llamas: Gavin Plume, Brandon Howell, Sunday Tinsley, and Ben Kunkle

Biomedical engineering institutions should regulate clinical trials of CRISPR-based germline editing until a full body of research concludes that germline editing can be safely, ethically, and equitably implemented. Germline editing alters the non-somatic cells of an organism; changes to the germline are permanent and pass on to the subject’s offspring (Wade). Unregulated genome editing can hurt society and create permanent adverse changes in human populations and the global environment (Clapper). This issue impacts everyone in society because germline editing, coupled with a gene drive to push a gene through a population, quickly affects everyone either directly genetically or through the environment (Swetlitz). Unregulated germline editing in humans is risky to the subjects and the population at large because CRISPR can malfunction or germline editing could be malevolently employed (Clapper). Germline editing in non-human organisms can cripple native ecosystems or cause harm to human populations via disease (Ly). These issues demand immediate action by internal stakeholders with the power to regulate CRISPR implementation to protect human and natural populations. Currently, germline editing is banned by legislation in most countries including those where it is banned only by guideline such as in China. Notably, the US is the only country where it is banned by moratorium, and it has ambiguous legal status in only a few countries such as Russia (Araki and Ishii). We advocate for internationally enforced regulations on germline editing with a structured discussion of the ethical and scientific ramifications of germline editing. A timeframe for research and conferences should be created to give a defined endpoint for the moratorium, at which point germline editing will be allowed under regulations or banned. The lack of a governing regulatory body stems from the absence of a collected body of knowledge about CRISPR and the challenges of establishing international bodies with actual power. We will advocate to governments and ally with like-minded scientists to create a regulatory body. First, we must advocate for regulations on germline editing to adult residents in the United States so that the United States Federal Government takes action to establish an international regulatory body. 

 

Works Cited:

Araki, Motoko, and Tetsuya Ishii. “International Regulatory Landscape and Integration of Corrective Genome Editing into in Vitro Fertilization.” Reproductive Biology and Endocrinology, vol. 12, no. 1, 2014, p. 108., doi:10.1186/1477-7827-12-108. 

Baltimore, David, et al. “A Prudent Path Forward for Genomic Engineering and Germline Gene Modification.” Science, vol. 348, no. 6230, 19 Mar. 2015, pp. 36–38., doi:10.1126/science.aab1028. 

Ly, Chen. “Algal Blooms in Freshwater Lakes Are Becoming More Common Worldwide.” New Scientist, New Scientist, 9 Feb. 2022, www.newscientist.com/article/2307185-algal-blooms-in-freshwater-lakes-are-becoming-more-common-worldwide/. 

Senate Armed Services Committee, Clapper, James R. Worldwide Threat Assessment of the U.S. Intelligence Community for the Senate Committee on Armed Services, Senate Armed Services Committee, 2016, pp. 9–9. 

Swetlitz, Ike. “Biologists: Let's Sic 'Gene Drive' on Zika-Carrying Mosquitoes.” Statnews.com, STAT, 8 June 2016, www.statnews.com/2016/02/03/zika-gene-drive-gene-editing/. 

Wade, Nicholas. “ Scientists Seek Ban on Method Of Editing the Human Genome.” New York Times, 20 Mar. 2015, pp. A1–A1. ProQuest, www.proquest.com/globalnews/docview/2074277665/fulltextPDF/AB0EDA0293D4045PQ/1?accountid=10362.

• Did you see a clearly stated problem? Explain.
    • yes, fishermen, those on coastlines, and those who buy the products of marine economies will all be harmed by rising sea levels
  • Are you convinced that the problem is pressing and needs addressing? Explain
    • yes, this is specifically addressed in the sentence "Due to temperature rise alone, by 2030 “a productivity loss equivalent to 80 million full-time jobs” could occur"
  • Does the team use effective rhetorical appeals for the audience they've identified? Explain.
    • I'm not sure who the target audience is. I'm assuming that it is governments since the last couple sentences call for legislation. If that's the case, then I believe the rhetorical appeals are effective. As they appeal to the governments want to preserve the economy by stating the drastic economic impacts climate change could have if left unchecked (or even if we do something about it)
  • Does the problem statement read coherently and clearly? Explain.
    • yes. It flows well from an overview of who will be affected, how they will be affected etc. Before moving on to the stuff politicians may care about more such as the impacts to the economy, ending with a clear claim
  • Does everything in the problem statement contribute in meaningful and convincing ways to define the problem? Explain.
    • sort of, the claim mainly focuses on why legislation should be passed to protect those who will be harmed by climate change but does not integrate the economic aspects
  • How effectively does the team explain the scientific terms and processes in the problem statement? Explain
    • very well, I was not confused by any language 
  • What do you consider to be the strongest, most effective part of this problem statement? Be specific.
    • If it is aimed at government legislation, I think the best argument is the economic one. The loss of jobs, loss of businesses etc. If it is aimed at the general populous however then I think the appeals to sympathy for those who will be affected are stronger.  
  • What do you think needs adjusting to become more effective in this problem statement? Be specific.
    • I think the authors could add more on the economic impacts because although they might not be the most important part of the issue, I think they are what the legislators who have the ability to pass the legislation they want passed care the most about

assignment.description:
"Entry Ticket" Problem Statement: Claim of Advocacy

30 points | "Entry Ticket" | 3 Parts

  • Part One Due: February 26 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two Due: In class on February 28
  • Part Three Due: February 28 by 11:59 pm

See Rubric for Assessment

By the end of this assignment, students should be able to:

  • compose a problem statement to set the foundation for the claim of advocacy project
  • describe the problem for their claim of advocacy
  • tailor a problem statement to their selected audience for the claim of advocacy
  • provide constructive criticism to their colleagues
  • incorporate evidence to support their description of the problem
  • cite all borrowed content in MLA8 format

This assignment requires your team to compose the problem statement you plan to incorporate into your website. As you've read, a good problem statement includes a sense of urgency, demonstration of seriousness/urgency, and rhetorical awareness of audience and situation. For review, revisit 8.2: Crafting a Problem Statement.

Part One: Compose a Problem Statement (15 points)

In less than 500 words, your team should compose a problem statement tailored to your audience for your claim of advocacy project. When writing for a digital audience, you want to choose each word wisely and precisely. Your problem statement should include the following:

  • Identification of the problem with a distinct focus on "the gap"
  • Relevant context to orient your reader
  • Demonstration of evidence to convince the reader that the problem exists including causal reasons for the problem
  • In-text documentation and a corresponding works cited using MLA8 formatting
  • Rhetorical choices in language, structure, and reasoning to resonate with the reader and the situation
  • Consideration and relevant inclusion of the advice mentioned in your course materials

Your problem statement, while team written, should read as unified and coherent. In your posting, include the audience/reader your team has selected for this project. In order to be assigned teams for Part Three, you must post this assignment on time. One team member per team should post the problem statement.

Part Two: Discussion with Peers in Class 

During our class meeting, you will review your problem statement with another team and gather feedback. We'll have a form ready for the meeting to review then.

Part Three: Post Feedback to Team in a Different Class (15 points)

Each team member should post constructive feedback to a team's posting in a different class. I will assign you a partner team from another class section on Feb. 27 by 6 am. Comment on the following as if you were the selected audience and use complete sentences (use the rubric):

  • Did you see a clearly stated problem? Explain.
  • Are you convinced that the problem is pressing and needs addressing? Explain
  • Does the team use effective rhetorical appeals for the audience they've identified? Explain.
  • Does the problem statement read coherently and clearly? Explain.
  • Does everything in the problem statement contribute in meaningful and convincing ways to define the problem? Explain.
  • How effectively does the team explain the scientific terms and processes in the problem statement? Explain
  • What do you consider to be the strongest, most effective part of this problem statement? Be specific.
  • What do you think needs adjusting to become more effective in this problem statement? Be specific.

Assessment

To earn points for this assignment,

  • your team must post a problem statement with in-text and works cited MLA documentation by the due date. Please post it in the text box and not as an attachment.
  • your team will consult with another team about both postings during our class session for Part Two
  • each individual team member needs to provide written, constructive feedback to their assigned team for Part Three by the due date
  • do use the rubric
assignment.name: "Entry Ticket" Problem Statement: Claim of Advocacy

rubric.long_description: Does the team provide enough evidence and information to demonstrate the problem? What more or less would you like to see?

ratings.long_description: Team posts Part One on time, individuals participate in Part Two and Three, answering all prompts completely

Team posts Part One on time or late by a couple of hours. Individuals may post feedback slightly late in Part Three or not participate in Part Two because of extenuating circumstances. Individuals may answer some of the prompts but may miss one or two minor answers.
Team doesn't post Problem Statement or posts it too late for review. Individuals don't post Part Three feedback to their assigned teams. Individuals don't answer to most of the prompts in Part Three.

rubric.long_description: Does the team write their problem statement with an audience in mind? What (if anything) indicates audience to you? What could be improved? What's "working" right now?

ratings.long_description: Team posts a developed problem statement while individuals provide thorough and constructive feedback.
Team posts a partially developed Problem Statement. Individuals provide general feedback that would benefit from more specificity.
Team doesn't post a Part One Problem Statement. Individuals provide scant to no feedback to their assigned team.

rubric.long_description: How well does the team present the problem? Are you convinced about the problem they describe? Do you see a sense of urgency and seriousness about this problem? Explain.
Does the problem statement include clear, precise language; clear syntax; citations to show what's informing the statement; tone directed toward an audience that's designed to build trust? Explain.

assignments.description:
Guiding Question Set Procedure

20 points | Entry Ticket Score | Two Parts

Estimated Duration: 60 minutes

Resources:

  • 6.1: 5 Analytical Moves: Analytical Heuristics
  • 6.2: Developing Strong Research and Guiding Questions
  • Guiding Question Textual Conversations.pptx

Here's the Video Explaining the Guiding Question Set Procedure:

Due Dates: 

  • Part One--Saturday Feb. 12 by 11:59 pm 
  • Part Two--Tuesday Feb. 15 by 11:59 pm

In order to be assigned two peers for Part Two, you must post Part One on time.

Please review the Discussion Guidelines prior to participating in any discussions. 

Part One: 10 points

Review your research notes. As you reflect on your observations and reactions to your research, select three pieces of evidence in your entries. Each piece should represent a specific quality.

  1. One piece of evidence that you think is significant in shaping your understanding of a stakeholder's perspective. Include the direct passage and the author. Then explain how this evidence has shaped your understanding of the topic.
  2. One piece of evidence that you think exposes the tension between two or three stakeholders. Include the direct passage and the author. Describe this tension from each stakeholder’s perspective. Explain how you’re reacting to or thinking about this evidence.
  3. One piece of evidence that surprises you. Include the direct passage and the author. Describe your previous assumption. Explain how this piece of evidence challenges that assumption.

After your descriptions of your evidence, compose a Guiding Question Set (see 6.2: Developing Strong Research and Guiding Questions and Stasis Theory: Claim of Value for specifics) that applies this formula:

  1. Statement of assertion based on your evidence—identify x, y, and verb (can be up to two sentences total)
  2. In what ways (or to what extent) does x verb y?
  3. Why does it matter that x verb y in those ways (or to that extent)?

Posting to Discussion

Post your guiding question set and research findings to this discussion. Please format it the following way using the bolded headers:

Shaping Evidence: example and explanation

Tension Evidence: example and explanation

Surprising Evidence: example and explanation

Guiding Question Set:

X =                                                      

Verb =                                                

Y =                                                      

Assertion: statement containing x, verb, and y

Question: To what extent does x verb y? or In what ways does x verb y?

Question: Why does it matter that x verb y to that extent?  or Why does it matter that x verb y in those ways?

Part Two: 10 points

You will be assigned two peers to provide feedback. In order to be assigned two peers, you must post Part One on time. In your responses, comment on the following:

  • What do you think is interesting about the significant evidence they provide?
  • What do you find intriguing about the tension evidence? What do you think might be missing?
  • Did you also find the surprising evidence surprising? Why or why not?
  • Review the Guiding Question Set for structure and potential. Comment on the following: 
    1. Does the Guiding Question Set clearly identify x, verb, and y? And if so, does the Guiding Question Set follow the structure described in the Guiding Question Set link? If no, to any of these questions, what can the author do to improve the clarity and/or structure to the Guiding Question Set?
    2. In what ways does the Guiding Question Set the author provides intrigue you? Explain.
    3. In what ways do you think the author could improve upon the Guiding Question Set’s focus or scope? Explain.

Post both Parts One and Two in the text boxes, not as attached documents. Be prepared to speak with your assigned partners in class

Assessment

To earn points for this assignment, students must complete the following:

  • Post Part One on time and to assignment description
  • Post Part Two on time and to two assigned peers
  • Compose contents based on their topics for Claim of Value projects
  • Use the format for the Guiding Question set
assignments.name: "Entry Ticket": Guiding Question Procedure

rubric.long_description: Student posts all three types of evidence and explanation, a guiding question set, and replies to two assigned peers on time

ratings.long_description: Students posts a complete submission and comments on two assigned peers' postings on time.
Student posts a slightly incomplete posting, may only post feedback to one assigned partner, or may post a day or two late.
Student is missing major parts of the assignment, posts past three days' late, or doesn't reply to both assigned peers.

rubric.long_description: Student posts evidence that comprises shaping, tension, and surprising and provides a clear explanation of that evidence. Student posts an accurate rendition of guiding question set: assertion, "in what ways..." question, and "why does it matter that..." question. Student provides constructive feedback to their assigned peers.

ratings.long_description: Student posts strong evidence that comprises shaping, tension, and surprising and provides a clear, insightful explanation of that evidence. Student posts an accurate rendition of guiding question set: assertion, "in what ways..." question, and "why does it matter that..." question. Student provides constructive feedback to their assigned peers.

Student posts evidence that comprises shaping, tension, and surprising and provides a general explanation of that evidence. Student posts a somewhat accurate rendition of guiding question set: assertion, "in what ways..." question, and "why does it matter that..." question but may confuse one of the questions or provide statements where there should be questions. Student provides general feedback to their assigned peers.

Student posts somewhat confusing evidence that loosely ties to shaping, tension, and surprising and provides an unclear explanation of that evidence. Student may have not posted major parts of the assignment. Student posts an inaccurate rendition of guiding question set: assertion, "in what ways..." question, and "why does it matter that..." question. Or student posts no guiding question set. Student provides little to no feedback to their assigned peers.

discussion_entries.message:
Topic: Medical applications of CRISPR

Shaping Evidence:

"Some of the inventors of the patent-holders of CRISPR technologies who are now the inventors of the various companies in biotechnology, they’ve also imposed their own moratoria on working in germ lines until more is understood. So there are parts of the scientific community that are very concerned and are trying to be very thoughtful about how to proceed and how to proceed safely."(Dr. Greg Licholai)

This gave me a good view on the companies developing CRISPR technologies. The biotech companies have an implicit motive to create the biotechnology so it's interesting that even they are being cautious.

Tension Evidence: 

"In the United States, there have been some regulations against moving forward in areas that aren’t safely understood. That doesn’t exist in other parts of the world, in particular in China. So there’s been several examples now of where China has leaped ahead of what’s going on in Europe or the United States but, the concern is, without the kind of regulatory and ethical safeguards that are in place in other countries." (Dr. Greg Licholai)

It seems the US and western regulatory bodies in general are trying to be more cautious. China on the otherhand has proven to be much more agressive in it's research of CRISPR with less concern for ethics.

Surprising Evidence:

"We think we know what we’re doing, we think we’re measuring exactly what changes we’re doing to the genes, but there’s always the possibility that either we miss something or our technology can’t pick up on other changes that have been made that haven’t been directed by us. And the fear then is that those changes lead to antibiotic resistance or other mutations that go out into the population and would be very difficult to control. Basically creating incurable diseases or other potential mutations that we wouldn’t really have control over. " (Dr. Greg Licholai) 

This really helped me understand why some people in the scientific community are cautious to use CRISPR. Previously I had thought CRISPR was perfect for medical applications as many different applications had been shown in tests to be safe. But this brings up the point that we might not know what we don't know. We don't know if we're missing something, and the consequences if we are missing something are potentially devastating.

Guiding Question Set:

X =   Wester caution towards developing CRISPR technologies due to ethical concerns   

Verb =   limits  

Y =    The wests development compared to Chinese development of CRISPR technologies (In general)   

Assertion: statement containing x, verb, and y

Western caution surrounding the development of CRISPR technologies due to ethical concerns limits its development compared to chinese development which is less restrained

Question: To what extent does x verb y? or In what ways does x verb y?

In the west there are some cases where development of medical technologies using CRISPR has been completely halted, sometimes by the inventors themselves, unitil it can be understood further or a consensus on the ethics can be reached. To my knowledge that has happened far less in China although they did increase restrictions following a rogue scientists modification of embryos in 2018.

Question: Why does it matter that x verb y to that extent?  or Why does it matter that x verb y in those ways?

If chinese scientists develop breakthrough medical technology we might get to a scenario where some in the west begin to make an "ends justify the means" argument. Trying to rush it's implementation outside of china because it could be helping people, even if a consensus on it's safety hasn't been reached

recent_replies.message:
Hi Benjamin,

What I found interesting about your significant evidence was the fact that the regulations that the biotech companies imposed regulations due to how new CRISPR technologies are, and maybe because they care for their employees safety. Something intriguing about the tension evidence was the fact that china is willing to increase the risk to increase the reward. I think what might be missing is perhaps knowledge and focus on the other countries as well. What I found surprising about the surprising evidence is the fact that scientists are willing to leave some things up to luck when considering diseases. It's understandable why they would rush to push out vaccines and medicines, but if it only works in the short run, then one the disease mutate, then the scientific community will pretty much be back to square one, and they'll be stuck in an endless cycle.

1. The guiding questions clearly identify x, verb, and y while following the structure in the guiding question set link.

2,. The guiding question set intrigues me because of its sole focus on china and the west. Although it is understandable to focus on the US's nuclear rival, it also limits the readers knowledge on the rest of the world.

3. I think to improve, the author just needs to include other countries to give us a better perspective of where China and the US stands in comparision to the rest of the world.

assignments.description:
"Entry Ticket": "Rate My Site" 

15 points | Entry Ticket Activity

Deliverable: Post document in pdf or docx

Assignment Due: Saturday, Jan. 15 by 11:59 pm

Approximate Time for Completion: 60 minutes

Prerequisite to complete activity--read and view: 

  • 2.2 Information Literacy Steps for Evaluating Sources
  • Starting Your Research: Ethics, Information Sources, and Evaluation

Assignment Description

Based on this week's readings and workshops, you will choose two websites below to read, evaluate, and rank using the "Reading Laterally" approach discussed in 2.2 Information Literacy Steps for Evaluating Sources and Evaluation Criteria. In a total of ~300 words, answer the following questions to determine the reputability of two of the provided sites:

Sites and Questions
Site Choices--Select Two Questions for Assessment--Answer all of them in your response

 

  • "Scientific Flaws And The 'Volcano' Of Io"
  • Red hot: NSW smashes February statewide heat records two days in a row
  • Tiny particles from city air invade peoples brains, interfere with cognition
  1. Who runs them?
  2. To what purpose?
  3. What is their history of accuracy? 
  4. How do they rate on process?
  5. How do they rate on aim?
  6. How do they rate on expertise?
  7. Would you trust information from each of these sites? Why or why not?

Assignment Objectives:

By successfully completing this assignment, students will be able to:

  • Evaluate the credibility of a website using the "reading laterally" approach
  • Determine whether or not to "trust" a website in their subsequent projects

Assessment

To earn points for this "Entry Ticket" assignment, you must complete the following:

  • Choose two websites from the provided list
  • Answer the seven listed questions in complete sentences 
  • Accurately apply the "Reading Laterally" approach to assessing these websites
  • Establish acceptable criteria for determining how these websites rank for process, aim, and expertise
  • Explain why the source is or isn't trustworthy using the concepts described in the course materials
  • Share your observations in class for our next meeting

assignments.description:
"Entry Ticket" Rhetoric, Argument, and the Scientific Process

20 points | "Entry Ticket" Assignment with Three Parts

Estimated time to complete assignment: Two hours including reading time

Part One Due: Jan. 8 by 11:59 pm

Part Two Due: Class Discussion Jan. 10

To complete this preparation activity, you need to have reviewed the following course materials:

  • 1.1: Introduction to Stasis Theory, Argument, and Rhetorical Appeals
  • 1.4 Toulmin Model of Argumentation
  • 1.5: Facts, Inferences, and Judgments
  • 1.6: Scientific Reasoning

Text for Analysis:

Read "Science Isn't Broken" by Christie Aschwanden for Part One and "Types of Scientific Evidence" for Parts One and Two

Assignment

Using this week's course materials, apply your understanding of these concepts to analyze "Science Isn't Broken" by Christie Aschwanden. 

Part One

Based on the Figure 5 Chart Diagram in the Toulmin Model reading, identify the following in "Science isn't Broken." identify the parts of the Toulmin Model you see at work in Aschwanden's argument. Use the following list formatting to write out your analysis:

  • Aschwanden's Main Claim
  • Two of Aschwanden's Data to support the main claim
  • One Warrant for each of Aschwanden's Data assertions (two total)
  • One Backing for each of Aschwanden's Warrants you identified (two total)
  • Two examples of qualifiers Aschwanden uses

Also, identify the following rhetorical principles Aschwanden applies:

  • Who is Aschwanden's audience--
    • what clues from the text indicate that for you?
  • Two examples of ethos you see in the text
  • Two examples of pathos you see in the text
  • Two examples of logos you see in the text

Answer the following :

  • What issues or problems is Aschwanden debating? In other words, which stasis questions is Aschwanden asking? 
  • Pick two sections or quotes that you think are significant, confusing, or striking from the reading--be prepared to share these with your colleagues in class--copy and paste them in your response so that I can see them

Part Two

Read "Types of Scientific Evidence" prior to class. We will discuss your answers and identifications for Part One in class and extend the discussion with this reading. 

Assessment

See rubric below

assignments.description:
"Entry Ticket": Stakeholders and Summary/Analysis

15 points | Entry Ticket Score | Two Parts

Estimated Duration: approximately 60 minutes to complete both parts, including video time

Due Dates: 

  • Part One: Saturday, Jan. 29 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two: Monday, Jan. 31 by 11:59 pm

Please locate the rubric by selecting the three dots at the upper right of this discussion, then select "Show Rubric."

Please review Discussion Guidelines prior to posting.

Prior to completing this activity, make sure you've reviewed the reading and viewing materials listed in

  • 4.1: Stakeholders
  • 4.2: Standard Summary Conventions

Objectives:

After the successful completion of this Activity, you will be able to:

  • Identify potential indirect and direct stakeholders
  • Evaluate potential stakeholder engagement in a topic
  • Summarize a video using standard summary conventions

Part One:

Watch one of the following TED Talks:

  • "How Your Brain Responds to Stories--and Why They're Crucial for Stories"
  • "How Bad Data Keeps Us from Good AI"
  • "Why Lakes and Rivers Should Have the Same Rights as Humans"

Transcripts are available for all of the above TED Talks if you prefer to read along.

For the TED Talk you've selected, do the following:

  • Write a 150-word summary using standard summary conventions discussed in your assigned reading materials--make sure to include the main claim and grounds the speaker makes in their argument in your summary.
  • Identify three potential stakeholders that the topic could affect
  • Label these potential stakeholders as either internal or external and why they fit those categories
  • Using the mapping matrix chart in the 4.1 Stakeholders reading, identify what you think are these stakeholders' investment and attitudes towards the speaker's position

Part Two:

Response: choose two peers to form a response: one peer who selected the same video as you and one who selected a different video than you did. If no one chose the same video as you, then answer to another who selected a different video

For the peer who selected the same video, answer the following:

  • What do you find interesting about the stakeholders your peer selected?
  • Why do you think that stakeholder might add another layer of interest or insight to the topic? Extend the conversation.

For the peer who selected a different video, answer the following:

  • Based on their summary and stakeholders choices, what do you think is significant about the stakeholders your peer identified?

You've successfully completed this assignment if you:

  • Post Parts One and Two by their respective due dates
  • Use standard summary conventions described in your course materials
  • Accurately interpret and render the video's argument in your summary
  • Post complete Parts One and Two according to the assignment description

Resource Links

    • How do I reply to a discussion as a student? (Links to an external site.)
    • How do I edit or delete a discussion as a student?

discussion_entries.message:
In her Ted Talk "How your brain responds to stories -- and why they're crucial for leaders" Karen Eber explains why story telling is so important for connecting with people especially as a leader. She starts off with two stories in which people realized the benefeit of making others feel seen and heard that she used to help her shape the culture at General Electric because they helped her connect with people. She then goes on to explain a few misconceptions about data. First of which is that it changes our opinions which she claims is actually done by emotions. Secondly, she asserts data never speaks for itself, while stories often do, they help guide us through the data telling us about the context, confilct, and outcome which helps us connect with the data and find meaning in it.

Three potential stakeholders are the leaders who use stories, the people they lead, and the people effected by the decisions the leaders and their followers make.

The stakeholders that are internal to the issue are the leaders and their followers. This is becuase they are the ones that directly interact, utilize, and benefieit from the use of stories to connect with people. The people effected by the actions of those two groups are then inherintly the external stakeholders. 

The internal stakeholders are very invested in the idea of using stories because they are the ones that really benefiet from it. They are the ones who work better together, accomplish more, and experience the impact on the culture of their organizations. The external stakeholders may think it's interesting and see how it could be useful for them personally but may care less about how it effects the organizations they aren't a part of.

recent_replies.message:
Hey Benjamin,

I also watched How your brain responds to stories - and why they're crucial for leaders". I also found similar stakeholders to you, and I found them interesting because it is clear that the speaker is directly mentioning that leaders can be more effective through connecting more personally to their audience with some story telling. I find it interesting that you selected the people who are effected by the decisions that leaders make, as I did not think of this. Those who are effected by leaders decisions are external due to the fact that they have no control over the issue. I would be interested to hear your thoughts on how this group of people can be more in control of the situation.

discussion_entries.message: Hi Jillian, I also watched this Ted Talk. I also said that two potential stakeholders  could be leaders and the people they lead, however I really like your reasons why they are stakeholders. I like that for the leaders you point out that they may have mixed feelings on using stories because of the extra work required to use them well. I think the third stakeholder being someone who collects data for the company and is against using stories because it makes their job less important is funny but also completely accurate.

Hi Kaija, I didn't watch this Ted talk but from your summary I think you chose three really important stakeholders. I think it's really interesting to think of the waterways as a stakeholder since the topic of the talk is giving the waterways rights. I also think you make a very good argument as too why the corporations would be an internal stakeholder and the general public would be an external stakeholder. As well as a great job explaining why the public may have split opinions on the issue.

assignments.description:
"Entry Ticket": Thinking Strategy

10 points | Entry Ticket Assignment | One Part

estimated completion time--as much as you need

Objectives:

By the end of this activity, you should be able to:

  • apply unconventional writing strategies and techniques to help you in your project process

Assignment Description

This assignment encourages you to use "down time" to help you on your progress for your quarter-long project. Choose from (or do your own) the following options:

  • have dinner with a parent, friend, roommate, stranger, etc.
  • take a hike and let your mind wander--let your subconscious do some of the heavy lifting
  • meditate with some soothing music to recenter your psyche
  • engage in your favorite physical activity--e.g., paintball, cross country running, etc.
  • try out something you've never done before--throw some pottery, go to The PAD for some rock climbing, try some kayaking...

Participating in activities that seem unconnected to writing will allow your subconscious the break it needs to reinvigorate you for this final stretch in your process. The "down" time is as important as the "active" time on these projects.

Completion for this Assignment

To earn credit for this assignment, please either tell me you did it or, if you feel like sharing, what you did. You'll earn the full 10 points.

  • try out something you've never done before--throw some pottery, go to The PAD for some rock climbing, try some kayaking...

Participating in activities that seem unconnected to writing will allow your subconscious the break it needs to reinvigorate you for this final stretch in your process. The "down" time is as important as the "active" time on these projects.

Completion for this Assignment

To earn credit for this assignment, please either tell me you did it or, if you feel like sharing, what you did. You'll earn the full 10 points.

Overview:

How do we know what we know? And how certain are we of that information when we make decisions or form conclusions? This discussion activity requires you to look deeper into reasoning glitches that most of us commit on a daily basis. You will identify the type of faulty reasoning, isolate the problem in the reasoning, create examples, and determine if the flawed reasoning is based on inductive, deductive, or abductive reasoning. Objectives:

  • Identify patterns of faulty reasoning

discussion_entries.message:
Article 1: The Halo Effect.

The article describes the bias formed when people are given uncertain premises make assumptions they atribute to the uncertain premises and that they are biased towards based on a smaller easier to process set of information without realizing.

These are abductive flaws. The most common example of this is making a judgement about someones abilities or personality that is influenced by how attractive the person is. This happens with pets as well, we will often assume that a dog is super nice based only on the fact it is cute.

Because we don't realize we are making these false assumptions in the moment it is hard to combat them as they happen. Instead we must retroactively check our steps either by thinking through how we came to a conclusion before using it or by asking someone else to check our logic.

 

Article 2: You're not going to believe what I'm about to tell you

This article describes the bias against information that goes against our core beliefs. 

This can be a flaw in any of the argument types because it depends on the recipient. If someone hears a deductive argument about police brutality that contradicts a core belief they may assert a premise was false leading to a never ending rabbit hole of proving premises. If an inductive argument is used explaining how examples of police brutality justify some action, the recepient may deny the examples are grounds for such an action. Finally if an abductive argument is used saying the rates of incarceration point to there probably being a race based component in the process the recipient can come up with alternate figures or statistics that support their core belief. 

Unfortunately it is highly unlikely we change our core beliefs. We can however control how we react to people with different core beliefs. Attampting to treat them with respect and understanding instead of lashing out.

recent_replies.message: Hi, Benjamin! I also did analysis on the article about the backfire effect. I agree that alternate figure and statistics can differ hugely and may skew, rather than converge, differing opinions. I also talked about how we can control our reactions to very personal, tense debates by respecting the other side or opinion. Lashing out is very common, especially on online platforms where there is a depersonalized atmosphere. However, I thought that rather than a never-ending rabbit hole of proving premises, the backfire effect comes from assumptions that people already have; So, they do not do any rationalizing or research, which is the main issue. To avoid this, I think that it is important for people to get used to having arguments and not to make it personal when someone disagrees with them. Also, it may be worthwhile for people to talk about controversial topics with people they know well, rather than strangers online.

Hey Benjamin, 

We both talked about the halo effect and the backfire effect. I agree with what you said about having to think back on our decision-making steps when we come to a conclusion in a moment. I also believe that the halo effect exhibits flaws in abductive reasoning. I wrote that the backfire effect exhibits flaws in just deductive reasoning, but now I see how it can show up in all three types of reasoning. I think we can change our beliefs, even if they are core beliefs, as long as we keep an open enough mind to allow ourselves to accept new reliable evidence. For sure treating people who are showing the backfire effect need to be respected and understood instead of being ridiculed. Shunning them just leads to them continuing with the backfire effect and confirmation bias.

Hi Benjamin,

I agree with you in thinking that the Halo Effect incorporates abductive reasoning. People quickly assume out of fear of being uncertain. I think that your example about the dog illustrates this effect very clearly. I like your reasons on combating this effect. I think another good idea is just to slow down and question yourself. A lot of the assumptions of the Halo Effect come from the speed at which the assumptions are made. Cognitive bias is difficult to keep in check. I agree that having peer review is a great way to combat bias. One's self can also simply try to think about assumptions from others viewpoints before acting.  

Thanks for sharing,

Sam

discussion_entries.message: Hi Jiya, I also read the comic “You’re not Going to Believe What I’m about to Tell You”. I really like your solutions to avoid the cognative biases, they are straightforward and easy to remember in the moment while also giving you the ability to spot where you're biases may be coming into play. While I agree that the backfire effect happens when peoples beliefs are challenged, I think it's important to include that it's specifically when someones core beliefs are challeged, rather than a previous belief they don't care about, that the backfire effect occurs. Even though this emotional gut reaction to our core beliefs being challenged is hard to identify in the moment, I think purposefully focusing on what the author is saying is a great way to deal with it.

Hi Joshua, I really like your description of the backfire effect, I appreciate that you focused on how it is not so much a flaw in logic, but an emotional response that impedes our ability to think rationally. I also agree with your description of the halo effect I think you described it well. I think everything else you said is true regarding how and why the halo effect occurs as well as what we should do about it when we notice it happening. However, I think it's important to touch on the "false certainty" aspect because it means we often don't realize when we're making the mistake. I'm thinking back to the example in the article where they asked college students how they felt about their groups dynamic after recieving a random grade because I feel like the grade actually impacted their recollection of how the group worked together. I do believe, however, that your solution to avoid defending a decision until you've double checked your logic is a good one to combat the false certainty.

assignments.description:
Translation, Metaphor, and Communication

Discussion Posting | 20 points | Two Parts

estimated completion time: 60 minutes

  • Part One Due: Saturday  Feb. 5 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two Due: Monday Feb. 7 by 11:59 pm

Please locate the rubric by selecting the three dots at the upper right of this discussion, then select "Show Rubric."

To complete this assignment, you will need to review the following from this week's materials:

  • 5.2: How Journalists Translate Science
  • 5.4: Diversity, Equity, Inclusion

You will also need to read the following articles:

  • "On the Problem and Promise of Metaphor Use in Science and Science Communication"
    • estimated reading time 15 minutes
  • "How Medical Jargon Can Make COVID Health Disparities Even Worse"
    • estimated reading time 10 minutes

Part One:

Based on your readings and course materials, consider how your academic discipline or stasis topic uses metaphors to communicate complex topics. Choose one "staple" metaphor (a common one that you see consistently either in your discipline or in your stasis topic). For example, the swiss cheese model of loss prevention can indicate how to provide multiple protective layers to minimize loss:

CC By SA-4.0 Ben Averling Design

This model was also applied to COVID prevention for my children's elementary school. 

CC By 4.0 Ian M. MacKay

For your discipline's or topic's metaphor use, explain the following in your posting:

  1. What is a common metaphor your discipline or topic uses to communicate a complicated concept?
  2. What is the metaphor intended to communicate? Be specific.
  3. How does the metaphor communicate this concept?
  4. In what ways is this metaphor effective in doing its job?  Explain, using points presented in "On the Problem and Promise of Metaphor Use in Science and Science Communication" and our course materials.
  5. In what ways might this metaphor be ineffective in doing its job? Explain, using points presented in "On the Problem and Promise of Metaphor Use in Science and Science Communication" and our course materials.
  6. Choose a different audience for the metaphor. In what ways might you need to adjust it to work for this audience? Explain two modifications you'd make and why you'd make them for this audience.

Part Two:

Select a posting from someone in the different discipline as you or something you found interesting in their metaphor selection. Answer the following:

  • What do you think is clear about that metaphor and the concept it's trying to convey? Extend beyond the original posting.
  • What do you think might be a shortcoming of the metaphor and the concept it's trying to convey to different audiences? Extend beyond the original posting.
  • Why do you think STEM fields are now prioritizing diversity, equity, and inclusion principles? Explain.
  • What do you think are potential benefits of considering diversity, equity, and inclusion principles in STEM? Explain.

Assessment

To earn points for this assignment, you must do the following:

  • Post Parts One and Two on time (or with prior approval, a day late) and mostly complete
  • Post a metaphor, explanation, evaluation, and audience consideration modifications from your discipline or stasis topic
  • Use our course texts and readings in your explanations

discussion_entries.message:
Metaphors In Computer Science.

Metaphors are EVERYWHERE in computer science. A complicated system of database calls, cookies, and more is simplified into a shopping cart on most online stores, code can inherit functionality from a parent or have children that inherit functionality from it. Errors are thrown and caught. Essentially, the metaphors are used for "information hiding" (Colburn). An online shopper doesn't need to know how their shopping choices are being stored and queued for them to purchase, it just needs to work and they need to be able to inherently understand what it's function is. Similarly a programmer (especially a new one) doesn't need to understand exactly how the computer is having code "inherit" code from somewhere else they just need to understand how to do it. The complexity of the modern computer is far to complex to ask the average person to try and understand just to buy something on amazon so the concepts are abstracted. "An abstraction is created to manage complexity through information hiding, and a metaphor is used to name the abstraction" (Colburn). I think the metaphors used in computer science are perfect. They hide the overwhelming amount of complexity beneath them that isn't necesary for the user to understand unless they want too. 

Works Cited.

Colburn, T.R., and G.M. Shute. “Metaphor in Computer Science.” Journal of Applied Logic, vol. 6, no. 4, Dec. 2008, pp. 526–533. Science Direct, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jal.2008.09.005. Accessed 1 Feb. 2022.

Hey Cate,

I really like this choice of metaphor I think it, and your explanation are really interesting. To build on your ideas though I think comparing mechanical systems to organisms also conveys a sense of evolution. The machine most likely doesn't look exactly like what the inventor had in mind when they started building, each part has probably grown and evolved to suit its intended function. This goes the other way as well though as the machine didn't evolve anything like living organisms do, the advancements were (most likely) not random mutations that had a positve or negative effect. Instead, they were a purposeful change in the design by the engineers so in a way I feel like it takes away from the impact the engineers had on the design making it sound like it evolved all by itself.  Great work, I think you did a great job equally representing both sides of the argument!

I think STEM fields are prioritizing inclusion, diversity, etc because as the saying goes "a rising tide raises all boats". A lot of what STEM fields do is turn ideas into things, and the more ideas you have as well as the wider the variety of ideas is the better. By that logic it's a no brainer to let anybody who wants be in stem be in stem. This is because letting in more people from different walks of life increases both the amount of ideas produced and leads to a greater variety in ideas hopefully leading to the best ideas being made into real things.

Based on your readings and course materials, consider how your academic discipline or stasis topic uses metaphors to communicate complex topics. Choose one "staple" metaphor (a common one that you see consistently either in your discipline or in your stasis topic). For example, the swiss cheese model of loss prevention can indicate how to provide multiple protective layers to minimize loss:

CC By SA-4.0 Ben Averling Design

This model was also applied to COVID prevention for my children's elementary school. 

CC By 4.0 Ian M. MacKay

For your discipline's or topic's metaphor use, explain the following in your posting:

  1. What is a common metaphor your discipline or topic uses to communicate a complicated concept?
  2. What is the metaphor intended to communicate? Be specific.
  3. How does the metaphor communicate this concept?
  4. In what ways is this metaphor effective in doing its job?  Explain, using points presented in "On the Problem and Promise of Metaphor Use in Science and Science Communication" and our course materials.
  5. In what ways might this metaphor be ineffective in doing its job? Explain, using points presented in "On the Problem and Promise of Metaphor Use in Science and Science Communication" and our course materials.
  6. Choose a different audience for the metaphor. In what ways might you need to adjust it to work for this audience? Explain two modifications you'd make and why you'd make them for this audience.

Part Two:

Select a posting from someone in the different discipline as you or something you found interesting in their metaphor selection. Answer the following:

  • What do you think is clear about that metaphor and the concept it's trying to convey? Extend beyond the original posting.
  • What do you think might be a shortcoming of the metaphor and the concept it's trying to convey to different audiences? Extend beyond the original posting.
  • Why do you think STEM fields are now prioritizing diversity, equity, and inclusion principles? Explain.
  • What do you think are potential benefits of considering diversity, equity, and inclusion principles in STEM? Explain.

Assessment

To earn points for this assignment, you must do the following:

  • Post Parts One and Two on time (or with prior approval, a day late) and mostly complete
  • Post a metaphor, explanation, evaluation, and audience consideration modifications from your discipline or stasis topic
  • Use our course texts and readings in your explanations

10 points | Two-Part Discussion

  • Part One Due: Wednesday, Jan. 5 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two Due: Friday, Jan. 7 by 11:59 pm

Please locate the rubric by selecting the three dots at the upper right of this discussion, then select "Show Rubric."

Please review Discussion Guidelines prior to posting.

Approximate time to complete both parts: 30 minutes

Part One: Jan. 5 by 11:59 pm (5 points--initial posting)

Welcome to Engl 147. Science fields require collaboration and STEM people often work on teams. We will be mimicking that characteristic in this course. Therefore, it's a good idea for you to get to know your colleagues and consider where your interests, schedules, and work modes align. Since we're in a hybrid course, and you'll be working on teams for some of our projects, I also think it's a good idea to allow you all to meet each other in some capacity, so please take some time to introduce yourself to the rest of our class. In the text box of this assignment (no attached documents), please answer the following questions: 

  1. Your name and major
  2. Your reasons for choosing your major (or if you're switching, why this new major)
  3. Your goals for this course (what you hope to learn)
  4. Your current location--e.g., on campus, off campus, etc.
  5. Your experiences at Cal Poly: projects thus far, classes, clubs, etc.
  6. Your experience with writing--when was the last time you wrote an essay? what types of writing do you like to do?
  7. Your STEM-related interests--what types of topics are you interested in exploring? What issues would you like to examine? List your top 3.
  8. What days/mornings/evenings of the week work best for you to meet with a team?
  9. Share something about yourself: Favorite hobbies/movies/music, etc...

To post, simply hit "reply" below. Then type into the text box and click "submit" when you're done.

Part Two: Jan. 7 by 11:59 pm (5 points--response to peers)

Choose two colleagues that you share some commonalities and respond to their postings. Say your version of "hello," describe what you may have in common, discuss what you'd like to learn from each other, discuss plans or ideas for completing this course or other courses, discuss possibilities of working together for collaborative activities, etc. In an effort to ensure that everyone gets at least one reply, make sure that you reply first to those without a reply and then move from there.

To earn credit for this assignment, students must complete the following:

  • Post Part One and Part Two by their respective due dates

recent_replies.message:
Hey Benjamin,

I'm Brandon Howell, I'm a first year, and I'm also a computer science major. I've also always loved computers, but I didn't have any real engineering courses at my high school so that decision was partially made for me. AI ethics is a super interesting topic, and one that will have to be explored even deeper as AI gets better in the future. I have a pretty similar schedule to you in terms of times I'm able to meet, so if we end up doing group projects or needing to study feel free to hit me up!

discussion_entries.message:
Hey Brandon,

I'm also a first year computer science major however, I was sure I wanted to be an engineer in 7th grade and it wasn't until I realized computer science wasn't like the website scratch that I found out I really loved it. I'm also excited for this class because the writing will be about issues in STEM which I am more likely to find interesting than the literary/history topics I've written about in the past. I'm also done with classes by 5 and I live in Tsiqawi.

Hello Joshua,

I'm interested to hear more about FIRST robotics as I've never heard of it. We had an engineering program at my high school called Project Lead The Way that was really great (especially since I was able to get credit at a community college for them and then transfer that credit to Cal Poly). I'm also interested in applying stem knowledge however since I'm a cs major I usually default to doing that through code. I have mostly afternoon classes but I'm free evenings every day of the week.

assignments.description:
Workshop: Claim of Value Essay

25 points | Preparation Grade | Two Parts

Estimated Duration: 90 minutes

Due Dates

  • Part One: Workshop Draft Posting: Wednesday Feb. 16 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two: Commenting on Two Peers' Essays: Friday Feb. 18 by 11:59 pm

Workshops for peer editing sessions provide a wonderful chance to get some valuable feedback from your colleagues in a low stakes setting. They have also been attuned to the assignment and participated in the same activities you have, so they can provide you insightful feedback. To prepare for this workshop, review:

  • Stasis Theory: Claim of Value
    • also, review the rubric
  • 2.4: MLA Citation: Avoiding Plagiarism, Academic Integrity, In-Text and Work Cited Citations
  • Writing Clear and Effective Sentences
  • Writing and Reasoning: ePrime

Part One: Workshop Draft Posting by Feb. 16 11:59 pm

Post a full working draft of your Claim of Value Essay and Works Cited page in pdf or docx format to this link. In order to be eligible for Part Two, you must post Part One on time. Inform your commenters of what you would like them to focus on as they provide you feedback. Use complete sentences. For example, if you're concerned about the thesis and unity, ask the reviewers to pay particular attention to those areas. You can also inform them of areas you'd rather they not spend attention to. For example, if you're still hashing out the conclusion, you can ask them not to bother with that part.

Part Two: Feedback Posting to Two Peers by Feb. 18 11:59 pm

On Tuesday, Feb. 15 at 6 am, you will be assigned two colleagues to provide constructive feedback. Please consult Canvas that morning to find them. See Canvas Guides links below for guidance. Once you've found your peers' essays, complete the following no later than Feb. 16 11:59 pm.

  • Read through each peer's submission and requests
  • Provide constructive criticism by filling out the rubric and annotating the writer's text. You should be able to do this by clicking on the document itself, making your comments, and typing directly into the rubric. Scroll down.

For clarity, please use complete sentences. Also, remember that this workshop is not a "seek out and destroy all grammar errors." You should focus on coherence, description, clarity, evidence, and unity when crafting your comments. Approach your partner's work as a reader who is interacting with the essay. What do you find interesting? What confuses you? What could be clearer? What engages you? 

Revision

Once you receive your feedback from your assigned peers, review and consider what advice you'll incorporate into your final draft to me, your instructor. Also, review your feedback from your Claim of Fact project. Use the clarity and conciseness materials for any areas that you struggle with in the writing. Use the MLA citation guides to ensure that you're integrating your source material ethically and smoothly.

  • 2.4: MLA Citation: Avoiding Plagiarism, Academic Integrity, In-Text and Work Cited Citations
  • Writing Clear and Effective Sentences
  • Writing and Reasoning: ePrime
  • Avoiding Wordiness Handout.pdf
  • Coherence: Making Connections in Your Writing

Have further questions? Attend office hours or make an appointment with theWriting and Learning Center.

Canvas Student Guides:

      • How do I know if I have a peer review assignment to complete? (Links to an external site.)
      • How do I submit a peer review to an assignment? (Links to an external site.)
      • Where can I find my peer's feedback for peer reviewed assignments? (Links to an external site.)
      • How do I annotate a file as an assignment submission in Canvas? (Links to an external site.)

Instructor Assessment

I will review your feedback to your peers  and award you a score based on the following criteria:

  • Quality of your feedback to your peers
    • Reviewer posts feedback that addresses the writers' requests
    • Reviewer posts constructive, thoughtful, and thorough feedback
  • Timeliness of your initial posting and feedback to your peers
    • Reviewer posts feedback by the due date to both peers
assignments.name: 7.1: Preparation: Workshop--Claim of Value Essay

rubric.long_description: How effectively does the writer represent and document the 3 stakeholders' viewpoints and perspectives in the essay? Do you see a variety of internal and external stakeholders represented? Do you see source references connected to these stakeholders' perspectives to indicate that these stakeholders are represented accurately and ethically?

How well does the writer identify and analyze the value systems of the stakeholders? Do you see binaries/tensions represented and examined? Does the writer establish an evaluation of where they stand? Does the writer explain why they hold the position they do?How effective is the writer's reasoning? Does the writer avoid committing logical fallacies? What else do you think the writer can do to improve the content and analysis?

How balanced is the essay? Do you see about 30% devoted to stakeholders' positions and the other 70% devoted to analysis and evaluation? What do you think could be improved? Be specific.
Can you follow the writer's train of thought? Does the writer use clear transitions from idea to idea? Does each paragraph fulfill a specific purpose in the essay? Does each paragraph make sense in the progression of ideas? Any suggestions for improvement?

How well does the writer establish their presence and position in the essay? How clear and precise is the language? Does the writer use appropriate tone for the essay's topic? Mark in the annotations any specific areas that you think are especially effective or unclear.

How effectively does the writer incorporate their research and documentation? Does the writer incorporate a minimum of 8 sources, 2 of which are peer reviewed and 1 that is an interview, into the essay in effective ways? Does the writer avoid floating quotes? Does the writer use both in-text documentation as well as a works cited? Does the in-text documentation match the works cited page? Are there any missing sources or unused sources on the works cited page? If so, this would indicate unintentional plagiarism.  Notify the writer of any discrepancies.

Discussion #3: Q & A 

Contributes to Grade in Claim of Fact Presentation | Team Project | 3 Parts

Due Dates: 

  • Part One: Wednesday Jan. 26 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two: Friday Jan. 28 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Three: Monday Jan. 31 by 11:59 pm

Part One: due Wednesday Jan. 26 by 11:59 pm

Your team should post the link to your Claim of Fact video here. One team member can do this for the whole team. In order to participate in this discussion and receive partners, you must post the link here on time.

Part Two: due by Friday Jan. 28 11:59 pm

Your team will be assigned to ask questions to another team's video submission. Please do the following:

  • View the other team's video submission.
  • Your team should post 3-4 relevant open-ended questions about the topic to this discussion. Note: open-ended questions are those that move beyond "yes/no" answers
    • each person who is part of the team must post a question, and it must be different from the other team member's questions in order to earn credit towards their claim of fact assignment

Part Three: due by Monday Jan. 31 11:59 pm

Your team will review the questions posted by your peers and answer them to the best of your abilities. I will provide some time in class on Monday for you to meet with the other team to clarify any questions and for your team to determine your answers.

  • each person who is part of the team must be represented in the answer to the questions--make sure you post some of your own writing in the reply 

Assessment

See the Claim of Fact Rubric for this portion of the grade

Canvas Guides

  • How do I know if I have a Peer Review discussion to complete?

Since this was a group posting, and I'm working out the "kinks" in Canvas, please let me know if you encounter any trouble. You should copy/paste your questions/answers to all the  people listed on your peer reviews. If you can't find the video link with one of the peers on your list, look through all of them. At least one of your partners will have a posted link. Once again, let me know if you encounter any trouble. Canvas is not intuitive.
assignments.name: Preparation | Discussion #3 | Q & A

discussion_entries.message:
"Hi guys, I really liked this presentation. My question is about the ethical lens on gene editing. The reports written by the Clinton administration and NBAC about the ethics of gene editing are now over 20 years old. As of 2021/2022, have the thoughts about the ethics of gene editing changed in any way in the U.S scientific community? Or is it mostly the same as it was in 1997 and 1999?"
- Timothy Ignatius Reyna , Jan 28 at 3:10pm
Hey Timothy thanks for watching our presentation I'm glad you enjoyed it. CRISPR was discovered 10+ years after the Clinton administrations reports and the conversation has been shifted as you might expect from such a breakthrough technology. Much of the debate now is over the ethics of human modification especially human enhancement, as well as the related topic of epigenetic modifications which could be inherited by the subjects offspring. Thanks again for watching and I hope this answers your question!

Contributes to Grade in Claim of Fact Presentation | Team Project | 3 Parts

Due Dates: 

  • Part One: Wednesday Jan. 26 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two: Friday Jan. 28 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Three: Monday Jan. 31 by 11:59 pm

Part One: due Wednesday Jan. 26 by 11:59 pm

Your team should post the link to your Claim of Fact video here. One team member can do this for the whole team. In order to participate in this discussion and receive partners, you must post the link here on time.

Part Two: due by Friday Jan. 28 11:59 pm

Your team will be assigned to ask questions to another team's video submission. Please do the following:

  • View the other team's video submission.
  • Your team should post 3-4 relevant open-ended questions about the topic to this discussion. Note: open-ended questions are those that move beyond "yes/no" answers
    • each person who is part of the team must post a question, and it must be different from the other team member's questions in order to earn credit towards their claim of fact assignment

Part Three: due by Monday Jan. 31 11:59 pm

Your team will review the questions posted by your peers and answer them to the best of your abilities. I will provide some time in class on Monday for you to meet with the other team to clarify any questions and for your team to determine your answers.

assignments.description:
Team Contract

The success of quality collaborative projects often relies significantly on meeting expectations for both team members and evaluators. By establishing team members' individual roles, norms, rewards, and sanctions formally through a well-organized contract reached by consensus, often teams can meet those expectations and have a great experience. Your team should determine early on the following:

  • Individual roles in the project
  • Team norms and expectations
  • Distribution of workload
  • Rewards for a job well done
  • Sanctions for not fulfilling requirements

Definitions:

  • Project Manager: people who "play the lead role in planning, executing, monitoring, controlling and closing projects. They are accountable for the entire project scope, project team, resources, and the success or failure of the project" (Alexander).
  • Coordinator: people who contact all team members, keep a summary of what occurs in meetings, contact all outside resources like interviews or instructor to notify of any changes, arrange venues for meetings, write agenda for upcoming meetings, relay any changes or adjustments to internal or external deadlines
  • Designer: people who determine the design and style concept for collaborative projects; they develop the template, color scheme, fonts, layout so that the design looks cohesive
  • Quality Control: people who review standards and determine whether or not the final product meets those standards
  • Internal Deadlines: the deadlines the project manager establishes to make sure that all team members have sufficient time to do their tasks to roll out the final product
  • External Deadlines: the deadlines the instructor provides for all due dates on projects

Review "Why and How do You Use a Team Contract?" in Technical Communication OER Textbook.pdf: Ch. 4.4 pp. 162-165 for specifics on what you should consider including in your contract (you don't need to itemize all of it). 

You will be working with your teams all quarter long, so establishing these standards early will help make for a smoother quarter. Don't underestimate the value of a well-designed contract. If you wish to make any changes to your contract as the quarter progresses, consult with your team, reach consensus, and repost the revised contract here.

Contract Contents

In your contract, I want to see the following:

  1. Each team member's full name
  2. Your team's broad topic and narrowed scope
  3. Each team member's individual lens choices--you can change this as necessary--just have the coordinator notify me
  4. Each team member's individual role (if the team has fewer members than roles, members will need to double-up some roles)
    • Project Manager--this person plans out the schedule of internal and external deadlines, leads the meetings, determines the content of meetings, and makes adjustments after listening to team members; this person also tries to meet the needs of all team members
    • Coordinator--this person is in charge of communications between team members and instructor
    • Designer--this person establishes templates, layout, and overall design scheme for collaborative projects
    • Quality Control--this person reviews the assignment description and rubric to ensure that the final product meets instructor expectations; this person proofreads the final product for any errors in execution of final product and recommends corrections to team members if necessary
  5. Expectations for Preparation: meeting attendance, prepared materials, allowances for emergencies, posting by due dates, etc.
  6. Sanctions for not meeting Expectations: 
    • What do you think should happen if someone doesn't meet expectations?
    • What specifically should your instructor do if someone doesn't meet their workload requirements or standards? Be specific and realistic with what I can do. 
    • How will you notify your team member about potential sanctions?
    • How will you notify your instructor about problems in team workload?
    • When will you notify your instructor about problems with the team?
  7. Rewards for Finished projects
    • What do you think your group should do to celebrate a completed project?
    • If someone in the group goes above and beyond in their contributions to the group, how should the instructor reward that member? (be realistic and reasonable here--I won't be handing out ponies...)
    • How will you notify your instructor that a team member contributed significantly more to the project?

Include an Electronic Signature that all group members agree to the contract requirements.

Works Cited

Alexander, Moira. "What is a Project Manager? The Lead Role for Project Success." CIO, 26 May 2019, https://www.cio.com/article/3224865/what-is-a-project-manager-the-lead-role-for-project-success.html, Accessed 19 Dec. 2020

assignments.description:
Choose Your Skills

As a way to customize your experience in this course, I want to provide you a range of different assignments that you can select from to practice and refine your writing, analytical, and research skills. To earn full credit for this requirement, you may successfully complete any 5 of these 8 "Choose Your Skills" assignments--look for the labels in the assignments or see the table below for your choices.  Assignments have specific due dates, so plan out your submissions accordingly.

Choose Your Skills Activities
Assignment Link and Title Brief Description Due Date
Choose Your Skills: Quiz--MLA Citation
  • quiz that measures your understanding of MLA citation formatting
 Jan. 14 by 11:59 pm
Choose Your Skills: Notice and Focus Exercise
  • pre-writing activity that develops your analytical skills using your Stasis Theory: Claim of Fact Evidence
    • helps you identify patterns and important evidence in your data
 Jan. 19 by 11:59 pm
Choose Your Skills: Quiz: Deductive, Inductive, and Abductive Reasoning
  • quiz that measures your understanding of deductive, inductive, and abductive reasoning
 Jan. 21 by 11:59 pm
Choose Your Skills: Extended Definition Practice
  • pre-writing discussion activity that asks you to describe a complex concept or technology associated with your claim of value topic using technical definition strategies

Part One: Feb. 2 by 11:59 pm

Part Two: Feb. 4 by 11:59 pm
Choose Your Skills: Defining the Conversation
  • pre-writing activity linked to your Claim of Value project. Summarizes your three stakeholders you've selected for this project and analyze the tensions between their perspectives and value systems
 Feb. 9 by 11:59 pm
Choose Your Skills | Discussion #5 | Data Visualization Introduction and Analysis
  • Analysis activity that asks you to examine and evaluate effective and ineffective data visualizations

Part One: March 2 by 11:59 pm

Part Two: March 4 by 11:59 pm
Choose Your Skills: Style and Clarity
  • Revision activity that asks you to revise two paragraphs from your claim of value project to improve style and clarity

March 9 by 11:59 pm
Choose Your Skills: Propaganda in an Industry
  • analysis activity that encourages you to explore how propaganda works in an industry
 March 4 by 11:59 pm

I do not award extra credit for completing more of these assignments. I want you to select what you truly think will help you improve your skills. If you'd like to complete more than 5, feel free, but I will only issue a score for 5 total. These will not substitute for any of your Preparation assignments.

Number of Activities Successfully Completed Score
5 100
4 85
3 70
2 55
1 20
