assignments.description:
Data Visualization Introduction and Analysis

Choose Your Skills Tally Mark | Two Parts

Estimated Duration: approximately 60 minutes to complete both parts

Due Dates: 

  • Part One--Wednesday March 2 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two--Friday  March 4 by 11:59 pm

Please locate the rubric by selecting the three dots at the upper right of this discussion, then select "Show Rubric."

Please review the Discussion Guidelines prior to participating in any discussions. 

Objectives:

After the successful completion of this Discussion Activity, you will be able to:

  • Find examples of data visualizations that center around one topic
  • Interpret a variety of features in data visualizations
  • Identify the purpose conveyed by data visualizations using inference and context
  • Evaluate the effectiveness of various data visualizations by using specific examples to illustrate your explanations
  • Evaluate the quality of data visualizations
  • Evaluate the source quality of various websites using the "Starting Your Research..." course module information and lecture materials

Overview:

Data and factual information can be presented multiple ways. Each choice in the visual representation of the data is designed to convey a message using that hard evidence. If the designer uses the data as presented, the representations are technically accurate, but some representations are more ethical or truthful than others. Using either the recent Presidential Election Map or Coronavirus visualizations as your central topic, you will choose two data visualizations total: one that you think represents the data ethically and one that you think misrepresents the data. Prior to your selection, read through either Packet One: Election Results Map Analyses or Packet Two: Coronavirus Data Visualizations:

Packet One--Election Results Map Analyses:

With the tumultuous election year for the presidency, we've seen many electoral maps being distributed by both major parties as proof of the final tally. These maps use data published by the Associated Press and other reliable places, making the data reliable. Yet, the maps indicate different results based on who is making them and what message they want to convey. Read through the following articles (one is from 2018 rather than 2020, so keep that in mind).

  • "Is the US Leaning Red or Blue? It All Depends on Your Map" by Issie Lipowsky from Wired magazine (2018)
  • "Four Maps that Show How America Voted in the 2020 Election, with Results by County and Number of Voters" by Mitchell Thorson et al. from USA Today newspaper (2020)

Packet Two--Coronavirus Data Visualizations:

Quite a few successful data visualizations work to help the public understand the global coronavirus impact. Some of these are meant to inform about the number of cases, deaths, and recoveries in each country. Some are designed to persuade the public to participate in "flattening the curve" of coronavirus. Others are meant to infuse some humor in trying times or even distort an audience's understanding of the virus' transmission. Here are a few of examples of data visualizations I've seen that have been used to help the general public understand a complex concept.

  • "Flattening the Curve (Links to an external site.)" by the Washington Post
  • "Coronavirus Live Map (Links to an external site.)" by USA Facts
  • "Frivolous Coronavirus Graphs (Links to an external site.)" by New Yorker

Look through these various data visualizations and answer the following (you will include your answers in Part One of assignment):

Packet Questions

  • What is the main takeaway that you found significant in your packet of articles? Be specific and use examples.
  • Why did you find that information significant?

Part One

Find one example of either an effective 2020 Election/coronavirus data visualization and one example of an ineffective 2020 Election/coronavirus data visualization: two examples total. They can't come from the examples I've provided you above. You need to choose new ones. You will be referencing both of these in your Discussion posting, so make sure that you have an image to share either by embedding the image or attaching to this posting or including a link to the webpage. To determine why the data visualizations are effective or ineffective, answer the questions below into sections. 

Evaluation Questions

  • What is the main takeaway you can gather from the graphics you selected?
  • What is the purpose of the graphics you selected?
  • What specific features from the graphics contribute to your interpretation?
  • What specific features (or lack thereof) detract from the purpose/meaning?
  • Do the data visualization creators provide evidence of where they gathered their data?
  • What do you think are some strong elements of the graphics you selected? Why?
  • What do you think are some weak elements of the graphics you selected? Why?

In your posting, include the following in this order:

First: Topic--either 2020 Election Map or Coronavirus Data Visualizations

Second: Brief summary of your answers to Packet Questions about Packet One or Packet Two articles.

  • What is the main takeaway that you found significant in your packet of articles? Be specific and use examples.
  • Why did you find that information significant?

Third: Ineffective Data Visualization Image (either embedded image, link, or attached file)

  1. Location--the publication, blog, website, etc. by name that houses it
  2. Purpose--what it is supposed to do
  3. Quality--why it's ineffective--be specific by including examples and answers to your Evaluation Questions

Fourth: Effective Data Visualization Image (either embedded image, link, or attached file)

  1. Location--the publication, blog, website, etc. by name that houses it
  2. Purpose--what it is supposed to do
  3. Quality--why it's effective--be specific by including examples and answers to your Evaluation Questions

Part Two:

In part two, you will select a person's posting who hasn't received a response yet, and you will find their data visualization examples using a reverse-image search or the link they provide. Then you will examine the location of the material and determine its reliability based on our discussions and materials about source evaluation. Finally, you will reply to that person's posting by agreeing, disagreeing, or agreeing with a difference to their assessment in approximately 250 words. Explain why you hold the position you do and use more detail in your evaluation of the data visualizations--don't merely repeat what the original posting had. Extend the analysis and evaluation.

To complete the project to build toward preparation grade tally:

  • Include all the requirements for the assignment
  • Provide examples of one effective and one ineffective 2020 Election Map or Coronavirus Data Visualization (must be different from the examples I provided above)
  • Post on time for Part One and Part Two of the assignment
  • Provide sufficient explanations using criteria and terminology from our texts, discussions, and selected data visualizations

Happy Hunting!

Resources:

How to Perform a Reverse Image Search the Easy Way

Reverse Image Search Procedure:

Conduct a Reverse Image Search to verify that the image's origins are what it purports to be.

  • Copy image link or save image to desktop
  • Go to Google Images
  • Paste image link or upload saved image from desktop
  • Click camera icon--"search by image"
  • Then double check the history of the image appearances from the list that Google provides

 

References:

"2020 Election Results--'Most of America is Purple' from Massachusetts Institute of Technology." USA TODAY, 10 Nov. 2020, https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/graphics/2020/11/10/election-maps-2020-america-county-results-more-voters/6226197002/, Accessed 15 Dec. 2020

All other Materials on this page

Copyright by Erin Martin-Elston  

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License

discussion_entries.message:
First: Topic--either 2020 Election Map or Coronavirus Data Visualizations

Second: Brief summary of your answers to Packet Questions about Packet One or Packet Two articles.

  • What is the main takeaway that you found significant in your packet of articles? Be specific and use examples.
    • The uses of data visualization don't have to be complex to communicate complex ideas, this is best shown by the animation in the washington post article where the "people" bounce around the box starting with one sick person showing exponential spread
  • Why did you find that information significant?
    • the visual was much more convincing than hearing "if infections keep going at an exponential rate we'll be at x number by y"

Third: Ineffective Data Visualization Image (either embedded image, link, or attached file)

  1. Location--the publication, blog, website, etc. by name that houses
    • CDC.gov
  2. Purpose--what it is supposed to do
    • show infomation showing both how many people in each group have been tested and how many have tested positive
  3. Quality--why it's ineffective--be specific by including examples and answers to your Evaluation Questions
    • It is very confusing, hard to extract any real meaning from. It is especially hard to make correlations between positivity rates as the y axis actually represents % positve for the lines and # tested for specimens so the overlap is only because of the scales of the axis

Fourth: Effective Data Visualization Image (either embedded image, link, or attached file)

  1. Location--the publication, blog, website, etc. by name that houses it
    • the center for evidence based medicine
  2. Purpose--what it is supposed to do
    • show the number of deaths to covid at different times of the year for different years
  3. Quality--why it's effective--be specific by including examples and answers to your Evaluation Questions
    • it's effective because you can see the spikes / new variants impacts compared to eachother and becasue the times are overlayed you can compare it to other years really easy. So the graph is very easy to interpret and also easily represents the differences in the of number of deaths over time

recent_replies.message:
Hi Benjamin,

 

The CDC is considered one of the greatest public health agencies by non-medical and medical personnel across the world, and the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine has close ties to the University of Oxford, a world renown university, so I believe the sources of the graphs come from reliable institutions and are credible.

I agree with your position regarding the ineffective data visualization example you provided since I think the information is hard to digest at a glance. I believe the x-axis labels are in year/week# format, but for someone looking through many graphs everyday, I think this would cause frustration. There is a lot of information on the chart, especially with the double y-axis data with many data points, however, I do think the correlation between higher test positivity and # of specimens tested is clear to see. Overall, I do agree with your stance.

As for your effective chart, I believe this one is borderline ineffective. At a glance, I can understand the information, but a circular chart makes it harder to see the trends over time. When comparing from one week to another I found myself circling around the chart, which is a bit tedious when this wouldn't be an issue with a horizontal chart. Overall, I think the chart effective in showing big spikes in deaths but less effective when comparing week to week, especially if the weeks are far apart in time.

Hey Benjamin,

Your first source for ineffective data comes from a very reliable source. I like how the CDC's site has a link where you can view the raw data and examine it to compare to the chart to double-check the findings. I agree the graph can be quite confusing to understand and therefore extract real data from it. I think it also adds confusion that laid data over each other that are based on different units. The data laid over each other makes the reader think they are correlated, but since one is measured by ten-thousands, and the other is measured by percentage, it can be misleading.

For the second source, I think the source is quite reliable as it let us know where all the information was gathered from and the people who gathered this information are quite reputable. While I agree that the data is effective since you can see the spikes in covid in relation to the spikes before covid, I think that same fact makes the data slightly ineffective. I say this because the data includes deaths from both covid, and everything else, and the way the graph is set up, there's no way to distinguish which deaths were caused by covid and which weren't. Because of this, it could be that spikes in the graph were caused by covid, or there could have been other factors involved.

discussion_entries.message: Hi Emily, I would actually disagree and say that the first graph is actually pretty good. Although it does show the %infected close to the top of the graph I believe that is mostly to make the most out of the space available and make the differences more pronounced, not falsely portray covid as more dangerous than it actually is. In fact I think the second graph does the pretty much the same thing. If the second graphs scale was much larger, ending at something like 10,000, the daily confirmed cases would look much lower. I think this is ok because the graphs are not entirely meant to show how serious covid is, but to allow comparing different covid statistics which you talk about when describing why the second graph is good. On that I couldn't agree more, I think it does a great job of showing how contries spiked together but also how they were different.

Prior to your selection, read through either Packet One: Election Results Map Analyses or Packet Two: Coronavirus Data Visualizations:

Packet One--Election Results Map Analyses:

With the tumultuous election year for the presidency, we've seen many electoral maps being distributed by both major parties as proof of the final tally. These maps use data published by the Associated Press and other reliable places, making the data reliable. Yet, the maps indicate different results based on who is making them and what message they want to convey. Read through the following articles (one is from 2018 rather than 2020, so keep that in mind).

  • "Is the US Leaning Red or Blue? It All Depends on Your Map" by Issie Lipowsky from Wired magazine (2018)
  • "Four Maps that Show How America Voted in the 2020 Election, with Results by County and Number of Voters" by Mitchell Thorson et al. from USA Today newspaper (2020)

Packet Two--Coronavirus Data Visualizations:

Quite a few successful data visualizations work to help the public understand the global coronavirus impact. Some of these are meant to inform about the number of cases, deaths, and recoveries in each country. Some are designed to persuade the public to participate in "flattening the curve" of coronavirus. Others are meant to infuse some humor in trying times or even distort an audience's understanding of the virus' transmission. Here are a few of examples of data visualizations I've seen that have been used to help the general public understand a complex concept.

  • "Flattening the Curve (Links to an external site.)" by the Washington Post
  • "Coronavirus Live Map (Links to an external site.)" by USA Facts
  • "Frivolous Coronavirus Graphs (Links to an external site.)" by New Yorker

Look through these various data visualizations and answer the following (you will include your answers in Part One of assignment):

Packet Questions

  • What is the main takeaway that you found significant in your packet of articles? Be specific and use examples.
  • Why did you find that information significant?

Part One

Find one example of either an effective 2020 Election/coronavirus data visualization and one example of an ineffective 2020 Election/coronavirus data visualization: two examples total. They can't come from the examples I've provided you above. You need to choose new ones. You will be referencing both of these in your Discussion posting, so make sure that you have an image to share either by embedding the image or attaching to this posting or including a link to the webpage. To determine why the data visualizations are effective or ineffective, answer the questions below into sections. 

Evaluation Questions

  • What is the main takeaway you can gather from the graphics you selected?
  • What is the purpose of the graphics you selected?
  • What specific features from the graphics contribute to your interpretation?
  • What specific features (or lack thereof) detract from the purpose/meaning?
  • Do the data visualization creators provide evidence of where they gathered their data?
  • What do you think are some strong elements of the graphics you selected? Why?
  • What do you think are some weak elements of the graphics you selected? Why?

In your posting, include the following in this order:

First: Topic--either 2020 Election Map or Coronavirus Data Visualizations

Second: Brief summary of your answers to Packet Questions about Packet One or Packet Two articles.

  • What is the main takeaway that you found significant in your packet of articles? Be specific and use examples.
  • Why did you find that information significant?

Third: Ineffective Data Visualization Image (either embedded image, link, or attached file)

  1. Location--the publication, blog, website, etc. by name that houses it
  2. Purpose--what it is supposed to do
  3. Quality--why it's ineffective--be specific by including examples and answers to your Evaluation Questions

Fourth: Effective Data Visualization Image (either embedded image, link, or attached file)

  1. Location--the publication, blog, website, etc. by name that houses it
  2. Purpose--what it is supposed to do
  3. Quality--why it's effective--be specific by including examples and answers to your Evaluation Questions

Part Two:

In part two, you will select a person's posting who hasn't received a response yet, and you will find their data visualization examples using a reverse-image search or the link they provide. Then you will examine the location of the material and determine its reliability based on our discussions and materials about source evaluation. Finally, you will reply to that person's posting by agreeing, disagreeing, or agreeing with a difference to their assessment in approximately 250 words. Explain why you hold the position you do and use more detail in your evaluation of the data visualizations--don't merely repeat what the original posting had. Extend the analysis and evaluation.

To complete the project to build toward preparation grade tally:

  • Include all the requirements for the assignment
  • Provide examples of one effective and one ineffective 2020 Election Map or Coronavirus Data Visualization (must be different from the examples I provided above)
  • Post on time for Part One and Part Two of the assignment
  • Provide sufficient explanations using criteria and terminology from our texts, discussions, and selected data visualizations

Happy Hunting!

Resources:

How to Perform a Reverse Image Search the Easy Way

Reverse Image Search Procedure:

Conduct a Reverse Image Search to verify that the image's origins are what it purports to be.

  • Copy image link or save image to desktop
  • Go to Google Images
  • Paste image link or upload saved image from desktop
  • Click camera icon--"search by image"
  • Then double check the history of the image appearances from the list that Google provides

 

References:

"2020 Election Results--'Most of America is Purple' from Massachusetts Institute of Technology." USA TODAY, 10 Nov. 2020, https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/graphics/2020/11/10/election-maps-2020-america-county-results-more-voters/6226197002/, Accessed 15 Dec. 2020

assignments.description:
Defining the Conversation

Format: One document uploaded to this assignment link in pdf or docx format

Workload: Two page double-spaced with paragraphs and works cited page in MLA format

Estimated Duration: approximately 2 hours to complete if you've already done your research

Value: Tally toward Choose Your Skills activities if assessed as competent

Due Date: 

  • Wednesday Feb. 9 by 11:59 pm

Objectives:

After the successful completion of this Activity, you will be able to:

  • Summarize multiple stakeholders' position using standard summary conventions
  • Define the scope of the conversation about your Stasis Theory project
  • Identify tensions and alignments between multiple stakeholders
  • Integrate source material using MLA in-text and works cited citation

Overview

The Conversation

"Imagine that you enter a parlor. You come late. When you arrive, others have long preceded you, and they are engaged in a heated discussion, a discussion too heated for them to pause and tell you exactly what it is about. In fact, the discussion had already begun long before any of them got there, so that no one present is qualified to retrace for you all the steps that had gone before. You listen for a while, until you decide that you have caught the tenor of the argument; then you put in your oar. Someone answers; you answer him; another comes to your defense; another aligns himself against you, to either the embarrassment or gratification of your opponent, depending upon the quality of your ally's assistance. However, the discussion is interminable. The hour grows late, and you must depart. And you do depart, with the discussion still vigorously in progress."

--The Philosophy of Literary From--Kenneth Burke 1941

Your Stasis Theory: Claim of Value project requires you to establish three stakeholders' viewpoints, concerns, and connections to your topic. This choose your skills project gives you the opportunity to do some pre-writing by summarizing these viewpoints, using research that provides you those insights. To complete this project, follow the steps below:

Step One:

Find reliable research that establishes clear, different, and explicit viewpoints from a combination of internal and external stakeholders. Your project requires a minimum of three stakeholders' viewpoints, so this assignment will require the three that you're thinking about using for your essay. Make sure that your stakeholders are connected to your main topic and have points of tension or dissent as well as some commonalities between each other. Good places to look for these viewpoints include the following:

  • conduct a Google search using "op-ed" + your topic
  • use the library databases like Opposing Viewpoints or CQ Researcher
  • watch TED Talks
  • listen to Podcasts

Your texts must be published somewhere reliable in order to qualify for this assignment. Avoid procon.org, as this site rarely has substantive or developed arguments.

Step Two:

Read 4.2: Standard Summary Conventions Once you've found your stakeholders' viewpoints, identify their claims, grounds, and warrants. Now, it's time to identify moments of alignment and tensions within these viewpoints. Using the Analytical Moves from "The Method," look across all your stakeholders' claims, grounds, evidence, and warrants. Identify the following (descriptions 6.1: 5 Analytical Moves: Analytical Heuristics:

  • Repetitions--Alignments
  • Strands--Alignments
  • Binary/Oppositions--Tensions
  • Anomalies

These identifications will help you determine the scope of your topic and frame the conversation for your upcoming essay.

Step Three:

Using standard summary conventions, provide a two page double-spaced description of the stakeholders' positions within the conversation and corresponding works cited page. Your framing of the conversation should include the following:

  • define the scope of the topic
  • establish clear and distinct viewpoints (minimum of three stakeholders)--summaries
  • include all sources in writing and on works cited page
  • identify ranked binaries/tensions and why they're significant
  • identify ranked repetitions/alignments and why they're significant
  • use accurate MLA8 citation both in-text and works cited

Standard summary conventions include the following techniques:

  • Provide objective rendering of stakeholders' positions--don't editorialize yet: save that for your essay
  • Identify author's name, article title, and position in opening line of introduction to viewpoint and sandwich-cite your borrowed content
  • Write in the present tense
  • Condense each summary in 150 words or less
  • Use the author's last name and signal phrases with strong verbs (avoid "talks," "says," and "writes")
  • Use your own words for the most part, but any borrowed language (kept to a minimum) must be encased in quotation marks

Note: Each stakeholder's perspective must be represented by a published source. It's not enough to provide a generalized description--you must have someone "on the record" for holding that viewpoint. You can incorporate much of this material into your Claim of Value essay.

References

Photo by Christina @ wocintechchat.com on Unsplash
assignments.name: Choose Your Skills: Defining the Conversation

rubric.description: Source Quality, Representation of Viewpoints, and Integration
rubric.long_description: The quality of the writer's source selection is reliable, demonstrates multiple viewpoints, grapples with the topic, integrates all sources within the writing.  The writer makes ethical choices when including all source material.

ratings.long_description: The writer chooses exceptional sources to represent the stakeholders' perspectives and presents them ethically and thoroughly using standard summary conventions. The writer skillfully integrates all source material as they move from point to point.

The writer uses reliable yet general sources to represent the stakeholders' viewpoints using many of the standard summary conventions. The writer competently weaves in the research but some of the source integration gets awkward in places. Maybe there are a few floating quotes or somewhat confusing sentences. For the most part, the writer represents the source material ethically but may slightly misrepresent a minor point or neglect to address a position's complexity.

The writer is missing a stakeholder's viewpoint, may use an unreliable or superficial source to represent a viewpoint, or may misrepresent or misattribute a position in a significant way and has significant trouble using standard summary conventions. The writer tends to over-rely on the source material to speak for itself rather than to interpret and summarize it.

rubric.long_description: The writer accurately cites all sources used in the text, both in-text and on the works cited page. The writer maneuvers through the various sources using clear, precise, and varied signal phrases or parenthetical citation. The writer avoids unintentional plagiarism.

ratings.long_description: The writer seamlessly integrates and cites material ethically and correctly. The works cited page matches the contents in the assignment. The writer uses signal phrases and parenthetical citation appropriately with conscious intent.

The writer integrates and cites material somewhat ethically and generally correctly. The works cited page matches the contents in the assignment. The writer uses signal phrases and parenthetical citation but some places may be awkward or clunky.

The writer has significant trouble integrating and citing material ethically and correctly. The works cited page does not match the contents in the assignment. The writer misuses or neglects to use signal phrases and parenthetical citation.

rubric.long_description: The writer clearly defines the topic and conversation between the sources selected.  The writer demonstrates nuanced and subtle observations and/or connections within the texts. The writer explores and exhausts the conversation's complexities by identifying moments of tension and alignments.

ratings.long_description: The writer skillfully and stylistically defines the topic and conversation between the sources selected. The writer demonstrates nuanced and subtle observations and/or connections within the texts. The writer explores and exhausts the conversation's complexities by identifying moments of tension and alignments using the Method's analytical approach.

The writer generally defines the topic and conversation between the sources selected. The writer demonstrates general observations and/or connections within the texts. The writer presents some of the conversation's complexities by identifying moments of tension and alignments using a generalized application of the Method.

The writer misidentifies or misrepresents the topic and conversation between the sources selected. The writer demonstrates superficial or non-existent observations and/or connections within the texts. The writer makes logical leaps when identifying the moments of tension and alignment or neglects to include any tensions or alignments.

assignments.description:
Choose Your Skills: Extended Definition Practice

Discussion Posting | Choose Your Skills Tally | Two Parts

estimated completion time: 45 minutes

  • Part One Due: Wednesday  Feb. 2 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two Due: Friday Feb. 4 by 11:59 pm

To see rubric, click on 3 dots above

Definition is one of the most  powerful forms of argument. In science, your ability to define and communicate complex concepts to layperson audiences is vital. To complete this assignment, make sure you have read the following: 

  • 5.1: Definition
  • What is Plain Language?
  • 5.5: Techniques for Definition

You will apply these concepts in your definition and description.

Part One: Due Wednesday Feb. 2 by 11:59 pm

Using the technical descriptions reading for definition and the different ways to define a concept, describe a complex concept or technology from your Stasis Theory topic in 300 words or less. You must use at least three different techniques listed in 5.5: Techniques for Definition in your description. You may end up using this passage in your claim of value project. In order to be eligible for Part Two, you will need to post Part One on time.

Part Two: Due Friday Feb. 4 by 11:59 pm

Reply to your assigned partner's posting. Comment on the following:

  • How effectively can you picture the concept or technology based on your peer's description?
  • What specific techniques did you see your peer use in their description? Comment on two and their effectiveness.
  • What do you think could be improved in the description?

Assessment

To earn credit for this assignment, you will need to:

  • Post Parts One and Two on time
  • Write a description of a complex concept or technology from your Stasis Topic using three different techniques and technical definition concepts
  • Comment on your assigned peer's posting with evaluative and constructive feedback

discussion_entries.message:
Definition: how disease testing with crispr works.

The first stage in developing a CRISPR based test for a disease involves preparing a sample of the target DNA. This target DNA is DNA extracted from the infectious cells that are being tested for. Once a sample of the target DNA has been extracted, the amount of DNA is amplified using a process called RPA which "is rapid and does not require special equipment" (Chertow). The DNA from the sample is then combined with CAS protiens which convert the DNA into CRISPR RNA (crRNA) which it then uses as a guide telling it where to cut. The RNA-guided CAS enzymes can then be combined with a sample from a patient. The Cas enzymes cut sequences of DNA matching the target DNA and fluorescent reporters bind with the RNA formed from the cleaved DNA sequences. The fluorescent signal can be "amplified though enzymatic activity, which enhances test sensitivity" (Chertow). This method "provides a result in 1-2 hours" (Chertow). These tests are relatively simple to develop (requiring little more than the target DNA), highly accurate, efficient, and highly applicable as they can be used to test for anything with DNA. 

Works Cited:

Chertow, Daniel S. “Next-generation diagnostics with CRISPR.” Science, vol 360, no. 6387, 27 April, 2018, pp. 381-382., https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aat4982

recent_replies.message:
Hello Benjamin,

I found it interesting how CRISPR can be used for disease testing as it is something I didn't previously.  I was able to get a good picture about the overall concept from your definition about how DNA matching is used to detect diseases. However, each individual process of how it was done was not clear to me and I was not able to visualize them as someone not involved in Biology. I can see that you used literal definitions a few times – some of which are relatively complex and I think it was mostly appropriate for college level readers but may not work to the same extent for people who are not at that level of reading. Process definition is a big part of your piece which makes sense since the who thing is a process and chronologically explaining the process was effective in my opinion. I think what CAS proteins should have been defined because I have no idea what they are and how are they different from other kinds of proteins. I would also have liked to see more analogy definitions as they would help outsiders to the topic get a better picture by helping them to relate to things they already know.

discussion_entries.message:
Hi Mazen,

I can picture how osmotic power works really well. You understandably used a lot of Process definition since osmotic power is the process of using osmosis to generate energy, and you also used stipulitive definitions for some of the technical words which I appreciated because It helped me understand what you meant. If I had to choose something for you to improve I think it would be the structure. I was a little confused at first what exactly osmotic power was or why I should care. I think the sentence on what it can be harnessed for (turbine, etc) should be at the beginning and maybe elaborate more on how it's harnessed later in the paragraph. I was also a little confused how the salt concentration was able to generate enough pressure to be meaningful but that's because I don't really remember the specifics of the power balance between solid concentration and pressure in osmosis so it's up to you whether you elaborate more on that. Overall great job! I had no idea osmosis was a viable energy source!

assignment.description:
Choose Your Skills: Extended Definition Practice

Discussion Posting | Choose Your Skills Tally | Two Parts

estimated completion time: 45 minutes

  • Part One Due: Wednesday  Feb. 2 by 11:59 pm
  • Part Two Due: Friday Feb. 4 by 11:59 pm

To see rubric, click on 3 dots above

Definition is one of the most  powerful forms of argument. In science, your ability to define and communicate complex concepts to layperson audiences is vital. To complete this assignment, make sure you have read the following: 

  • 5.1: Definition
  • What is Plain Language?
  • 5.5: Techniques for Definition

You will apply these concepts in your definition and description.

Part One: Due Wednesday Feb. 2 by 11:59 pm

Using the technical descriptions reading for definition and the different ways to define a concept, describe a complex concept or technology from your Stasis Theory topic in 300 words or less. You must use at least three different techniques listed in 5.5: Techniques for Definition in your description. You may end up using this passage in your claim of value project. In order to be eligible for Part Two, you will need to post Part One on time.

Part Two: Due Friday Feb. 4 by 11:59 pm

Reply to your assigned partner's posting. Comment on the following:

  • How effectively can you picture the concept or technology based on your peer's description?
  • What specific techniques did you see your peer use in their description? Comment on two and their effectiveness.
  • What do you think could be improved in the description?

Assessment

To earn credit for this assignment, you will need to:

  • Post Parts One and Two on time
  • Write a description of a complex concept or technology from your Stasis Topic using three different techniques and technical definition concepts
  • Comment on your assigned peer's posting with evaluative and constructive feedback

assignments.description:
Choose Your Skills: Notice and Focus Exercise

Choose Your Skills Activity

Notice and Focus created by Rosenwasser and Stephen--adapted by Erin Martin-Elston.

This is an activity with three steps. To begin this activity, you will need to have acquired, reviewed, and annotated at least 4 reliable sources for your Claim of Fact project. If you don't have those yet, you will not be able to complete this Choose Your Skills assignment. Also, you need to have reviewed: 2.4: MLA Citation: Avoiding Plagiarism, Academic Integrity, In-Text and Work Cited Citations.

Estimated Duration: 60 minutes + your previous research process

Due: by Wednesday Jan. 19, 2022

Grading: Complete/Incomplete tally toward Choose Your Skills

Please locate the rubric by scrolling down to the bottom of this page.

This exercise is an analytical tool that you can apply to research and texts. Notice and Focus enhances your observational skills and encourages you to hone in on what you think is important or significant in your data/evidence. 

After the successful completion of this exercise, you will be able to:

  • Identify significant evidence in your range of research
  • Rank the evidence you consider to be important
  • Explain the significance of the evidence you've ranked
  • Practice accurate MLA8 format for works cited pages

Notice and Focus Procedure

Look at your list of evidence you've accumulated for your Stasis Theory: Claim of Fact assignment. At this stage, you should have a minimum of four reliable sources that you've reviewed and annotated. You're going to make a list of everything that you notice across your research, so create a document to jot down your observations. This exercise requires you to "dwell in the data" and move beyond perfunctory scanning (Rosenwasser and Stephen).

Step One:

For approximately 30 minutes, repeatedly answer the question: "What do you Notice?" (Rosenwasser and Stephen).

Jot down every single piece of evidence you notice in a list during this time period. Try to reach a list of at least 10 pieces of evidence across at least four different sources.

Step Two: 

Rank by order of importance the various data that you have noticed. Choose the" top three details you think are most interesting (or significant or revealing or strange)" (Rosenwasser and Stephen). Please note that this is about what data/evidence intrigue you or make an impression on you. 

Step Three:

Write why the three things you selected struck you as the most "interesting," "strange," "significant," or" revealing" (Rosenwasser and Stephen).  Explain what types of logical connections you can make across your research; please use complete sentences. Devote approximately 200 words to this step. These components or examples from the image will serve as part of your list that you can incorporate into your Claim of Fact analysis.

Construct a Works Cited page in MLA8 format that includes at least 4 sources that you used to inform you. Use the Purdue OWL link below for accurate formatting.

MLA Style Guide--Purdue OWL

Assignment Submission Format

Post your list, ranking, responses, and works cited to this assignment in pdf or docx format. You can use much of this material in your Claim of Fact assignment. Your final document submission for this activity should look like this:

Notice and Focus: 

  • Step One: your topic and list of evidence--try to reach 10 and include references--which source is informing you? Include evidence from at least 4 different sources
  • Step Two: your ranking of significance
  • Step Three: ~200 words explanation of significance and connetions
  • Works Cited in MLA8 format with a minimum of four sources--Use this link: Purdue OWL

Works Cited

Photo by redcharlie on Unsplash

Rosenwasser, David and Jill Stephen. Writing Analytically. 5th ed. Thomson Wadsworth, 2009.

assignments.description:
Choose Your Skills: Propaganda in an Industry

Format: One document uploaded to this assignment link in pdf or docx format

Workload: Two page double-spaced with paragraphs, examples, and works cited page in MLA format

Estimated Duration: approximately 60 minutes to complete

Value: Preparation Grade Tally Completion

Due Date: 

  • March 4 by 11:59 pm

Objectives:

After the successful completion of this Activity, you will be able to:

  • Identify propaganda techniques in industries
  • Analyze how the propaganda techniques function 
  • Explain how propaganda techniques persuade audience

Overview

Assignment Description

Review the following texts:

  • 9.4: Propaganda: How To Detect List

You will examine a propaganda technique at work within a specific industry or arena. If it's a propaganda technique not on our list, research its definition. Choose one term from each column to focus your project. 

Propaganda and Industry List
Propaganda Technique Industry or Arena
Gaslighting News Media
Greenwashing Politics
Euphemism Agriculture
Framing Human Rights
Card Stacking Energy
Echo Chamber Technology
Whataboutism Health

Once you have selected one Propaganda technique and one Industry (arena), research the term and define it. Then, find current (within the last year--January 1, 2021 cutoff) examples from the industry or arena of your choice and explain how these examples demonstrate this technique to influence public sentiment. 

You will need to include the following:

  • specific, detailed examples (a minimum of three different examples)
  • clear definitions of techniques
  • detailed explanations of how the examples illustrate the propaganda technique
  • detailed explanations of how these examples influence public sentiment
  • works cited list to show where all borrowed content was accessed

Assessment

To earn a complete tally mark for your submission, you must include the following:

  • Assignment submitted by the due date
  • Selected Industry and Propaganda Technique from the list above
  • Three current (within the last year--January 1, 2021 cutoff) examples of industry and propaganda technique
  • Accurate descriptions of how the examples illustrate the propaganda label you applied
  • Accurately and ethically documented in MLA8 format 

See the Rubric below for assessment

Accommodations for DRC or Document Accessibility

It is university policy to provide, on a flexible and individualized basis, reasonable accommodations to students who have disabilities that may affect their ability to participate in course activities or meet course requirements. Students with disabilities are encouraged to contact their instructor to discuss their individual needs for accommodations. If you need to convert a file to a more accessible medium, please use Sensus Access.

assignments.description:
Style and Clarity

Score: Complete/Incomplete goes to Choose Your Skills Total

Due: any time after receiving feedback from your instructor until March 9 by 11:59 pm

Since your papers are your best teachers for improving clarity and develop a stylistic voice, they will provide the materials for this assignment. You may complete this assignment once you receive instructor feedback from your Claim of Value essay. 

For your Style and Clarity assignment, please do the following:

Select two paragraphs from either your Claim of Value essay that you consider to be your weakest parts of the essay. These can be subsequent paragraphs or isolated paragraphs within the essay, but they must come from this essay project. Revise these paragraphs by creating more rhythmic sentence structure, using more concise language, employ stronger transition use, and incorporate more thorough description or analysis.  Explain why you made the changes you made underneath the revised paragraphs. Use the following resources to help you in your revision process:

  • Coherence: Making Connections in Your Writing
  • English Shorthand Abbreviations Legend
  • Writing and Reasoning: ePrime
  • Writing Clear and Effective Sentences

Format:

  1. Provide original paragraphs
  2. Label and provide revised paragraphs and highlight those changes with the highlighter function on your word program
  3. Explain the choices you made for those changes

assignments.description:
Lab 0, CSC/CPE 203 - Python to Java (types)

Orientation — Explicit types, semi-colons, and curly braces

This lab is designed to highlight many of the differences between Python and Java. Many of the differences are purely syntactical. Other features, like for loops, function differently. You'll need to get back in the habit of using your semi-colons! Those already familiar with Java should finish the lab and then offer to help others. This is a half week lab.

Objectives

  • To be able to translate a Python program to Java.
  • To be able to develop and run a complete Java program.

Resources

  • Your peers
  • Your instructor
  • The Java Standard Library - Bookmark this web page, you will be using the Java Standard Library documentation regularly this quarter.

 

Lab 0, CSC/CPE 203 - Python to Java (types)

Orientation — Explicit types, semi-colons, and curly braces

This lab is designed to highlight many of the differences between Python and Java. Many of the differences are purely syntactical. Other features, like for loops, function differently. If you are like me, you will need to get back in the habit of using your semi-colons! Those already familiar with Java should finish the lab and then offer to help others. This is a half week lab

Objectives

  • To be able to translate a Python program to Java.
  • To be able to develop and run a complete Java program.

Resources

  • Your peers
  • Your instructor
  • The Java Standard Library - Bookmark this web page, you will be using the Java Standard Library documentation regularly this quarter.

Download the files for this lab.

Ground Rules

You may collaborate with your peers as much as you like on this lab. Labs are for your practice. Make sure you can do every lab!

Setup

You can write code for this lab using any editor you like, but you are required to compile and run Java from the command-line. Yes, even though there are very good IDEs available for Java, running on the command-line is still a valuable skill.

To compile the java lab code file, type:

javac Lab00.java

To run the code then type:

java Lab00

Specification

  1. From the starting code run lab00.py. Make sure you understand how everything in this file works. If you need help (or haven’t learned Python) please ask me or a classmate to explain things. You will NOT be tested on Python this quarter, but will need to understand this file enough to write an equivalent java version.

  2. Now take a look at the file Lab00.java. This file is incomplete and you will need to finish it. Translate the given Python file to Java. Please translate everything, including the comments!   Remember: To compile your files, type:

    javac Lab00.java

    To run the code then type:

    java Lab00

Demo

Demonstrate your working program to your instructor. Be prepared to show your source code. Come to lab on the due day with your lab finished!

Ground Rules

You may collaborate with your peers as much as you like on this lab. Labs are for your practice. Make sure you can do every lab!

Setup

You can write code for this lab using any editor you like, but you are required to compile and run Java from the command-line. Yes, even though there are very good IDEs available for Java, running on the command-line is still a valuable skill.

To compile the java lab code file, type:

javac Lab00.java

To run the code then type:

java Lab00

Specification

  1. From the starting code run lab00.py. Make sure you understand how everything in this file works. If you need help (or haven’t learned Python) please ask me or a classmate to explain things. You will NOT be tested on Python this quarter, but will need to understand this file enough to write an equivalent java version.

  2. Now take a look at the file Lab00.java. This file is incomplete and you will need to finish it. Translate the given Python file to Java. Please translate everything, including the comments!  To compile your files, type:

    javac Lab00.java

    To run the code then type:

    java Lab00

Demo

Demonstrate your working program to the instructor in lab. Be prepared to show your source code. Come to lab on the due day with your lab finished! If you can't make it to lab, upload a zipped folder containing your solution.

Orientation — Explicit types, semi-colons, and curly braces

This lab is designed to highlight many of the differences between Python and Java. Many of the differences are purely syntactical. Other features, like for loops, function differently. If you are like me, you will need to get back in the habit of using your semi-colons! Those already familiar with Java should finish the lab and then offer to help others. This is a half week lab

Objectives

  • To be able to translate a Python program to Java.
  • To be able to develop and run a complete Java program.

Resources

  • Your peers
  • Your instructor
  • The Java Standard Library - Bookmark this web page, you will be using the Java Standard Library documentation regularly this quarter.

Download the files for this lab.

Ground Rules

You may collaborate with your peers as much as you like on this lab. Labs are for your practice. Make sure you can do every lab!

Setup

You can write code for this lab using any editor you like, but you are required to compile and run Java from the command-line. Yes, even though there are very good IDEs available for Java, running on the command-line is still a valuable skill.

To compile the java lab code file, type:

javac Lab00.java

To run the code then type:

java Lab00

Specification

  1. From the starting code run lab00.py. Make sure you understand how everything in this file works. If you need help (or haven’t learned Python) please ask me or a classmate to explain things. You will NOT be tested on Python this quarter, but will need to understand this file enough to write an equivalent java version.

  2. Now take a look at the file Lab00.java. This file is incomplete and you will need to finish it. Translate the given Python file to Java. Please translate everything, including the comments!   Remember: To compile your files, type:

    javac Lab00.java

    To run the code then type:

    java Lab00

Demo

Demonstrate your working program to your instructor. Be prepared to show your source code. Come to lab on the due day with your lab finished!

You will NOT be tested on Python this quarter, but will need to understand this file enough to write an equivalent java version.

assignment.name: Lab 0 — Python to Java

assignments.description:
Lab 1, CSC/CPE 203 — Loops and Lists

This lab is adapted from this assignment in Evan Peck’s list of Ethical CS modules for CS 1.

Objectives

  • To be able to iterate through different Java collections with various control loops (part 1)
  • To be able to write your own class with specified methods (part 2).
  • To be able to use unit testing, including writing your own tests for your code (part 1 and 2)
  • To be able to write a very simple UML diagram of a class (part 3)

Resources

  • Your peers
  • Your instructor
  • The Java Standard Library (Java 17) — Bookmark this web page, you will be using the Java Standard Library documentation regularly this quarter.

Setup

Like the previous lab, you will use IntelliJ IDEA to write and run your code.

Important: For this lab, we will be using JUnit to help us test the correctness of our code. You can either let IntelliJ add it to your project automatically, or you can do it manually yourself. To do it manually, you’ll need to download the JUnit library (available in the Modules page) and add it to your project in IntelliJ IDEA. Instructions for how to do it either way can be found here.

Aside: What’s JUnit? JUnit lets us make assertions about what our code should do. You can think of them as statements of expectations—for example, if we wrote a program to do addition, then we can expect that 2 + 2 = 4 and that -1 + 3 = 2. As a project grows over time, these assertions (“tests”) grow along with it, giving us a “safety net” of checks that can assure us that our program is doing what we expect.

Retrieve the files provided for this lab by accepting the assignment from github classroom here: https://classroom.github.com/a/4zX9oQpX

This lab allows you to practice Java syntax related to collections and control (Part 1), basic class structure and methods (Part 2), and includes an introduction to UML (Part 3). Those already familiar with Java should finish the lab and then offer to help others.

Algorithms as Future-Makers

Imagine you are working for Moogle, a well-known tech company that receives tens of thousands of job applications from graduating seniors every year. Since the company receives too many job applications for the Human Resources Department (HR) to individually assess in a reasonable amount of time, you are asked to create a program that algorithmically analyzes applications and selects the ones most worth passing onto HR. Your job is to build an algorithm that helps determine the order which job applicants will be called in for an interview. This is a real scenario playing out every day and will likely impact you as an applicant someday.

To make it easier for their algorithms to process, Moogle designs their application forms to get some numerical data about their applicants’ education. Applicants must enter the grades they receive from their 5 core CS courses, as well as their overall non-CS GPA at the university. For your convenience, this will be stored in a Java array or list that you can access. For example, a student who received the following scores…

  • Intro to CS: 100
  • Data Structures: 95
  • Algorithms: 89
  • Computer Organization: 91
  • Operating Systems: 75
  • Non-CS GPA: 83

…would result in the following list:

[100, 95, 89, 91, 75, 83]

That is, you can assume that index 0 is always Intro to CS, 1 is always Data Structures, and so on.

Part 1: Java Control Constructs and Introduction to Collections

In the provided part1 subdirectory, edit each of the given files to complete the implementations and tests. Comments in each file will direct the edits that you are expected to make. Look up any classes you don’t know how to use (such as Map) in the Java Standard Library.

It is recommended that you use the order of the unit tests in TestCases.java as a guide for the order in which to complete the methods. This order corresponds to the increasing complexity of the methods. A good process to follow would be to read the first group of tests in TestCases.java. Edit the corresponding class to make the code pass the tests. Run the tests to make sure they now pass. Add the required additional test case. Run the tests again. Then move on to the next group.

The output for a failed test is incredibly verbose (a stack trace is printed). You can see the specific error at the numbered line above each stack trace. As you fix the code one file at a time, re-run the code to make sure that the number of errors is decreasing!

Part 2: Classes and Objects

For this part, you will implement a simple class (named Applicant) representing a job applicant and their resume. Do this by creating a file named Applicant.java and put in all the code specified below. This class must support the following operations (including a single constructor).

  • public Applicant(String name, List<CourseGrade> grades) — Constructor.
  • public String getName() — Returns the applicant’s name.
  • public List<CourseGrade> getGrades() — Returns the applicant’s list of scores.
  • public CourseGrade getGradeFor(String course) — Returns the score that was asked for. The course parameter can be one of the courses as defined here. That is, getGradeFor("Intro to CS") will return the CourseGrade at index 0, getGradeFor("DataStructures") will return the CourseGrade at index 1, and so on.

Once this class is created, look at the TestCases.java file in the part2 directory—complete the test cases or add new ones as appropriate.

Creating your own filter

You’ve now written and seen the effect of 3 different analyses. It’s time to create your own.

You will decide what you think is the most fair way to filter applications. You shouldn’t just use what we’ve created so far. Come up with something better. Keep in mind that you will be expected to explain your rationale for your filter.

So far, our Applicant only has a name and course grades. Do you want to take more information into account while deciding whether or not to accept the applicant? Add the appropriate fields to the Applicant class.

Then, in the SimpleIf class, create a new function:

  • public static boolean analyzeApplicant2(Applicant applicant)

And implement your new filtering mechanism. In a JavaDoc comment for analyzeApplicant2, explain in plain English your rationale for this new applicant filter.

Finally, write tests in part2/TestCases.java to ensure that your new filter is working correctly. How many assertions will you need to be confident that your filter is working as expected?

Part 3: UML

See the following pdf description of the UML portion of the lab.

Demo

Show your finished UML from part 3 to the instructor in lab on the day it is due. Parts 1 and 2 will be submitted to GitHub. If time permits, you may also demo Parts 1 and 2 to the instructor.

Submission

Submit your code for Parts 1 and 2 to GitHub by the due date. That means you must commit and push your code. We will test and grade the code that you submit. Code submitted after midnight on the due date will not be graded.

assignment.name: Lab 1 — Loops and lists

assignments.description:
Lab 2, CSC/CPE 203 — Static Methods and Instance Methods

Objectives

  • To write overloaded methods that operate on objects of different types
  • To write static methods to perform operations on provided objects
  • To write instance methods to perform similar operations
  • To able to write your own test cases to check that the code you write does what you expect it to do

Resources

Same as the previous lab.

You can get the base code at the following GitHub link: https://classroom.github.com/a/6EOtZO47

Greenhouse gases

Emissions of gases that create a greenhouse effect have resulted in large-scale shifts in global weather patterns. A greenhouse effect occurs when the Earth absorbs sunlight and then radiates it as heat. Gases emitted largely due to human activities—like carbon dioxide and methane gas—have collected in the atmosphere, slowing the rate at which this heat leaves the atmosphere and escapes into space. This has resulted in large-scale changes in global weather patterns, i.e., climate change.

In this lab, we will use Object-oriented design principles to (1) model some data about global greenhouse gas emissions (obtained from the Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research), and (2) use the resulting classes to help answer some research questions about greenhouse gas emissions.

Part 1: Classes and Overloaded Methods

In the provided part1 subdirectory, implement the following classes with these general requirements.

  • Each instance variable must be private
  • Provide constructors for creating new instances of the class with values specified as parameters
  • Provide the appropriate “accessor”/“getter” methods for the instance variables (see PartOneTestCases.java for names)
  • You may add methods beyond those required, but any such additional method must be private

Automaton Warning: You are an intelligent person; you should not just mechanically apply these rules only to satisfy a style checker in order to complete the lab. Instead, consider the reasons for these rules, what violating them exposes to the user/client of the corresponding class, and what following them guarantees to you, the implementer. If you aren’t sure, ask your neighbor, they might have thoughts of their own.

Requirements specific to each class are described below.

Classes

Emission.java

The Emission class represents the emissions in kilo-tons of the greenhouse gases carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrous oxide (N2O), and methane gas (CH4). Each emission amount is represented as a Double.

So for example, an Emission might look like this:

co2: 288000.0,
n2o: 684000.0,
ch4: 4690000.0

Note: The Emission class should have a constructor that takes double values for the CO2, N2O, and CH4 emissions, in that order.

Country.java

The Country class represents a country and its greenhouse gas emissions over time. Each Country is represented by its name (String) and a Map from years (Integer) to the greenhouse gas Emission amounts for that year. So, the following…

name: "United States"
emissions:
  1970: Emission(
    co2: 288000.0,
    n2o: 684000.0,
    ch4: 4690000.0
  ) 
  1971: Emission(
    co2: 290000.0,
    n2o: 689000.0,
    ch4: 4560000.0
  )

…would indicate that the United States emitted 288,000 kilo-tons of carbon dioxide, 684,000 kilo-tons of nitrous oxide, and 4,690,000 kilo-tons of methane gas in 1970; and 290,000 kilo-tons of carbon-dioxide, 689,000 kilo-tons of nitrous oxide, and 4,560,000 kilo-tons of methane gas in 1971.

Sector.java

Sector.java represents a particular sector of industry and its global greenhouse gas emissions over time, measured in kilo-tons.1 Each Sector is represented by a name (String) and a Map from years (Integer) to greenhouse gas emissions measured in kilo-tons during that year (Double). So, the following…

name: "Transport",
emissions:
  1970: 2278.8,
  1971: 2358.43

…would indicate that the Transport industry emitted 2278.8 kilo-tons of greenhouse gases globally in 1970, and the equivalent of 2358.43 kilo-tons of CO2 globally in 1971 globally.

Note that as your implementation will be tested with PartOneTestCases, you may want to read exactly what the expected “get” method names are!

Overloaded methods

Define a Util class with two static methods to getYearWithHighestEmissions. Each such method takes, as its single parameter, one of the classes defined in the previous step (i.e., there is one getYearWithHighestEmissions method that takes a Country, and one getYearWithHighestEmissions that takes a Sector) and returns the year with the highest greenhouse gas emissions as an int.

To be more specific, do the following:

  • For the method that takes a Sector, return the year with the highest emissions in its Map of years to emissions.
  • For the method that takes a Country, return the year with the highest total emissions in its Map of years to CO2, N2O, and CH4 emissions.

A method (or methods) like getYearWithHighestEmissions is considered overloaded since there is a separate definition for different parameter types. This is also referred to as ad-hoc polymorphism because the (theoretically) single method is effectively defined to work with a small set of parameter types, not for all parameter types—that is, the method takes “many forms”, but only very specific forms are supported. You will likely hear "overloaded" much more often, but “ad-hoc polymorphism” sounds so much cooler (though, admittedly, it is a bit more intimidating).

Note that to call a static method like these, you can invoke:

Util.getYearWithHighestEmissions(new Country("United States", ...))

Deeper understanding: How does the Java implementation know which version of getYearWithHighestEmissions to use when the method is invoked (not-so-great hint at this point, the compiler determines the implementation under this scenario)? If the answer is not apparent, then think about the different method invocations and speak with those around you. If the answer seems obvious, then hold on to that belief for the next few weeks to see if it continues to hold.

Tests

Yes, of course you will want to test all of these operations. Add your tests to the provided PartOneTestCases.java file.

Helper: here is an example of testing the highest emissions method for the Transport sector.

@Test
public void testYearWithHighestEmissions() {
    // Create the testable Sector object
    Map<Integer, Double> emissions = new HashMap<>();
    emissions.put(1970, 2278.8);
    emissions.put(1971, 2356.43);
    emissions.put(1972, 2243.3);
    Sector sector = new Sector("Transport", emissions);
    
    // Check that the method works as expected
    assertEquals(1971, Util.getYearWithHighestEmissions(sector));
}

Part 2: Methods

Copy your files from part1 into part2 (you will not need the test cases file from part1).

The definition of yearWithHighestEmissions in the first part of this lab does not follow an object-oriented style. This part of the lab asks that you make a few modifications to improve the code (further such improvements can come with later material). Don’t worry this part will be easier!

From Util.java, move each getYearWithHighestEmissions method into the appropriate class (as a non-static method, i.e., instance method) corresponding to yearWithHigestEmissions’s parameter. The goal is that each object “knows how” to compute its own year with the highest greenhouse gas emissions. As such, yearWithHighestEmissions will no longer need to take a parameter (it acts on this which refers to…well, there is no universally accepted term for the target of this because computer scientists are not very good at naming things or at agreeing on the meaning of names/terms. You might hear “calling object”, “current object”, “context object”, “target”, “callee”, “referent”, “object on which the method was invoked” (that last one is real, and accurate, but is a sign of giving up on naming)).

You can remove Util.java once this is done.

Take a moment…do you like one style over the other?

Tests

Add tests to the provided PartTwoTestCases.java file. This is where you will also be able to see the changes of having the methods defined within each class (instance methods) versus the static methods with which this lab started. Again, there should be an added test for each of the types of getYearWithHighestEmissions.

Again, reflect—do you like one style over the other?

Part 3: Answering some questions

Take a look at the Main.java file in the part3 directory. Don’t modify any of the existing methods in this file. In the main method, notice that we have created two lists, countries and sectors. Both contain real data about greenhouse gas emissions from 1970 to 2012, sourced from the Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research. In this part, you will write methods to help make sense of this data by answering some questions.

Write methods to do the following:

  • Given a list of countries (List<Country>), identify the country with the highest CH4 emissions in a specified year. To do this, write a static method in the Country class with the following signature:
public static Country countryWithHighestCH4InYear(List<Country> countries, int year)
  • Given a list of countries (List<Country>), identify the country with the highest change in total greenhouse gas emissions between two specified years. Write a static method in the Country class with the signature below. In addition to returning the country, print its name and the change in emissions you identified..
public static Country countryWithHighestChangeInEmissions(List<Country> countries, int startYear, int endYear)
  • Given a list of sectors (List<Sector>), identify the sector which has seen the highest average greenhouse gas emissions between two specified years. Write a static method in the Sector class with the following signature. Print the sector name and the average value you identified.
public static Sector sectorWithHighestAverageEmissions(List<Sector> sectors, int startYear, int endYear)

Hint: Note that startYear and endYear provide you with a range of years. What do you use to compute something across a range of numbers?

Back in Main.java, use these methods to answer the following questions using the data in the countries and sectors lists.

  • Which country had the highest methane gas emissions in 2000?
  • Which country had the highest increase in greenhouse gas emissions between 1988 (the year the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change was formed) and 2012?
  • Which sector had the highest average greenhouse gas emissions between 1988 and 2012?

Print out your answers in the main method.

Submission and demo

Be sure to commit and push your code the due date.

Demonstrate all parts of your working program to your instructor at once. Be prepared to show and answer questions about your source code. You will need to demo your working code IN LAB on the day it is due. (Partial credit available at the instructor’s discretion). You may not demo after your assigned lab period, unless arranged with the instructor beforehand.

  1. Actually, emissions of gases other than CO2 are measured in equivalent kilo-tons of CO2. Amounts of other gases are converted to the equivalent amount of CO2 with the same global warming potential.↩︎
